The Greater Chennai Corporation has decided to prepare a tree plantation strategy for coping with future disasters. The strategy will also be integrated with the Smart Cities Mission proposals.

Following a brainstorming session with NGOs, research scholars and scientists on Friday, the civic body is set to collect comprehensive information relating to trees using GIS. The city is yet to have a comprehensive database of trees.

The collection of information through GIS has been done by NGOs in ward 176 of Adyar zone. Similar surveys will be conducted in all the 200 wards in the city before chalking out the tree plantation strategy. “We will prepare a detailed project report shortly,” said Corporation Commissioner and Special Officer D. Karthikeyan.

According to participants in the brainstorming session, the damage to trees in many parts of the city was caused because the right trees were not planted.

The Corporation will rope in NGOs and residents’ associations to preserve trees. Corporation officials will advise residents not to remove trees on their premises and offer technical assistance to improve green cover in each area. Many residents have started removing trees and reducing green cover on their premises after Cyclone Vardah. According to Development Regulation 32 of the Chennai Metropolitan Development Authority, the authorities issuing planning permission and building approval may issue a tree preservation order to save green cover in any private area. A number of participants at the brainstorming session also stressed the need for identifying species of trees suitable for each road in residential areas developed along beaches, hills, marshes or waterbodies.

Residents of each area will get information on aspects of tree plantation, including outlets supplying saplings. Each of the saplings will be planted in a space with a dimension of 4 ft by 4 ft.
title: Seeking smart strategies for tree planting

text:
Without doubt, 2016 has been a tumultuous year for Tamil Nadu. Looking back, it would certainly be in contention for the title annus horribilis, beginning with the aftermath of unprecedented floods in December 2015, and at curtain call, the State struggling to grapple with the death of a Chief Minister and the resultant political pandemonium.

In January last, the State was barely recovering from the devastating impact caused by the floods of December 2015, but the events of the year, as they unfolded, brought greater shocks to Tamil Nadu. Undeniably, the biggest of them was the death of Chief Minister Jayalalithaa. She was hospitalised on September 22 and stayed at the Apollo Hospitals for 75 days. But, her sudden cardiac arrest when it seemed as if she was recovering, was the single biggest event for the State in 2016. The events that followed are likely to reshape the political profile of the State.

O. Panneerselvam, who had stepped in twice before for Jayalalithaa as Chief Minister, had been reallocated her portfolios when in hospital, and it was but natural that he was nominated Chief Minister by his party after her death, despite the intrigue and secrecy that preceded his anointing.

It was later, the succession of Jayalalithaa’s close aide V.K. Sasikala to the position of general secretary of the AIADMK that caused a raging storm, with the year ending on speculation about the extent of her ambition.

The Assembly elections in May saw the victory of the AIADMK over the DMK. Elections 2016 put paid to the idea of a possible third front as an alternative to the two Dravidian parties existed. The People’s Welfare Front, cobbled together by MDMK leader Vaiko and including the VCK, Communist parties and DMDK leader Vijayakant bombed. Reports of rampant corruption caused the postponement of polls to two seats: Thanjavur and Aravakurichi. However, the ruling party picked these up easily later, as well as the Thiruparankundram constituency in the by-election.

During September and October, protests erupted in Karnataka and Tamil Nadu, and for weeks, transportation across the border ceased, in continuation of the decades-long rivalry over sharing of Cauvery river water between the two States.

In June 2016, the State froze in shock at the gruesome murder of Infosys employee S. Swathi at the Nungambakkam railway station. A manhunt ensued, and the State was seized with the details of the case, right up to the sensational early morning arrest, incarceration and alleged ‘suicide’ of the accused in the case, Ram Kumar.

Yet another train that caught the imagination of the public was the daring robbery in the Salem-Chennai express in August, where thieves made away with Rs. 5.78 crore of soiled currency being transported to the RBI for incineration.

As 2016 bids farewell, concerns remain over the water position in the State, its political future, and the fate of the other Dravidian party (DMK) whose patriarch M. Karunanidhi has been ailing for a while now, and of course, Chennaiites wonder what fresh monsters hide behind another December (2017).
title: Three coronations, a funeral, a heist and a cyclone

text:
The Principal Judge for CBI cases, Chennai, has dismissed the bail applications moved by former Tirumala Tirupathi Devasthanams (TTD) Board Member and industrialist J. Sekhar Reddy and four of his associates who were arrested by the CBI for possession of currencies in new denominations to the tune of several crore.

On December 8, the Income Tax Department conducted raids in various properties owned by Mr. Reddy and his associates and seized Rs.34 crore in new denomination and a huge quantity of gold. Subsequently, the CBI registered cases under the Prevention of Corruption Act (PC), 1988, and the Indian Penal Code (IPC). On December 21, the Central agency arrested Mr. Reddy and his associate V. Srinivasalu.

Later, his other associates Dindigul Rathinam, Muthupettai Ramachandran and Prem Kumar were also arrested by the CBI.

Soon after the accused were remanded, the CBI moved an application seeking 15 days custody of Mr. Reddy. Similarly, all the accused persons, including Mr. Reddy, moved applications seeking to enlarge them on bail.

After hearing the arguments of the counsels representing the accused and the CBI, the Judge on Friday refused to allow the bail petitions, noting that the investigation is in initial stage, and that there are chances for the accused to tamper the evidence.

The judge also dismissed the custody application moved by the CBI.

‘Since the investigation is in initial stage, the accused could tamper with evidence’
title: CBI court dismisses bail plea of Sekhar Reddy

text:
The Cooum riverfront is likely to get yet another makeover. After a delay, the Greater Chennai Corporation has started work on developing a 23-km-long fence along the Cooum River.

Owing to a delay in getting CRZ clearance for the Integrated Cooum River Ecorestoration Projects, the civic body has decided to start work in areas that do not require CRZ clearance. Senior officials of Greater Chennai Corporation have recently visited other parts of the country to study aspects of riverfront development such as Sabarmati Riverfront.

“We have started work along a 200-metre length of the Cooum river in Rail Nagar near Padi Kuppam Road. The work will be completed in three years,” said an official.

Officials are also studying Sabarmati Riverfront, covering aspects including riverfront market, amusement park, exhibition centre, sports complex, events ground and urban forest.

Work on parks along five locations and four walkways will also be implemented shortly.

“The fence development project was expected to begin in 2015 after removing 14,000 encroachments. But many of the encroachments are yet to be removed,” said an official.

The fence is estimated at Rs.40 crore and the parks will be developed at an estimated cost of Rs.11 crore. Chennai Corporation officials are planning to conduct brain storming sessions to implement riverfront development of the Cooum. The civic body will start public consultations with local residents of neighbourhoods before finalising the riverfront makeover.

Work on a 9.6-km stretch of the river from Chetpet bridge to the river mouth will not begin owing to the delay in CRZ clearance.

Work order for eight parks was issued at an estimated cost of Rs. 39 crore a few years ago. But the work has not yet started in many areas.
title: Cooum riverfront to get makeover

text:
Rajan Eye Care Hospital Chairman and Medical Director Mohan Rajan (left) said comprehensive eye screening will be done for all slum dwellers. —Photo: K.V. Srinivasan

Residents of low-income neighbourhoods are set to get better tertiary eye care facilities at their doorstep shortly.

As part of the Corporate Social Responsibility initiatives, various institutions on Friday launched a Slum Vision Project through Rajan Eye Care Hospital.

Launching the project, District Governor RI 3230 Natarajan Nagoji said three lakh residents in Chennai are likely to be covered.

Rajan Eye Care Hospital Chairman and Medical Director Mohan Rajan said comprehensive eye screening will be done for all slum dwellers. “The aim of the project is to identify and treat curable blindness in the slum population. More than 26 per cent of the population in Chennai are living in slums. There are 3,000 slums with a population of two million,” said Dr. Rajan.

A total of 1,000 slums will be covered in the next four years in Chennai Metropolitan Area and its suburbs.

The project will be implemented by a mobile ophthalmic clinic supported by the Cognizant Foundation and the Vijay Amritraj Foundation. The mobile clinic is equipped with Fundus camera, green laser, yag laser, tele ophthalmic unit, slit lamp, biomicroscope and non contact tonometer.

The mobile clinic will visit slums and carry out vision testing, diabetic retinopathy screening, glaucoma screening, laser treatment, green laser for diabetic retinopathy free of cost. “Patients who require cataract or other eye surgeries will be transported to the base hospitalfree of cost,” said Dr.Rajan.

A total of 1,000 slums will be covered in the next four years in Chennai and

its suburbs
title: Tertiary eye care at doorstep of slum-dwellers soon

text:
The Chennai city police have finally apprehended notorious criminal ‘Neeravi’ Murugan, who was wanted for his involvement in several cases of chain snatching. He was apprehended by a special team formed by the Rayala Nagar police.

A senior police officer said ‘Neeravi’ Murugan had been operating with his friend Sakthivel of Tondiarpet. The duo were the prime suspects in several incidents of chain snatching and burglary in Porur, Valasaravakkam, Virugambakkam and Vadapalani. The city police formed a special team headed by Inspector Kumaran and Sub Inspector Jayaraman, who began tracking the criminal.

Initially, Murugan escaped to Renigunta in Andhra Pradesh, but returned and resumed targeting women who were alone in the houses and snatched their chains.

Murugan, a native of Thoothukudi, is an accused in a total of 40 criminal cases across the State, including murder cases.

The accused was arrested along with Sakthivel when a patrol team stopped his two-wheeler in Porur.

‘Viral’ robbery

Murugan had gained notoriety after a video of him and an accomplice waylaying and robbing a teacher at knifepoint on December 19, 2014, became viral.

The police recovered six two-wheelers, gold chains and several knives from the duo.

The criminal and his associate were wanted by the police in several cases of chain snatching
title: Police nab history-sheeter ‘Neeravi’ Murugan

text:
The 18th edition of Shaastra, the techno-fest of Indian Institute of Technology-Madras, will commence on Saturday with a focus on accessibility.

The institute will conduct a hackathon for the visually impaired. The students of IIT-M, along with professors of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and University of California, Berkeley, plan to train visually challenged students to present their projects at Shaastra.

Shaastra’s social campaign this year was on waste management and sanitation. The campaign was to collect used plastic bottles. The bottles are used as substitutes for bricks in the construction of toilets in villages near Chennai.

Every year, internationally recognised experts are invited to give talks during the event as part of the Spotlight Lecture series.

This year, William E. Moerner, Nobel laureate in chemistry, Yoshua Bengio, father of deep learning, former tennis player Vijay Amritraj and visual effects designer Srinivas Mohan will be addressing the students.

There would be a night drone racing event that is being organised in association with the Indian Drone Racing League.

Also part of the schedule are the student-run show Envisage and an exhibition of innovations in science and technology from across the world.

Visitors would get to interact with India’s first 3D printed humanoid robot and the world’s first mind-controlled wheelchair.
title: IIT-M’s Shaastra to begin today

text:
V.K. Sasikala, who is all set to take charge as general secretary of the ruling All India Anna Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam (AIADMK) on Saturday, will be the sixth person and the second woman to hold the post.

M.G. Ramachandran, who founded the party in October 1972 following his exit from the Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam (DMK), was the first general secretary. He occupied the post till June 1978.

When reports of infighting in the AIADMK cropped up, MGR took back the post in October 1986 and went on to hold it till his death in December 1987.

A perusal of materials available with The Hindu archives reveals that at a public meeting in Thirukazhukundram in the present Kancheepuram district to mark the party inception 44 years ago, MGR had said that workers of the party would hereafter elect the party general secretary and the term of the office would be only three years.

V.R. Nedunchezhian, who joined the AIADMK in September 1977 after running the Makkal DMK for five months that year following his resignation from the DMK, was initially made the officiating general secretary and subsequently, the full-fledged general secretary in January 1979.

Nedunchezhian had to quit the post in June 1980 after he became Finance Minister. The next month, P.U. Shanmugam succeeded him. Consequent to becoming Local Administration Minister in March 1985, he resigned from the post.

S. Raghavanandam, who became the next general secretary, occupied the post nearly for one and a half years.

After the death of MGR, the party suffered a split. On January 1, 1988, Jayalalithaa, who was the then propaganda secretary, announced that she assumed the general secretaryship of the party in response to, what was claimed, a request conveyed by 15 district secretaries of the party (out of a total of 20 secretaries) through a letter. For sometime, this group was identified as AIADMK (Jayalalithaa).

The other faction owing allegiance to MGR’s widow Janaki Ramachandran came to be called the AIADMK (Janaki). Rahgavanandam, who was a senior deputy general secretary at the time of the split, became the general secretary in-charge of this faction.

After the two factions suffered heavy reverses in the January 1989 Assembly elections, they came together and became the unified AIADMK. The party symbol of “two leaves,” which was suspended following the split, was also restored to the party in February 1989. Jayalalithaa continued to hold on to the post of the general secretary till her death in December 2016.
title: She is the sixth person to be AIADMK general secretary

text: The Railway Protection Force has seized about nine kilograms of banned narcotic substance cannabis (ganja). Sources said RPF personnel were conducting routine checks on Howrah – Chennai Mail that reached Chennai Central . The team noticed an unclaimed bag under of the berths. Suspecting that it might be an explosive device, the unit from the Bomb Detection and Disposal Squad made a complete check and declared that the bag did not contain any explosive device. Policemen then opened the bag, which contained nine kilograms of cannabis. The bag was later handed over to the Narcotics Intelligence Bureau.
title: Narcotic drugs seized from train

text:
Dumping of garbage and setting them on fire continues unabated on the fringes of Outer Ring Road, a vital link to the city’s extended areas.

A drive from Minjur-Vandalur on the Outer Ring Road (ORR) is not a pleasant experience as non-stop burning of garbage along the highway at many spots affects visibility and also causes irritation to many motorists. A resident of Tiruneermalai, M. Keerthivasan, said several motorists witnessed the burning of garbage along the service roads of the Outer Ring Road. Their locality has, for a long time, remained largely neglected and even waste from industrial units was burnt here, he added.

“While the situation near the border of Kundrathur Town Panchayat and Sirukalathur village panchayat is the worst in terms of sanitation, the scenes near Tirumudivakkam and several other stretches remain garbage strewn,” he said. According to him, garbage dumping and subsequent burning has been taking place in this area for many years as a result of which even the wells here are contaminated. According to residents, garbage along Adyar River garbage is dumped by village panchayats of Kundrathur Panchayat Union and Kundrathur Town Panchayat.

Residents have appealed to the Panchayat Union, District Rural Development Agency and Tamil Nadu Pollution Control Board to intervene and stop the menace.

Officials of Directorate of Town Panchayats said the garbage collected from 18 wards are being segregated, recycled and taken to the compost yard to minimise disposal in landfills. The town panchayat is one of the local bodies that awaits location of an alternate site for landfill. But the huge mound of garbage has to be handled using bio-mining process, for which clearance is awaited from the State Exchequer.

Wells have been contaminated due to garbage dumping and subsequent burning in the area for years
title: Burning of garbage poses environmental threat

text:
The Chennai City police have given security to film actor Anandraj at his house in Nungambakkam.

Policemen were posted at his house after the actor registered a complaint that he had received death threats over phone.

Nungambakkam police officials said the actor had sought police security in view of the threats and based on the complaint security has been beefed up at his house. Film actor Anandraj who was a member of the All India Anna Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam (AIADMK) and quit from the party on Wednesday.
title: Security provided to actor Anandraj

text:
The annual Carnatic Eastern Ethnic New Year celebrations of Carnatic musicians is being organised at Vani Mahal, G.N.Chetty Road, this year.

The event organised by Carnatica in association with Sri Thyaga Brahma Gana Sabha will commence at 10 p.m. on December 31 and conclude by 2 a.m. It is open to all rasikas.

“This year’s event will be dedicated as a musical offering to pray that 2017 is free of man-made and natural disasters,” said K. N. Shashikiran, founder trustee, Carnatica.

The event will be inaugurated by vocalist Aruna Sairam. Mridangam maestro Umayalpuram K. Sivaraman presides and presents ‘Rhythm Cascade- Man Vs Machine’ on the Glass Mrudangam. The event would include meditation through music, chanting and group rendition of musical prayers at midnight by leading musician, who would present Endaro Mahanubhavulu , Maithreem Bhajatha and Shanthi Nilava Vendum.

The choir will be lead by Carnatic vocalist Sudha Ragunathan.

The list of performing artistes include Neyveli Santhanagopalan, Abhishek Raghuram, K.Gayathri, Amritha Murali, Ramakrishnan Murthy, K. Bharat Sundar, Chinmaya Sisters, Akkarai Sisters, Tiruvarur Girish, Jayanth J.A., V. Shankaranarayanan, Sriranjani Santhanagopalan, Rithvik Raja and Nirmala Rajasekhar, the release said.

For details contact: 94440 18269.
title: Spend New Year’s eve with Carnatic music in Chennai

text:
There is a need to develop cost-effective and eco-friendly technologies to manage water resources. Desalination and water recycling are emerging to be reliable alternative sources of water, Rajiv Mittal, managing director, VA Tech Wabag Limited, said here on Thursday. The company is engaged in maintaining the Nemmeli desalination plant of Chennai Metrowater and he was delivering the T.S. Narayanaswami Memorial Endowment Lecture on ‘Managing the Difficult Water’ organised by the Indian Institute of Chemical Engineers at Anna University.

While use of recycled water is common for industry, there was still a need for change in the mindset of people to reuse water for drinking, he said and highlighted the strategies such as rainwater harvesting and interlinking of rivers to ensure water security, he said.

As part of its efforts to meet industrial water requirements, Chennai Metrowater awarded project to VA Tech Wabag to supply tertiary treated sewage — an advanced process that produces high quality water — to industries. The treated water will be supplied to industries around Ooragadam.
title: ‘Cost-effective methods needed to recycle water’

text:
Vivek Papisetty, son of former Tamil Nadu Chief Secretary P. Rama Mohana Rao, appeared before income tax officials on Friday for questioning in connection with the searches at his home and office.

A senior official from the Income Tax Department, told The Hindu , “He arrived here (Income Tax office) at 5.30 pm and was here till 8 pm. We have recorded his statement.”

The official refused to disclose the details of the interaction.

‘Undisclosed income’

On December 21, the I-T Department conducted searches on the residential and office premises of Mr. Vivek.

The taxmen had unearthed “undisclosed income” to the tune of Rs. 5 crore from his house on day one.

On day two, his offices at Chamiers Road, Nandanam was searched by the sleuths.

The premises housed three companies – Trans Earth Logistics, Blue Ocean Personnel and Allied Services Private Limited and Virtu Technologies.

The Income Tax Department had issued summons to Mr. Vivek and asked him to appear before them last week. But he cited personal reasons and failed to turn up.

Official refuses to disclose the details of the interaction that went on for

two-and-half hours
title: Rama Mohana Rao’s son quizzed by I-T officials

text:
In a freak accident, a newspaper delivery man died after he suffered a grievous neck injury caused by a coir rope tied at a checkpost in front of the entry gate at a private hospital in Kelambakkam on Friday morning.

A police officer said the accident occurred just after D. Gowrishankar (35), a resident of Padur, delivered newspapers to a private hospital in Kelambakkam.

As he was coming out of the hospital complex on his two-wheeler, the rope slashed his neck and he died on the spot.

Based on a complaint filed by Gowrishankar’s father, Duraibabu, in which the security officials of the hospital were accused of not taking adequate steps to prevent such incidents, the Kelambakkam Police registered a case under Section 304 (punishment for culpable homicide not amounting to murder) of the Indian Penal Code.

Two security personnel of the hospital have been detained, the police officer added.

He was coming out of a hospital complex when a coir rope cut his neck, killing him on the spot
title: Deliveryman dies after coir rope slashes neck

text:
Custom officials seized a huge tranche of Turkish currency notes from a postal parcel at Chennai Airport on Wednesday.

Ranjan Routray, Principal Commissioner of Customs, Chennai Airport and Foreign Post Office, said that during a routine inspection, customs staff found a parcel, which had arrived from China, to be suspicious and on opening it found Turkish currency stacked in plastic covers. The seized currency was valued at Rs. 62 crore in Indian rupee. — Staff Reporter
title: Turkish currency seized at airport

text:
At a time when the city is being lit to celebrate the new year, many streets in the city are dark because of faulty street lights. An estimate says that around 20 per cent of the 55,000-plus lights are under repair.

Across the 100 wards in five zones, barring a few places, many lights are faulty for months together as the contractors engaged for the purpose are not doing the job. Sources say that the contractors do not turn up in time and even if they come, they do not carry necessary spare parts or bulbs to fix faulty lights. From Vadavalli in the west to Ondipudur in the east the story is the same, they add.

Inquiries with those familiar with the issue reveal that the contractors are unable to maintain the street lights because the Coimbatore Corporation had not paid them for long. The amount varies from Rs. 40 lakh to Rs. 45 lakh to nearly Rs. 1 crore for contractors. And it has been pending for six to nine months now.

The sources say that because the Corporation has not paid the contractors, they are unable to buy spare parts as they have exhausted their credit limit with suppliers and were borrowing to pay weekly wages to workers. The contractors’ reliance on workers has increased because they are the ones who switch on and off the street lights as the automated system has been given a go-by.

Contractors say they are overstretched and can do very little other than doing the bare minimum. They expected the Corporation to pay them after its revenue collection increased post demonetisation, but that has not happened. Corporation officials said that the civic body was in the process of clearing the contractors’ dues. But in some cases it had deliberately held back payments following complaints of poor maintenance. Once the contractors improve the quality of service and replace faulty lights, the Corporation will release the remaining money.
title: Poor street light maintenance casts shadow on Corporation

text:
Negamam police have rescued an eight-year-old boy who was allegedly kidnapped by his father’s colleague for ransom and taken to Usilampatti.

According to the police, cotton mill worker Selvan lodged a complaint on Wednesday that his son Manoj, who went to a salon, did not return home. The police registered a case and started investigation. They discovered that Selvan’s colleague at the mill, Balamurugan, was also missing. When the police got in touch with Balamurugan, he told them that he had kidnapped Manoj to avenge Selvan’s insults and that he would handover the boy only if Selvan agreed to pay Rs. 40,000.

The police then asked Selvan to promise to pay Balamurugan and thereafter started tracking the latter’s whereabouts using mobile phone signal. After they learnt that Balamurugan was hiding with Manoj at his sister’s place in Usilampatti, they sent a team to rescue the boy and arrest Balamurugan.

Man attempts suicide

Gopal (40), a differently abled man from Chettipalayam, attempted to immolate himself at the District Employment Office on Friday. The man doused himself with kerosene and tried to set himself afire, when he was stopped by the policemen there on duty.

According to the police, Gopal, who could not get a job despite registering with the office in 1992, picked up an argument with the officials there, walked out and doused himself with kerosene. Those with suicidal tendencies may dial Sneha 24x7 helpline 044-24640050 for help.
title: Police rescue boy kidnapped for ransom

text: Unidentified persons reportedly decamped with 36 sovereign jewellery and Rs. 1.32 lakh from a house in Kulandai Gounder Street in South Ukkadam a few days ago. Yunus, the house owner, who had gone to Palakkad, returned home on Thursday to find the bureau broken open, and the valuables missing. He has lodged a complaint with the Big Bazaar Police, who have registered a case. Yunus runs a lodge on N.H. Road.
title: House burgled

text:
Temporary conservancy workers in the corporation area belonging to the district unit of Ooraga Valarchi Ullatchithurai Uzhiyar Sangam, affiliated to CITU, staged a demonstration on Friday demanding regularisation of service.

Citing a Supreme Court order, they said it was mandatory for the local body to accord permanency to the work of conservancy workers appointed on contract, daily wage and on consolidated pay. Members of women self-help groups recruited for conservancy work must also be integrated into regular service, they emphasised and demanded cash payment of salary, pension and dearness allowance.
title: Temporary conservancy workers demand service permanency

text:
Members of Ganirowtherkulam Tank Retrieval Movement were on a fast for the fifth day on Friday.–PHOTO: M. GOVARTHANM_GOVARTHAN

Members of Ganirowtherkulam Tank Retrieval Movement, who have been on an indefinite fast for the last five days demanding eviction of all encroachments in the tank area, called off their protest on Friday evening after taking part in talks convened by District Collector S. Prabakar.

The fast by nine members, led by coordinator of the Movement Nilavan, demanding demolition of a large unauthorised building in the middle of the tank and other structures elsewhere in the tank area, continued beyond the third day as there was no outcome despite intervention by Erode Revenue Divisional Officer Narmada Devi.

The Collector assured them that notices would be issued to all the buildings that were within 15 m of the tank on a spread of 15 acres determined in a resurvey by Revenue Department. The resurvey was conducted by District Revenue Officer R.Sathish earlier this year. In his order, the DRO issued instructions to the City Corporation for evicting encroachments with the support of the Police Department to avert law and order situation.

When the Movement conducted a protest during September, concrete action was promised by the district administration within two months. The indefinite fast by the Movement was triggered by the perceived inaction by the authorities.

The Movement would wait for 15 days and resume the protest if there was no follow-up action, said Kalaivendan, member of the Movement, who took part in the talks with the Collector.

PUCL State president K.Kurinji and functionaries of political parties including DMK and CPI took part in the talks.
title: Members of Ganirowtherkulam Tank Retrieval Movement end fast

text:
District Collector S.Prabakar said on Friday that a meeting would be convened on January 5 to discuss requirement of mechanised agricultural equipment in the district.

During the grievances redress meeting, the farmers said that the old practice of determining need of agricultural implements with respect to various crops must be revived.

The discussion must factor in the scope for reduction in man days through use of crop-specific mechanised equipment alongside specifying the extent of subsidies, said Mohan, a farmer from Ammapet. The Collector replied that the discussion would be conducted regularly and invited farmers for the first meeting on the issue at the office of Agricultural Engineering wing at 3 p.m. on January 5.

Responding to outbursts by Senniappan and other representatives of farmers’ associations over the purported delay by Sakthi Sugar Mill to settle pending dues for the last three months, the Collector instructed the mill management to make it clear to farmers before the cultivation cycle whether it would be in a position to make prompt settlements for the procured sugarcane. If not, the cane farmers could look at alternatives.

The district administration would do its part to secure the pending dues by issuing notice to the mill under Revenue Recovery Act, the Collector said when many farmers expressed displeasure over what they termed the “unwillingness” of the Sakthi and Bannari Amman sugar mills to pay the State Advisory Price over the last three years. Mr. Prabakar also promised to look into complaints by farmers that the Bannari Mill had “unilaterally” fixed Rs. 2,425 as the procurement price instead of the mandatory Rs. 2,850 per tonne encompassing the Central Government’s Fair and Remunerative Price of Rs. 2,300 per tonne and Rs. 540 as SAP.

The Collector reprimanded PWD officials for not doing enough to remove encroachments on water bodies and catchment areas in and around Sathyamangalam town.
title: Requirement of mechanised implements to be discussed in January

text:
The solar panel installed at a tribal dwelling at Vallankulam on Kodaikanal hills.ma30solar panel

Members of Rotary Club of Kodaikanal have provided solar light to the dwellings in Vallankulam village, a tribal settlement situated 15 km away from Pannaikadu on Kodaikanal hills.

Dindigul Superintendent of Police Saravanan inaugurated the facility on Wednesday in the presence of Revenue Divisional Officer (Kodaikanal) Suresh, Rotary Club of Kodaikanal president Rajkumar and others.

After 50 years

Expressing happiness and thanking the Rotarians for their gesture, the villagers said: “We have been living here for more than 50 years, but only now, we see light in our homes.”

“From now on, we can also get our mobile phones charged easily,” said Ramanan, a 16-year-old boy studying in a higher secondary school at Pannaikadu.

The idea of providing solar lights to the tribal people was given to the Rotarians by Inspector General of Police (South Zone) Murugan and other officers, Mr. Rajkumar said, adding over the last six months the Rotarians worked on the project, which cost them Rs. 3.12 lakh.

This included the cost for five-year maintenance by the company that installed the lights.

Each dwelling can now enjoy power supply for 12 hours (7 p.m. to 7 a.m.).

The tribals, who worked in a nearby coffee estate, earned Rs. 150 to Rs. 200 per day as wages.
title: Rotarians light up tribal hamlet on Kodaikanal hills

text:
The NABARD has envisaged credit potential of Rs. 5,195 crore under priority sector lending for Krishnagiri district during the year 2017-18, as against Rs. 4,480 crore envisaged for the year 2016-17. The Potential Linked Credit Plan (PLP) for the next year registers an increase of 16 per cent fund flow.

The estimates include crop loan Rs. 2,231 crore (43 per cent), term investment for agriculture and allied activities Rs. 817 crore (16 per cent), agriculture infrastructure Rs. 124 crore (2.4 per cent) and ancillary activities (including food and agro processing) Rs. 191 crore (3.6 per cent) forming farm sector total of Rs. 3,363 crore (65 per cent.

The potential for MSME sector has been estimated at Rs. 775 crore and other priority sectors such as education, housing, renewable energy, SHG / JLG lending, export and; social Infrastructure has been estimated at Rs. 1,057 crore.

The PLP was released by C. Kathiravan, District Collector, at the district level review committee meeting held on Friday.

The first copy was received by S. Ravindran, AGM, Reserve Bank of India. Narasimhan, project director, DRDA, Nasreen Salim, AGM, NABARD, Swaminathan, AGM, Indian Bank, Zonal office, were present.

The Collector advised bankers to increase lending for infrastructure in agriculture sector. Bankers were advised to support beneficiaries to get the benefits of various credit linked and other subsidy schemes available from Centre and State Government under Dairy Entrepreneurship Development, National Livestock Mission, solar pumpsets, farm mechanisation, water saving devices, poly house cultivation and infrastructure development.

The PLP also proposed Area Development Scheme for cultivation of vegetables under pandal system in Kelamangalam and Thally blocks. Micro credit is predominant in Krishnagiri district. Of a total target of Rs. 6,000 crore for the State, the district has a target of Rs. 575 crore which is being achieved fully during the last few years.

The activities in individual or group mode like Joint Liability groups (JLGs) may be financed liberally. The district has been allotted a target for formation of 500 JLGs during the current year.
title: Credit plan for Krishnagiri released

text:
Asserting that it was foolish to expect a saviour from elsewhere to come to their rescue, film director Pa. Ranjith urged the oppressed to organise themselves and begin fighting for their rights.

Speaking at a conference organised by Adi Tamilar Katchi (ATK) on the livelihood of those involved in manual scavenging, Mr. Ranjith said, “Let us do some introspection on why we are in this situation first. Then let us begin the fight.”

Claiming that the Indian society, contrary to its claims of rich cultural heritage, was an inhumane society that deified cows but treated fellow humans as untouchables, he said that it was irrational to expect that those at the top in such a society to deliver justice for the oppressed.

“I am told that 26 deaths in manholes were documented in the past one year in Tamil Nadu. But were we able to stop work throughout the State even for a day to protest?” he questioned.

He said that until the oppressed castes united themselves as a political force, the long struggle for their dignity will not see much victory.

“Though we come together in avenues like these, we go with various political parties in elections. We must think whether those elected from reserved constituencies have fought for our issues,” he said.

R. Christodas Gandhi, retired IAS officer, said that the conservancy workers should fight for the removal of their work from Essential Services Maintenance Act since it prevented them from striking work as a protest to demand their rights.

He said that efforts should be made to include re-engineering of sewage systems as part of the much touted Smart Cities Mission as the present sewage systems are shoddily designed requiring manual intervention in their maintenance.

K. Jakkaiyan, State president of ATK, said that the persistence of manual scavenging despite enactment of legislations banning it only showed the indifference of the State in eradicating the practice.

“When the government can overnight enforce demonetisation of majority of the currency in use, why cannot they show the same commitment in stopping manual scavenging” he asked.

‘We must think whether those elected from reserved constituencies have fought for our issues’
title: The oppressed should fight for their rights: Pa. Ranjith

text:
A group of lawyers practising in the Madras High Court Bench here and their friends embarked on a pilgrimage to Sree Dharma Sastha Temple at Sabarimala in Kerala on Wednesday strictly abiding by orders passed by High Court of Kerala last year with respect to preserving the ecosystem at the hillock that forms part of Western Ghats.

The lawyers wore T-shirts that carried messages on the need to go green, avoided plastics in their Irumudi Kattu (twin bags carried by pilgrims with puja materials and edibles required for personal use) and carried teak, sandalwood and mahogany saplings to be handed over to representatives of Pathanamthitta Collector R. Girija.

Beginning their pilgrimage from the Lord Ayyapan Temple at West Masi Street here, the advocates also chanted the slogan ‘Save Green, Save Sabarimala,” along with the regular devotional slogan of “Swamiye... Saranam Ayyappa.”

Leading the group, advocate R. Gandhi said that he had been a regular visitor to Sabarimala for the last 20 years and had stood witness to the forest area, through which the devotees trek to reach the Sastha temple, and River Pampa being polluted due to more than three crore devotees flocking the place between November and January ever year.

“After several experiments, the government officials came up with the Punyam Poonkavanam Project in Sabari hills. It envisaged involvement of the devotees in preserving the environment at Sabarimala and was appreciated by the High Court of Kerala. Therefore, we thought of doing our bit too towards such a good endeavour,” he said.

In its order on August 5 last, a Division Bench of Justices Thottathil B. Radhakrishnan and Sunil Thomas had said: “Their (devotees) participation in such a project is an indefeasible opportunity for them to express their gratitude and reverence to ‘mother nature.’ That is always recognised as a commendable mode of worship apart from contributing positively in terms of the fundamental duties of the citizens enshrined in the Constitution.”

The judges also imposed a ban on use of plastic and other bio-hazardous materials at the temple premises, Pampa and the trekking route between both the places. “This restriction and direction shall be strictly enforced by all officers concerned without fail. Any official dereliction of this direction, from any office of governance in this regard, will be visited with due consequences. This shall be treated as an alert by all concerned,” they observed.

Further, sale of articles unconnected with the pilgrimage was also ordered to be prohibited by the Travancore Devaswom Board at the temple, Pampa, trekking path and Nilackal.

“Since scores of Tamil pilgrims too visit Sabarimala, we thought that we have a moral responsibility towards maintaining the pristine beauty of the hillock. Secondly, as lawyers we should be the first to obey the court orders. Therefore, we decided to carry saplings too along with our Irumudi Kattu,” said Mr. Gandhi.
title: Lawyers carry saplings to Sabarimala

text:
S. Arvind, Director, Aravind Eye Care System, interacting with the participants of ‘Jagriti Yatra’ in Madurai on Wednesday.— Photo: R. AshokR_ASHOK

With 480 participants, Jagriti yatra, which started in Mumbai on December 24, arrived here on Wednesday.

The yatra was aimed at inspiring the youth of the country to become job creators and develop enterprise solutions in their respective districts.

Among the participants, who were from 27 States of India and 46 other countries, women accounted for 40 per cent. The idea of the yatra was to cover the length and breadth of the nation and learn about different sectors such as agriculture, health, energy, water sanitation and education. The participants of the yatra, who arrived here by train, listened to a speech at Arvind Eye Hospital. Interacting with them, Aravind Eye Care System Director S. Arvind and Executive Director R.D. Thulasiraj traced the establishment of the hospital, founded by Dr. G. Venkataswamy.

The model of Aravind Eye Care Hospitals had been applauded and become a subject for numerous case studies across the globe, including in premium business schools such Harvard Business School and the IIMs, they said.

The participants appreciated the hospital team for its yeomen service and went around the hospital to know about various activities carried out there.

Over the last nine years, Jagriti yatra had impacted the enterprise landscape of the country significantly by creating future leaders, who believed in ‘building India through enterprise’.

These leaders, 4,000 of them spread across the country, had begun a journey for transforming ‘Middle India’ by collaborating among themselves, said Ashutosh, executive director, Jagriti, in a press release.

The yatra would end at Mumbai on January 8.

The yatra was aimed at inspiring youth of the country to become job creators
title: “Jagriti yatra inspired youth”

text:
Even as the door-to-door verification to identify priority households (PHH) as part of the implementation of National Food Security Act is in progress here for more than a week, residents in some areas have alleged that the exercise is being carried out in a lackadaisical manner.

Allegations have been made about the personnel deployed for the exercise summoning the residents in the area to come to the ration shop or any common place, instead of visiting every household. “Word spread in my area that officials were waiting near a tea shop in the adjacent street. My wife rushed with the ration card to get the verification done,” said N. Kathiresan, a resident of Duraisamy Nagar.

“We are told that the outcome of this exercise will determine the provisions we will get from ration shops. If they are not visiting every household, aren’t there chances of a deserving family getting missed out,” questioned M. Syed Basha, a resident of Yagappa Nagar.

Though Tamil Nadu had assured that the present quantity of rice received by a family will not be reduced, officials had said that the comprehensive verification was to eliminate bogus beneficiaries and ensure that only the deserving households were identified as PHHs to receive additional benefits.

Acknowledging that possibility of inefficiencies cannot be ruled out, Collector K. Veera Raghava Rao said that adequate number of supervisory staff had been deployed to monitor the whole exercise with random cross-verification.

“We are deploying additional personnel wherever needed since we have adequate manpower pooled from different departments,” he said.
title: Concern over sloppiness in field verification

text:
The Madras High Court Bench here has expressed concern over increasing number of murders for gain being reported from various parts of the State and observed that the reason for a spurt in such crimes was the growing tendency to live a cosy life by accumulating wealth irrespective of the means.

A Division Bench of Justices S. Nagamuthu and M. V. Muralidaran made the observation while dismissing a criminal appeal preferred by a tenant convicted and imposed with the punishment of life imprisonment by a Sessions Court in Karur in August 2013 for murdering his aged landlady in October 2011.

“Nowadays murder for gain is increasing and we cannot shut our eyes in such kind of cases. These days no one is prepared to do any work but wants to lead a happy life by committing crimes which cannot be allowed. Murder for gain is a danger to the society and the person involved in it should be punished severely,” it said.

The appeal had been preferred by Suresh alias Sathiyaraj, now confined in the Tiruchi Central Prison, challenging the life imprisonment imposed on him for the offence of murder as well as 10 years of rigorous imprisonment for house trespass and seven years of rigorous imprisonment for causing hurt at the time of robbery.

According to Mayanoor police in Karur district, the landlady, a widow, was residing along with her maternal grand daughter in her house and rented out a portion of it to the convict. The widow’s grand daughter was working in a textile mill and the incident had occurred when the young girl was not available at home.

The convict had killed the elderly woman and decamped with gold jewels, a mobile phone, four saris, a perfume bottle and Rs. 2,000 in cash. Though there was no eye witness to the crime, the prosecution had established his guilt through circumstantial evidence.

Assailing the trial court judgement, the appellant’s counsel contended that the police had failed to recover a gold chain, the cash as well as the mobile phone which were reportedly robbed from the house of the deceased and therefore, the Bench should set aside the conviction and life imprisonment by according the benefit of doubt.

Mr. Justice Muralidaran said: “Merely because the respondent police had not recovered certain articles, it does not mean that the accused has not committed the offence.”
title: HC for severe punishment for convicts in murders for gain

text:
As many as 18 bonded labourers, including three child labourers, working at a private fish net company near here were rescued on Thursday night.

Based on a complaint received by the Collector, a team of officials from District Child Protection Unit (DCPU) inspected the company at Ananatha Nadar Kudiyiruppu and found 18 persons, including 10 men, five women and three child labourers, working as bonded labourers. The team was led by District Child Protection Officer Kumudha. Enquiries revealed that the firm allegedly tortured them by not allowing them to speak to their family members and not paying salary for the last three months. The rescued were from Odisha and Tamil Nadu.

The girl children and women were handed over to the children’s home at Parakkinkal in Vadiveeswaram area near Nagercoil.

Medical tests were conducted for the girl children. It was found that the rescued persons were affected by skin diseases.

Meanwhile, the company management has accepted to settle the wage arrears immediately and has given an undertaking not to employ child labourers, officials also said.
title: Eighteen bonded labourers, including 3 children, rescued

text:
Residents of Vadaseri and neighbouring areas in the town are facing not only the stench emanating from improper disposal of chicken waste at the dumping yard behind a hospital but also are putting up with pigs that are feeding on the waste.

When the Ministry of Urban Development (MoUD) beginning its Swachh Sarvekshan-2016 from January 4 for rating smart cities, Nagercoil, the district headquarters of Kanniyakumari situated at the southern end of the nation is stinking, R.S. Lal Mohan, Coordinator, Nagercoil Chapter of Indian National Trust for Arts and Cultural Heritage (INTACH) said here on Friday.

The union government’s Swachh Sarvekshan survey is a ranking exercise and encourages towns and cities to actively implement mission initiatives in a time-bound and innovative manner.

MoUD now proposes to conduct its second survey to rank 500 cities with a population of 1 lakh and above under Swachh Bharat Mission-Urban.

The residents living around the dumping yard said the municipal officials were mere spectators of poultry waste being brought from far off places including from neighbouring Kerala and dumped here.

A local resident on condition of anonymity said that trucks carrying chicken waste have been openly dumping it in the yard for more than a year. Steps have not been taken to cover this waste with mud. “The stench is unbearable,” he added.

A doctor from Vasanthan hospital near the dumping yard said that the problem was aggravated by the pigs feeding on the waste. “It is difficult for the people entering our premises, as the pigs have made the dumping yard their home,” he said.

It has become an ordeal for the hospital staff to take patients around the premises.

Appeals from the residents and people’s representatives have only fallen into deaf ears of the authorities.

Nagercoil DMK MLA and former Minister N. Suresh Rajan had also visited the dumping yard recently and appealed to the municipal authorities to prevent dumping of poultry waste and take steps to prevent health hazards.
title: Stench, pig menace haunt Vadaseri

As per the decision of the State government, inner sheets would be pasted in all the 5.85-lakh ration cards from Monday (January 2), said Collector Sajjansingh R. Chavan here on Friday.

Inspecting the printed inner sheets kept ready for distribution to ration shops at the office of the District Supply Officer at the Collectorate, Mr. Chavan said essential food items would be supplied to the ration card holders after pasting inner sheets for one year from January 1, 2017.

The inner sheets would be pasted for a total number of 5.85-lakh ration cards — 1.54-lakh ration cards attached to 215 shops in Agasteeswaram taluk, 1.76 lakh cards attached to 245 shops in Kalkulam taluk, 40,000 cards attached to 59 shops in Thovalai taluk and 1.70 lakh ration cards attached to 245 shops in Vilavancode taluk.

Ration card holders have been asked to get the inner sheets pasted in their cards at the respective ration shops from Monday, the release said.
title: Inner sheets to be pasted in ration cards from Monday

text:
In a surprise visit to the Government Hospital in Karungal town on Friday, Killiyoor Congress MLA Rajesh Kumar appealed to the doctors to show compassion with smile towards patients. “This will heal 50 per cent of the disease,” he told doctors. Mr. Rajesh Kumar enquired with the patients whether they are getting proper treatment. He verified availability of medical equipment and appealed to the doctors and other paramedical staff to turn up at the hospital on time and keep the surroundings of the hospital neat and clean.

Healing touch is related only to doctors and no other professional, he said. Stating that the doctors were like God to the sick, he said if the medical professionals lacked the humane touch, where would the patients go, S. Rajesh Kumar said here on Friday.

A 29-year-old resident of Bhavani in Erode district was picked up by the police after he gave photocopy of Rs. 500 note at a store in Kumarapalayam recently.

Dinesh Kumar of Mayilambadi gave the note to the shop owner who suspected it and handed him over to the police. Inquiries by Kumarapalayam police revealed that Dinesh Kumar obtained a Rs. 2,000 note from his friend. He went to a TASMAC outlet where he was denied exchange for the note. While waiting outside the outlet, an unidentified person offered to exchange the currency and gave him three Rs. 500 notes and five Rs. 100 notes. The police are inquiring whether a gang was involved in circulating the fake currency.
title: Probe on into fake note

text:
NOT SO CLEAN:I. Dhanaraju, Food Safety Officer, and his colleagues raided shops selling packaged drinking water inside the new bus stand in Puducherry on Friday.— PHOTO: S.S. KUMARS_S_KUMAR

Officials from the Department of Food Safety on Friday conducted raids on shops in the new bus stand and seized samples of water sachets, bubble top cans, and packaged drinking water of various brands for analysis and examination.

The team, led by I. Dhanaraju, Food Safety Officer, raided 10 shops in the new bus stand and seized five bubble top water cans, 30 bottles of packaged drinking water, and 300 packets of packaged water for analysis and examination on instructions from the Commissioner of Food Safety and Drug Administration. The raids were conducted by the authorities to check the quality and genuineness of branded water being sold for public consumption in the bus stand.

Samples sent

The samples were collected and despatched to the Food and Drug Testing Lab in Gorimedu.

The laboratory analysis would reveal whether the samples met the prescribed quality standards, Mr. Dhanaraju said.

The Department of Food Safety would continue with the raids to ensure that substandard products did not enter the market, he added.
title: Food safety officials raid shops in bus stand

text:
A NEW THERAPY:K.V. Raman, Director, Department of Health, distributes TB-HIV tablets among patients at the Indira Gandhi Medical College and Research Institute on Friday.— PHOTO: S.S. KUMARS_S_KUMAR

A new daily regimen of Fixed Dose Combinations (FDC) for TB/HIV patients was launched at the Indira Gandhi Medical College, Kathirkamam.

This follows the Central TB Division deciding to adopt FDC with daily regimen wherein all the four ATT drugs are combined and packed in a single tablet to reduce the number of pills intake and to improve the patient compliance.

Major challenge

According to a press note, tuberculosis was the most common opportunistic infection among HIV positives in India with about 25 per cent of deaths in HIV due to TB. With about 5 per cent of diagnosed TB patients found to be HIV positive in India, the situation posed a major public health challenge.

Aiming to control this menace, the Central TB Division and National AIDS Control Organisation have started collaboration since 2001. All the clients attending Integrated Counselling and Testing Centre (ICTC), the Facility Integrated ICTC and the anti-retroviral therapy centres were screened for TB with four symptoms complex and the diagnosis are made swiftly with a newer technology called CBNAAT wherein the results are obtained within the same day. At present, the DOTS treatment (intermittent regimen) was the standard for the diagnosed TBHIV co-infected patients.

The FDC regimen adopted by the Central TB Division was launched at the antiretroviral therapy centre at the IGMCRI by Dr. K.V. Raman, Director (Health and Family Welfare Services) in the presence of Dr. Kalimuthu, Mission Director (PSHM), Dr. S. Govindarajan, State TB Officer, and Dr. S.Jayanthi, Project Director, Pondicherry AIDS Control Society.
title: New regimen of drugs for TB/HIV patients launched

The Puducherry police will be deployed in full strength across the city on Saturday for New Year celebrations.

Director-General of Police S.K. Gautam said the police estimated around 20,000 people to gather here for New Year celebrations.

The hotel owners have been advised to get proper documents from visitors and to conduct the celebrations without creating disturbance. Loudspeakers would not be allowed to be used after 10 p.m.

The entire boulevard had been made a no-parking zone and arrangements had been made for New Year revellers to park their vehicles at Petit Seminaire Higher Secondary School ground, Indira Gandhi Stadium, and Old Distillery.

title: Police will keep a close watch on revelry

text:
Demonetisation has slowed down the trade, says Rajiv Gowda, MP.— PHOTO: S.S. KUMAR— PHOTO: S.S. KUMAR

The Congress on Friday termed the demonetisation of higher denomination currency notes as a “complete failure.”

Congress leader and Member of Parliament Rajeev Gowda told presspersons here that the demonetisation could not achieve any of the stated objectives. The amount of demonetised currency that had come into the banking system suggested that the black money hoarded was only about 5 to 6 per cent and not 20 to 25 per cent as projected.

The bulk of the black money had been invested in foreign land and real estate business. The ban on higher denomination notes had not yielded any results, he said.

“The country and the people are in distress after 50 days of the exercise,” he said.

The ban, besides causing hardship to the public, had resulted in slow down in trade, loss of job, and reduction in farm activity.

The economic growth potential had fallen due to the ban on currency notes, he said. Things had come to a stage where only a trader with a point of sale machine could do business.

Many marginal traders had lost their business because of non-availability of PoS machines. Buyers were now going to shopping malls, he added.

“The Prime Minister has failed to understand the intricacies of the Indian economy. The BJP government has reversed the average growth of 7.6 per cent achieved during 10 years of UPA rule,” he said.

Mr. Rajeev Gowda accused the National Democratic Alliance of undermining the authority of institutions such as the Reserve Bank of India.

Chief Minister V. Narayanasamy said after the Centre announced the withdrawal of Rs. 500 and Rs. 1,000 currency notes, several small scale industrial units had shut shop. He questioned the rational behind introducing new Rs. 2,000 notes after demonetising higher denomination notes.

Minister for Public Works and Puducherry Pradesh Congress Committee president A. Namassivayam, Minister for Revenue M.O.H.F Shahjahan, and Minister for Power R. Kamalakannan were present.
title: Demonetisation has failed in all aspects, says Congress MP

Members of the CITU staged a demonstration in front of the office of the Tamil Nadu Generation and Distribution Corporation here on Friday, urging the Centre to take immediate action to ensure adequate availability of currency notes to all the banks across the country.

They said that salaried classes were the worst-hit and appealed to the Centre to effect cash disbursement of wages and salaries to the employed sector. Lot of human resource was being wasted by standing in queue for hours together daily at banks, they pointed out.

K. Selvaraj, District president, presided over the stir. P. Shanmugam, vice-president, spoke.
