text:
The 1996 batch of TAPMI with students during its visit to the Government CompositeHigh School at Rajeev Nagar in Manipal.

The 1996 batch of T.A. Pai Management Institute (TAPMI) raised Rs. 23 lakh from its batch-mates, over Rs. 10 lakh from corporates, including International Paper (India) Ltd. and CIPLA Ltd., and another Rs. 5 lakh from implementation partners to build three classrooms, an auditorium, toilets and a water tank at the Government Composite High School at Rajeev Nagar here.

A press release issued by the institute here on Thursday said that as part of the reunion celebrations, 58 classmates recently met after 20 years and visited the school where construction is in progress.

The building block is their “give-back” to the town that set them on the path to professional success and also is in memory of two of their batch-mates they lost.

In true TAPMI tradition of being more than just successful professionals, this batch decided to make a difference where it matters the most — education.

They believed that education is paramount in India’s plan for the future. And hence, doing something in the area of education was their way of paving the way for another child’s future. Especially in a school that needed the infrastructure and benefits.

Some of these batch mates flew in from abroad — Canada, the U.S., the U.K., France, Kuwait and UAE, just to be part of this momentous occasion.

The head master of the school, P. Balakrishna, thanked the TAPMI Batch of 1996 for its noble gesture, the release said.
title: A noble gesture from TAPMI alumni

text:
Calling the Western Ghats as the country’s lungs, Union Minister of State for Environment, Forest and Climate Change Anil Madhav Dave said here on Friday that one must be practical in conserving water bodies than merely talking about them academically or otherwise.

Speaking at the valedictory of the 10th biennial lake conference of the Centre for Ecological Sciences, Indian Institute of Science, Bengaluru, at Alva’s College, the Minister asked the participants to introspect if they have done anything worth on the field to conserve water bodies. “Have you worked at least for an hour or two practically on the field to save lakes?” the Minister asked.

Stating that one should be a performer and not non-performer in saving water bodies, he wondered if lake conservation should remain only a topic for discussion in seminars and workshops.

Mr. Dave said that those having a soft corner for saving water bodies should select water bodies of their choice for conservation and physically involve themselves in the conservation efforts.

Stating that genuine efforts are required to save water bodies, the Minister said that practical experience of conserving lakes, ponds, rivers, tanks eventually gave “the pleasure of meeting God”. Stating that the Netravathi is the lifeline of the coastal belt, he said: “I will not permit for any misbehaviour with the river.”

The Minister also asked the people not to waste food and water.

T.V. Ramachandra, professor, Centre for Ecological Sciences, Indian Institute of Science, Bengaluru, called the State government’s Yettinahole Integrated Drinking Water Project as a “senseless project”. It would yield only 0.85 tmcft of water for diversion against the projected quantity of 24 tmcft. Should the government spend Rs. 13,000 crore to fetch 0.85 tmcft of water? he asked.

He suggested that rainwater harvesting, rejuvenation of lakes, ponds and tanks, removing silt from them were the feasible plans to augment water for supplying to the parched districts in the State.

Meanwhile, recommendations of the conference said that swamps, marshes and shoal forests of the Western Ghats being the storage areas for the monsoon rain and being the perennial sources of water need to be mapped and prioritised for conservation and restoration.

Alva’s College and the IISc jointly organised the conference.
title: Be practical in saving water bodies: Dave

text:
The Koraga community, a primitive tribal community of coastal Karnataka, is among the most backward communities in Udupi district.

According to the figures provided by the Integrated Tribal Development Project (ITDP) Department, the population of ST communities in the district is 52,897. Of this, the population of the Marathi Naik community is 39,808, that of theKoraga community 11,133, and that of the Malekudiya tribe 1,956.

The population spread of the Koraga community is 6,200 persons (1,283 families) in Udupi taluk, 3,154 persons (853 families) in Kundapur taluk, and 1,779 (432 families) persons in Karkala taluk.

According to Ganesh Kundapur, a Koraga community leader, the major problems faced by the community are health and education. The life expectation of Koraga community members is short when compared to that in other communities, he said.

Alcoholism among the men is another problem. “The people of my community are naive. A lot of awareness has to be created among them,” he said.

Education a concern

He added that Koraga children lag behind when it comes to education. “The government should appoint a teacher for every Koraga colony in such villages. This teacher should do follow-up with the school-going children,” Mr. Kundapur said.

According to him, the parents are often too attached to their children, and vice-versa. Hence, they hesitate to send their children to schools that are far away.

Yet another demand of the community is that the government provide title deeds to community members who have built houses on revenue or forest lands. “The members of the community cannot be expected to run to government offices to get title deeds. They are too naive to understand the rules and regulations. Government officials should deliver [the deeds] to their doorstep,” he said.

273 unemployed

According to the ITDP Department, there are 197 Koraga community members in the district with government jobs. As many as 276 are self-employed, 366 work in the private sector, 327 are involved in agricultural activities, and 1,961 hold ‘other jobs’. As many as 273 persons are unemployed.

The number of Koraga community members with Aadhaar cards is 8,260; as many as 6,754 have bank accounts, and 2,078 have ration cards.
title: ‘Koraga community lags in health and education’

text:
THE HAMLET:(Clockwise from above) The house of Marli Koraga, where Social Welfare Minister H. Anjaneya will stay during his grama vastavya at Mururu hamlet in Udupi district;completion of a bridge built across a stream in the hamlet is among the major demands of the residents; ahead of the Minister’s visit, the Integrated Tribal Development Project Department constructed a western toilet outside Ms. Koraga’s house.— PHOTOS: SPECIAL ARRANGEMENT

The authorities are leaving no stone unturned to make the grama vastavya programme of Social Welfare Minister H. Anjaneya to be held here on Saturday, a success.

The Kalthodu Gram Panchayat, under whose jurisdiction Mururu village comes, has also fully involved itself in this work.

As per the tentative programme, Mr. Anjaneya will arrive at Mururu at 11.30 a.m. And, the Minister will distribute various facilities to the members of the Koraga community.

“We expect beneficiaries of the Koraga community from Kundapur taluk if not the entire district to attend the function,” said Harish Gaonkar, in-charge Project Director of Integrated Tribal Development Project (ITDP) Department.

A shamiana has already been put up at Mururu for this function. Lunch will be provided to all those who attend this function.

After the function, the members of the Koraga community would present a cultural function for about half-an-hour. This would be followed by lunch.

After lunch, Mr. Anjaneya would participate in an interaction programme at the same venue at around 2.30 p.m. and this is expected to go on till 6 p.m. A mobile toilet too has been set up at the venue.

After that Mr. Anjaneya will take up his grama vastavya at Marli Koraga’s house in the hamlet. Ms. Koraga and her four daughters said that they had planned to cook chappatis, boiled rice, belesaaru, a suppina palya and a vegetable palya for the Minister for dinner.

“Since its New Year’s Eve, we will also prepare Kadalebele Sabbakki Payasa. We will use vegetables from our own garden for cooking,” Gulabi Koraga, Ms. Marli’s daughter, said.

After staying at Ms. Marli’s house overnight, Mr. Anjaneya would leave the hamlet at around 8 a.m. on Sunday. There is excitement among the people of the hamlet that Mr. Anjaneya is staying there.

The Minister will distribute various facilities to the members of the Koraga community during his village stay
title: All set for Anjaneya’s grama vastavya in Mururu

text:
One grouse of the people of Mururu hamlet, which comes under the Kalthodu Gram Panchayat, is the inadequate bus connectivity from the hamlet to the taluk headquarters.

Residents have to travel 5 km to the nearby Bolamballi hamlet to catch a bus to go to the taluk headquarters of Kundapur. And the bus comes only thrice a day.

Annappa Shetty, president of the Kalthodu Gram Panchayat, says the bus comes to Bolamballi at 6.30 a.m. and leaves at 8 a.m. It then comes at 10 a.m. and leaves at 10.15 a.m., and on the third trip it arrives and departs at 4.45 p.m. and 5.15 p.m., respectively.

He said these timings are not convenient at all to locals. “It is of no help to the people of Mururu. They cannot even bring their ration supplies because of wide gap in timings. But mostly, people just walk 10 km from Kalthodu, where the ration shop is located. Because even to catch a bus, they have to walk 5 km,” Mr. Shetty said.
title: Connectivity is an issue

text:
The bulk of the business in tourism and the hospitality sector is fuelled by domestic tourists who are flocking to popular destinations like the Lalitha Mahal Palace.— File PhotosM_A_SRIRAM;M_A_SRIRAM - M_A_SRIRAM

The hospitality sector in Mysuru is witnessing a surge in business in the current holiday season from Christmas to New Year with occupancy rates in excess of 80 per cent in most properties.

The demonetisation exercise and the currency crunch has not dampened the new fizz in the sector given the boom in number of tourists visiting the city since December 23 and most hotels are reporting encouraging business with confirmed bookings till January 2, 2017.

The bulk of the business in tourism and the hospitality sector is fuelled by domestic tourists, who are being enticed by hotels with special programmes for the New Year celebrations and the holiday season which commenced from Christmas continues.

“Most of our members are reporting almost cent per cent occupancy from Christmas to New Year and this augurs well for the tourism and the hospitality sector,” said C. Narayangowda, president, Hotel Owners’ Association.

He told The Hindu that December was particularly good for the hospitality sector as there were a slew of events like the surgeons’ conference that saw more than 4,000 doctors from all over India converging at Mysuru besides other events.

At Sandesh The Prince, a hotel catering to tourists in the luxury segment, occupancy rates were in excess of 80 per cent.

A spokesperson for the hotel said the impact of demonetisation was felt for the first few weeks after the initial announcement on November 8 after which there was normalcy.

But December has witnessed a surge in tourists and made up for the short lull, the spokesperson said.

The fact that January 1, 2017 is a Sunday has given a boost to the weekend tourists visiting the city for the extended New Year celebrations as they will not be in a hurry to rush back to work the next day.

At Guru Residency catering to tourists in the middle and upper middle income group, there is no accommodation till January 2 while the Country Inn and Suite by Carlson, a high-end property on the outskirts of the city has similar trends.

That the investors see a great potential in Mysuru’s tourism sector also stems from investments for four new hotels approved last week and this will add to the nearly 180 existing properties catering to tourists ranging from budget segment to those in the luxury segment.

Investment to the tune of Rs.14.46 crore is expected which will augment the accomodation facility in the city.
title: Hospitality sector witnesses surge

text:
The death of one person in an operation to drive a tigress and her cubs back into the forests near Antharasanthe range of the Nagarahole National Park on Thursday, underscores the need for crowd management during conflict situations.

Murthy (25) was keenly watching the operation just like many others who had congregated at the spot. He, unfortunately, came in the line of fire when forest guards tried to shoot the tigress.

Though conservationists working in the field say that the incident is a pointer to inept training and practice of the staff in using firearms, they also point out that in Indian situations, it’s more difficult to manage crowds than animals. Sources in the Forest Department told The Hindu that despite repeated appeals, the crowd refused to disperse and the authorities were left with no option but to persist with the operation.

The National Tiger Conservation Authority (NTCA) guidelines on animal rescue operation is very clear on crowd management being critical for success in such missions.

Mob presence

The rescue team is often hindered by the presence of a mob and are unable to take a decision as they tend to dictate or force an option and the guards give in to pressure. Hence, it is imperative that the area is cordoned off, say wildlife activists. Authorities had a tough time in H.D. Kote some months ago when a herd of elephants strayed from their habitat and were unable to trace their way back due to the unruly mob which pelted stones at the herd.

The incident also reinforces the escalating man-animal conflict in the region in the absence of protected buffer zones to absorb the increase in animal population.

Nagarahole is home to nearly 80 to 100 tigers and experts aver that the ecosystem may have reached its ecological carrying capacity. There were a slew of tiger deaths in both Nagarahole and Bandipur early this year due to territorial infighting, highlighting the increase in carnivore population, some of which may have been ejected to the forest fringes. The region is also known for human-elephant conflict due to habitat degradation and disturbance, though the pachyderm population is stable without a significant increase in their numbers.

No trace of tigers

An operation to drive a tiger and its two cubs back into the jungles at Malali village in H.D. Kote concluded on Friday with no trace of the animals. The three animals had found a sanctuary in a banana plantation. On Thursday, efforts to drive them back into the forests at the Antharsanthe range of the park had led to a commotion and the death of a farmer, Murthy.

Conservator of Forests S. Manikandan said two elephants, Abhimanyu and Krishna, were deployed for combing the area to ensure that the tigers were not present at the plantation.
title: Crowd management critical for man-animal conflict situations

text:
The district administration has instructed all the banks to readjust the loans of the farmers and convert short-term loans into long term loans.

It also asked the banks not to insist on farmers paying either the interest or the principle amount for time being as farmers were hard hit by consecutive drought and failure of rains.

Shivashankar, Chief Executive Officer of the zilla panchayat, told The Hindu that the Deputy Commissioner held the district consultative committee meeting recently and .

The CEO further said that drinking water units were being installed in over 263 villages across the district. Works in over 166 places were near completion, he said and he noted that most of the drinking water units would be functional from January last week.

Drinking water units were installed in such places which were facing drinking water scarcity for several years now, he said.

He said that works to set up the water units would have been completed by this time but the agency, which was assigned the job, could not complete even a single unit. Hence the ZP blacklisted the agency and assigned the job of installing the pure drinking water units to KRDL.

Mr. Shivashankar said that this is the first time that people were facing a drought for a long time and he noted that hitherto drought situation was there for a maximum period of 90 days.

But this year drought would last for more than 120 days, he said adding that the district administration was making all efforts to tackle long duration drought this year.
title: Banks instructed to readjust farmers’ loans

text:
There was no significant surge in the number of people visiting banks on Thursday, the last date to exchange old currency notes, following the demonetisation of Rs. 500 and Rs. 1,000 in Mysuru.

District Lead Bank Manager K.M. Shivalingaiah told The Hindu that there was no report from anywhere in the district of a last-minute scramble to surrender the old notes by the public.

“Banks in Mysuru region had stopped receiving high-value currency notes in bulk for exchange almost 15 days ago,” he added.

While authorities were expecting a last-minute rush to beat the deadline, it never materialised and it was business as usual in most branches, according to the Lead Bank manager.

He said following the release of the new Rs. 500 notes, there is a semblance of normalcy in market with no hassles for the change as the banks continue to meet the demand for Rs.100 denomination notes.

There are 733 ATMs in the district and each of them are replenished with Rs.10 lakh on a regular basis and hence there are no lengthy queues as well. “The cash flow from the Reserve Bank of India has been steady based on the availability and has increased compared to what the situation was a few weeks ago,” said Mr. Shivalingaiah.

But a senior official pointed out that the cash infusion at ATMs were lasting more than two days as there are restrictions on withdrawal.

“The situation cannot be deemed to be fully normal until the cash withdrawal norms are also withdrawn,” he added.

Thursday was the last day to exchange old Rs. 500 and Rs. 1,000 notes after demonetisation drive
title: No major rush to exchange notes

text:
Karnataka Dalit Sangharsh Samiti’s N. Murthy has urged the State government to raise reservation for backward communities from 50 per cent to 70 per cent.

He was addressing a press conference here on Thursday.

At present, out of the 50 per cent reservation, 18 per cent reservation went away for the Scheduled Castes and the rest for Other Backward Classes. If another 20 per cent reservation was added to the 50 per cent reservation, the deprived communities would get benefits effectively, he said and added that Chief Minister Siddaramaiah should take immediate action in the matter.

Mr. Murthy also said that benefits under the Special Component Plan (SCP) and Tribal Sub Plan (TSP) schemes were not reaching the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes owing to lack of efforts from officials in spending the earmarked grants.

Therefore, the government has to take action and ensure the strict implementation of the schemes by utilising the grants properly, he added.

Land right records for cultivators of bagair hukum land should be distributed immediately as 12.50 lakh acres of land is being cultivated by the landless who have been deprived of the rights for many years, Mr. Murthy said.

G. Lingappa, Basavaraj Sasalamari Ashok Nanjaladinni and others were present.
title: ‘Raise quota from 50 p.c. to 70 p.c. for backward communities’

Members of the Akhila Karnataka Bhovi Vaddara Yuva Vedike submitting a memorandum in Raichur on Friday— PHOTO: SANTOSH SAGAR

The women’s wing of the Akhila Karnataka Bhovi Vaddara Yuva Vedike has demanded that the State government not take action to implement the A.J. Sadashiva Commission recommendations.

While submitting a memorandum addressed to Chief Minister Siddaramaiah to the Deputy Commissioner of Raichur on Friday, members of the vedike said that the recommendations of the commission were unscientific and against the Bhovi and other communities like Bhovi.

They also demanded that the government take action against those who allegedly threatened legislators Shivaraj Tangadagi and Manappa Vajjal for raising their voice against the commission’s recommendations.

The Bhovi, the Koracha, the Korama, the Banjara and other communities would launch State-wide agitations shortly demanding that the recommendations be dropped, they added.

Eramma, Tayamma, Nagamma, Devamma and others were present.
title: Do not implement Sadashiva panel recommendations, govt. told

text:
The meeting of the District Development, Coordination and Monitoring Committee on Friday decided to press the State government to take necessary measures for extraction of sand in the blocks that fall in places identified as ecologically sensitive zones in the Kasturirangan report on conservation of Western Ghats.

Member of the committee Gurumurthy expressed displeasure in the meeting that construction activities and infrastructure upgradation works in the district have come to a standstill owing to delay in commencement of the process of lifting and distributing sand.

The government should take necessary measures to meet the requirement for sand here from the blocks in Davangere district, he said.

The officials of the Department of Mines and Geology told the meeting that of the 98 blocks on river banks in the district where sand extraction could be undertaken, the Department of Forest and Environment had sanctioned permission to lift sand in 45 blocks.

The permission to lift sand in the remaining blocks was denied as they fall under the ecologically sensitive zones, the officials said.

B.S. Yeddyurappa, MP for Shivamogga, expressed displeasure against denial of permission for lifting sand citing the Kasturirangan panel report. The recommendations of the panel have not yet been enforced in Karnataka and it was unfair to deny permission for mining sand citing it. The Department of Forest and Environment should reconsider its decision on denial of permission for mining sand in 53 block citing the Kasturirangan panel recommendations, he said.

The officials of the Public Works Department said that mining of sand in five blocks — Gabali, Buklapura, Holehatti, Holalur, and Hadonahalli — will commence by January 7.
title: Panel unhappy with restrictions

text:
An incident of a woman member of a gram panchayat being subjected to forceful confinement with her four-year-old child at a brick manufacturing unit in Honnavile village near here has been reported on Friday.

Gangamma, vice-president of Bilavaala GP in Chikkamagaluru district, and other members of her family were working as labourers at the brick manufacturing unit being run by Kariyappa.

Gangamma’s brother Siddaraju had allegedly received an advance from Kariyappa to bring labourers for the unit.

Kariyappa allegedly subjected Gangamma and her husband to forceful confinement for four days and had made them to work in his unit towards the money her brother owed him.

The police raided the unit on Friday and released Gangamma, her husband and her child. The police have booked a case under Section 342 (punishment for wrongful confinement) of the Indian Penal Code against Kariyappa.
title: Gram panchayat vice-president rescued

text:
The meeting of the Irrigation Consultative Committee (ICC) of the Bhadra Command Area Development Authority (CADA) held here on Friday has decided to release water from the Bhadra reservoir for a period of 40 days along the right bank canal and for 45 days along the left bank canal for the standing crops during the forthcoming summer season.

At present, Bhadra reservoir has 29 tmcft water of which 14 tmcft is dead storage and 7 tmcft water should be stored to meet the drinking water requirements of the human habitats in the command area during summer. The meeting has decided to release the remaining 8 tmcft for irrigation purpose on on-and-off system for the standing crops during summer of 2017.

According to the schedule worked out in the meeting, water will be released along the right bank canal from January 7 to 18, from February 18 to 27, from March 29 to April 7, and from May 4 to 11. Water would be released along the left bank canal from January 5 to 19, February 19 to March 5, and from March 31 to April 14. Speaking on the occasion, H.S. Sundaresh, Chairman of Bhadra CADA, said that in the wake of acute shortage of water in the reservoir owing to a sluggish monsoon, farmers have been directed not to take up cultivation of fresh crops during summer. The water will be released only for standing crops, including arecanut, coconut, banana, and sugarcane, he said. Vadnal Rajanna, MLA for Channagiri, working president of the Karnataka Rajya Raitha Sangha K.T. Gangadhar, and its general secretary H.R. Basavarajappa were present.
title: Bhadra water to be released for standing crops

The former MLA, Araga Jnanendra, had recently alleged that the silence maintained by Mr. Ratnakar over the sub-standard work executed in the modernisation of the Tunga canal had led to the suspicion that he might have received a kickback from the civil engineering firm that had bagged the contract for the work.

After offering ‘satya kanike’ at the temple ‘hundi’ and performing rituals related to submission of truth before the deity, Mr. Ratnakar made a declaration that he had not received any favours from the firm that had bagged the contract.

Mr. Ratnakar also challenged Mr. Jnanendra to swear before the deity over the issue.

A student of Kasturba Medical College was killed and another injured when the motorcycle on which they were travelling hit a road median near Hotel Sharada International here in the wee hours of Friday.

According to the police, Pawan Kumar Raghavan and Sakshi Maheshwari, both fifth-semester MBBS students at the college, were riding from Udupi to Manipal at the time of the accident.

When the motorcycle hit the median, both the students were thrown off it. They were taken to the district government hospital, where doctors pronounced Pawan dead. Sakshi, who was severely injured, was shifted to Kasturba Hospital.

Found after hours

According to sources, the accident is said to have taken place around 2.30 a.m. But the students were found only around 7 a.m. A case has been registered.

The two MBBS students of Kasturba Medical College

were riding from Udupi to Manipal
title: One killed, another hurt as bike hits median

Yeddyurappa, as the next Chief Minister and to realise the dream of a strong and prosperous India of Prime Minister Narendra Modi.

Rafeeq Ahmed, convenor of Community Relation Committee of Kalaburagi division, has said that no special programmes were implemented to eradicate educational and economical backwardness among Muslims even after 69 years of Independence.

Therefore, Muslims should get education themselves to find solutions to their problems, he added.

Addressing a joint press conference, along with Imtiyazuddin Siddiqui, president of the committee, here on Thursday, Mr. Ahmed stressed that the Muslim community should get education compulsorily to find permanent solutions to backwardness and urge the governments to take up special programmes for the welfare of their community.

Admitting that Muslims are not open with the other communities in society, he appealed to the community people to come forward to utilise the opportunities extended and develop good relationship with other communities to show solidarity with the nation.

Remembering the contributions by Muslims to the country’s development, Mr. Ahmed said that due to some differences, all Jamat-e-Islami Hind organisations had remained at a distance from one another.

But, they now are coming together to strengthen the community by providing financial and educational stability.

To create awareness among the community over these issues, a conference would be held in Yadgir on January 1.

Several religious heads such as Hazarat Razakhan from Delhi, Moulana Maqsud Imran Saheb from Bengaluru, Muzeeb-ur-Rahman from Bidar and others would address the conference.

Around 4,000 people are expected to participate in it, he said.

Nazeem Ahmed, Hussain Basha, Mansoor Ahmed, Gulam Jilani and Anwer Patel and others were present.

Children in the nine months to 15 years age group of are eligible for vaccination, she said and suggested that officials to make all preparations for a smooth and successful completion of the drive.

Officials of the District Health and Family Welfare and Education departments and a representative of the World Health Organisation Anil Talikoti were present.

text:
Gross underutilisation of the generation capacity at the NTPC thermal power plant at Kayamkulam continues despite the State facing power shortage. The KSEB places orders for electricity generation here mostly as a stopgap arrangement when the State fails to get the required quantity from alternative sources.

The board has not sought power from the plant though there has been a dent in the electricity available for distribution in the State this week, NTPC sources told The Hindu .

Additional quantity of naphtha had been stored at the plant in view of the prevailing power scenario. The orders for power generation are generally issued to the NTPC at short notice. The State has an installed generation capacity of less than 2,900 MW against a demand of 4,000 MW. With opposition to the Athirapilly hydroelectric project from various quarters, the expansion of the Kayamkulam project could be a viable option before the government.

Natural gas

The LDF government had promised to promote natural gas and has taken the initiative to complete the GAIL pipeline project to carry gas from Kochi to Bengaluru and Mangaluru, but the Kochi-Kayamkulam project has failed to get due attention of the government.

The NTPC plan to expand capacity at the Kayamkulam plant is facing uncertainty as the questions over LNG transport remain unresolved.

LNG pricing is an important issue in the natural gas-based power production scheme envisaged at the plant and efforts are required from the State government as well as Petronet LNG Limited, which has set up the LNG terminal at Kochi, to sort out the issue.

Though higher cost of production is the reason cited by the board for the poor intake of power from the Kayamkulam plant, utilising less than 10 per cent of the installed capacity, NTPC sources have disputed the argument. While the power generated at the plant is supplied at Rs. 6.30 per unit, the NTPC has been providing power to the State at a low rate of Rs. 1.20 to Rs. 1.80 per unit from its plant at Talcher in Odisha.

The higher cost of generation at Kayamkulam arises out of the use of naphtha, which is costly. The NTPC has overhauled its machinery to make use of LNG, but plans to transport natural gas from the LNG terminal at Puthuvype in Kochi to the plant at Kayamkulam have remained a non-starter.
title: NTPC plant stays underutilised

text:
Loading and unloading workers at the FCI depot here have been transferred en masse to Kollam.

The action was taken by the FCI authorities after more than 40 workers, belonging to FCI Workers Union, reportedly resorted to a go-slow demanding higher stacking charges.

The delay in the loading and unloading work had affected the food grains supply through ration retail outlets, according to Civil Supplies officials.

The FCI authorities carried out the work with the help of new workers on Thursday and Friday, under police protection.

Transfer order

The representatives of the FCI Workers Union said the transfer order had not been received by them and they would not accept it.

They refuted the charge that go-slow had been resorted to and alleged that the transfer move was aimed at inducting workers belonging to trade unions affiliated to Left parties.
title: Row over transfer of FCI workers

The Minister examined records and found out several irregularities. He also conducted inspection at the Supply Office, Alappuzha.
