title: Surprise checks at ration shops

text:
Declining price, low production, and shortage of currency notes post-demonetisation during the harvest season have put coffee farmers in a spot of bother.

The spot price for raw robusta coffee in Wayanad market on Monday was Rs.75 a kg as against Rs. 81.50 a few weeks ago. The price of coffee beans too declined to Rs.130 a kg from Rs.142 a kg during the period.

The fall in prices was on a par with international markets but it did not fully reflect in the Indian market owing to the fall in rupee, trade sources said.

International prices have come down because of arrival from other origins, especially Vietnam. Further, the selling pressure during the harvest season also tends to bring down the price, the sources added.

According to the data with the Coffee Board, the production of robusta coffee in the State declined to 8.58 per cent this season, starting October, owing to the poor monsoon.

The total coffee production in the State was 63,290 tonnes, including 52,500 tonnes from Wayanad, during the 2016-17 coffee season as against 69,230 tonnes, including 57,850 tonnes from Wayanad, in 2015-16. Prasanth Rajesh, president of the Wayanad Coffee Growers’ Association, said coffee production dipped more than 15 per cent in the district this season owing to the dearth of backup showers during monsoon.

“The drought-like situation in the district this year has adversely affected growth of coffee plants and it will reflect in the production of beans in the coming years,” Mr. Rajesh said.

The situation in the other coffee-growing regions in the State, including Nelliampathy in Palakkad and parts of Idukki, is not different, the sources said. The farm community fears that the production may dip further next year owing to the dearth of new shoots on coffee plants following the truant weather. The dearth of lower denomination currency notes, after the demonetisation drive, during the harvest season has also put the agrarian community in a tight spot.
title: Coffee farmers face distressing times

text:
Burglars broke into the Mathoth Sri Mahavishnu teimple at Kanhangad south and decamped with 12 grams of gold ornaments and six cash boxes early Friday.

The theft was first noticed by temple priest Vishnudas when he reached the shrine early morning, the police said. The burglars also took away six cash boxes installed in the vicinity of other deities in the temple compound located close to the State Highway. The police said the burglary may have taken place after 2.30 a.m. after the night patrol team inspected the locality and signed the register kept there.

The cash boxes lifted from the shrine were found broken open and abandoned in the eastern side of the shrine. A team of police personnel led by Hosdurg Circle Inspector C.K. Sunil Kumar inspected the shrine.
title: Temple at Kanhangad burgled

text:
As 2016 draws to a close, Kasaragod district does not have much to cheer with its development aspirations remaining unfulfilled.

The majority of projects have been left halfway or untouched, apparently owing to lack of ‘political’ pressure or ‘committed’ employees to provide momentum to the ongoing projects.

Some of these projects are the rail overbridge (ROB) at Pallikkare, near Neeleshwaram, the proposed airstrip at Periye, revival of the Uduma Spinning Mill, which could not produce a single yarn since it was inaugurated in 2011, and tapping domestic tourism potential by developing the Bekal beach.

The fate of the Kanhangad-Kaniyooru rail link that provides easy access to Bengaluru from north Kerala remains uncertain, with the project facing several hurdles.

Work on the government medical college at Badiadukka, near here, that began in November 2013, is moving at a snail’s pace.

ROB work by March

Work on the long-awaited rail overbridge (ROB) at Pallikkare is now set to begin only in Maréch on account of fresh land alignment in view of the road widening and revised land survey, P. Karunakaran, MP, told The Hindu on Friday.

The former Chief Minister, Oommen Chandy, while inaugurating the ROB near Cheruvathur railway station in 2013 had given an assurance that he would accord top priority to the Pallikkare ROB.

According to K. Kunhiraman, MLA, the State-run Bekal Resorts Development Corporation (BRDC), which has been entrusted with developing tourism infrastructure around the Bekal Fort, was “doing nothing” to boost tourism potential.

Work on the airstrip at Periye is yet to take off in spite of the fact that 56 of the 80-acre land for the scheme had already been acquired, Mr. Kunhiraman said adding that he would take the initiative to begin the work by March next.

The new LDF government had resolved to revive the defunct Uduma Spinning mill with the then Industries Minister, K.P. Jayarajan, announcing that the Rs. 22 crore worth ”rusted” mill would be made operational by December by spending another Rs. 8 crore for turning it operational.

However, political developments, culminating in the resignation of Mr. Jayarajan had affected the revival work and the mill would be made operational by March, he said.

Solar power

Efforts to generate 200 MW solar power from three areas in the district is the visible sign of development initiatives. The Ambalathara plant has already begun to distribute 50 MW solar power to the KSEB grid and hope for an additional 50 MW by next month.

The majority of projects have been left halfway owing to lack of ‘political’ pressure.
title: Kasaragod still lacking in development

text:
The district administration has drawn up a five-point operative charter for the New Year to meet challenging tasks ahead.

The charter includes finding a holistic solution to the city’s traffic woes, technology-based intervention in governance, focus on key development projects, enhancing green cover and launching a comprehensive child-safe Ernakulam campaign.

Interacting with The Hindu at the camp office on Friday, District Collector K. Mohammed Y. Safirulla said the district administration was gearing up for technology infusion to bring relief to commoners.

Technology infusion

“The portal for facilitating online transfer of registry and payment of land tax, to root out one of the lucrative avenues of corruption, will be launched in a couple of months. The complete shift to online transfer of registry will be done initially in 73 out of 126 villages in the district where resurvey has been completed,” he said.

Another technology initiative, e-office, will be rolled out in a phased manned over the next three months. It will initially cover the Collectorate followed by revenue divisional offices and taluk offices. The tender process and hardware installation are over and the project is ready for execution. “It will help fix accountability in addressing people’s petitions and is likely to reduce the delay in action by 50 to 60 per cent,” Mr. Safirulla said.

Traffic problems

The district administration is looking at finding a holistic solution to the city’s traffic problems, ranging from absence of good roads and rash driving to pedestrian hardships alongside a campaign for responsible driving.

Child-safe Ernakulam

The district administration is set to launch a holistic programme for child-safe Ernakulam, whereby children aged below 14 years will be taken care of by identifying disabilities, including learning disabilities, at an early stage.

“Intervention through 150-odd orphanages and child care institutions in the district will also be made to ensure that inmates there are not deprived of a normal childhood,” Mr. Safirulla said.

Development projects

Priority will be given to key development projects like Kochi Metro, Smart City and Haritha Keralam while land acquisition will be another focus area of the Ernakulam administration.

Green cover

The district administration proposes to leverage the Haritha Keralam project to overcome the challenge posed by nearly 35 per cent rain deficiency in Ernakulam this year.

“This is an opportune time to increase green cover, rejuvenate water bodies, bring more fallow land under cultivation and launch sanitation campaigns. The projects launched by the previous Collector like Ente Kulam Ernakulam and Padikkaam Padippikkam will continue and will be funded through corporate social responsibility initiatives,” Mr. Safirulla said.
title: 5-point charter for district to meet challenges in 2017

text:
A state-of-the-art District Emergency Centre will be set up at the district collectorate in the next three months in order to add teeth to the disaster management capabilities of the district.

The new centre will be an upgrade on the existing one with a round-the-clock control room that ensures the coordination of representatives of all departments related to fighting disasters. It will function right next to the District Collector’s chamber facilitating his continuous monitoring. It will have a seamless networking with the State and Central emergency centres.

“A voluntary team will also be set up to scale up the state of preparedness and help fight emergencies,” District Collector K. Mohammed Y. Safirulla said.

Cleaning canals

Considering that cleanliness of canals is necessary to avoid waterlogging, the district administration is working on an integrated system to ensure smooth coordination among six different agencies - major irrigation, minor irrigation, Periyar Valley and Muvattupuzha Valley irrigation projects, Idamalayar Major Irrigation Project and the corporation - that have the control of canals in the district.

Discussions had also been initiated with the departments concerned on cleaning the canals, Mr. Safirulla said.

Besides, the Fire and Safety Department is set to undertake a fire safety awareness campaign followed by an enforcement drive that focusses on the high-rise buildings in the city.
title: District Emergency Centre to be modernised soon

text:
The Greater Cochin Development Authority (GCDA) on Friday issued a show-cause notice to an assistant engineer who was the custodian of the Chairman’s house from where valuables worth lakhs went missing.

GCDA secretary M.C. Joseph issued the notice with an ultimatum to give a ‘convincing and satisfying reply’ by the evening of January 3.

GCDA chairman C.N. Mohanan said if the reply was not forthcoming or found unsatisfactory, the agency would file a case for theft.

The GCDA came to know about the missing household items, from furniture and air conditioners to even gas cylinders, after officials took the newly appointed chairman, C.N. Mohanan, to show him the place around soon after he assumed charge earlier this week.

The new chairman found to his utter shock that the house was far from inhabitable with the missing furniture and even cots.

Mr. Mohanan said Vigilance and Anti-Corruption Bureau (VACB) officials visited the GCDA office at Kadavanthra on Thursday to collect information based on media reports.

The VACB is likely to register a suo motu case on the issue.

Meanwhile, a few of the missing items reappeared mysteriously after the issue kicked up a storm. However, materials worth lakhs are still missing.

If the reply is unsatisfactory, GCDA will file a case for theft, says Chairman C.N. Mohanan
title: Missing valuables: GCDA issues show-cause notice to official

text:
The budget of the Mahatma Gandhi University gives major emphasis on launching online services, with a view to becoming student-friendly and elevating the university to the international level.

It will also develop software to enable distribution of question papers and evaluation of answer sheets online.

The deficit budget, which envisages an expenditure of Rs.311.97 crore and an income of Rs.238.74 crore, was presented by Syndicate Finance Committee convenor K. Sherafudeen.

The university will soon start a round-the-clock computerised student facilitation centre to dole out services. Accident insurance for students has been raised to Rs.2 lakh from the present Rs.1 lakh.

In a major transformation, question papers for university examinations will be distributed online and measures will be taken, with the support of the staff, to conduct evaluation of answer sheets online. Development of software and other technical requirements to implement this will be done within the university. The move will be introduced at the postgraduate level.

Among the services, certificates of eligibility, equivalence, and official transcript will be made available online. All procedures pertaining to PhD will be computerised. The university will also digitise exam records. A statutory department will be set up for nanotechnology and nanoscience.
title: Emphasis on online services in Mahatma Gandhi varsity budget

text:
Dancers Hema and Sila step on colours kept in trays while performing on huge canvasses to celebrate free expression in the city on Friday.for th

A group of artists and writers, united under the newly-formed Kalakar Koottayma to resist attempts at muzzling freedom of expression, protested the recent infringements on creative expression by taking out a demonstration from the High Court Junction to Durbar Hall on Friday.

Five people wearing flowing red robes, representing the fine arts, music and literature, pushed a small cart up to the Durbar Hall premises – the fragrant smoke emanating from a bowl on the cart wafting their way. A red mark lined their path all the way, critical of impositions such as the apex court’s ruling on playing the national anthem in cinema halls.

At Durbar Hall, an art installation done by Selvaraj using wheat corns resembled the map of India, but the doves that flocked around flapped their wings in fright and flew away every time a vehicle passed by, making guttural noises. “It’s a place where we can all live peacefully, but sudden disturbances disrupt creativity and ruin our peace of mind,” said artist Ochuman aka Hochimin.

Sculptor T.K. Anil made an installation using planks covered in sack adorned, from top to bottom, with 171 hemispherical coconut shells looking like breasts, with traditional cloth cribs around the structure carrying toy babies.

An earthen cookware atop the structure remained on the boil. “I just wanted to portray how these religious and communal forces tried to appropriate the identity of women,” said Mr. Anil.

Several artists joined to paint huge blocks of ice, while dancers Hema and Sila stepped on colours kept in trays before dancing on huge canvasses to celebrate free expression.

“They performed both classical and contemporary dance, their feet painting curious forms on the canvass,” said Mr. Ochuman.
title: When artists spoke up for freedom of expression

text:
Films, which were released prior to the present dispute between producers and distributors associations on one side and the exhibitors federation on the other, continued to be screened in select theatres across the State on Friday.

Distributors’ and producers’ associations had announced that films such as Pulimurugan and Kattappanayile Hrithik Roshan would not be screened in movie halls belonging to the Kerala Film Exhibitors’ Federation from Friday in protest against the exhibitors’ refusal to climb down from their demand for increased revenue share from movie halls.

Siyad Kokker, president of the Kerala Film Distributors Association, said that the blockbuster Pulimurugan , the first film to enter the Rs. 100-crore club in Malayalam industry, was given an extended run in select theatres to ensure that it completes the landmark of 100 days, Pulimurugan , however, was not screened in movie halls in Kochi though it continued its run in multiplexes.

G. Suresh Kumar, president of Kerala Film Producers Association, said that Kattappanayile Hrithik Roshan continued to be screened in theatres belonging to the Kerala Cine Exhibitors Association. The decision was not to screen movies in theatres belonging to the federation, he said.

Mr. Kokker, however, claimed that the movies were allowed to be screened in some cinema halls belonging to the federation as well as part of a strategy to prove that there was a split among the exhibitors. “Not all of them were in favour of the federation’s decision. Many of them had invested in renovating their theatres and won’t be able to forego the revenue from screening movies for long,” he said.

However, P.V. Basheer Ahamed, president of the exhibitors’ federation, rejected claims of split as a pipe dream of distributors’ and producers’ associations. “If there was a split how come they could not get some of our members to release the new flicks,” he asked.

He said that some of the federation members were allowed to continue the screening of old releases considering various factors. Some movie halls had taken advance online booking and their requests to be allowed to screen the movies to honour that commitment were accepted, Mr. Ahamed said.

Hit movie Pulimurugan given extended run in select halls to complete 100 days
title: Old releases not fully withdrawn

text:
The tiff between Indian Union Muslim League (IUML) councillors of the Kochi Corporation and Mayor Soumini Jain is snowballing into a major crisis with the League planning to take it up with the State leadership of the United Democratic Front (UDF).

League leaders will raise the issue in the State platform of the UDF as the party is a constituent of the front in the State and Kochi Corporation.

Though the district committee meeting of the party, which was held on Friday evening, expressed strong resentment against the Kochi Mayor and her style of functioning, the party stopped short of passing a resolution demanding her ouster.

“The meeting, however, has decided to take up the issue with the State leadership,” sources said.

On the issue of its councillor T.K. Ashraf locking horns with a trade union leader of the council, the meeting shared the sentiment that the Mayor had supported the trade union leader to act against the councillor, League sources said.

The party would legally and politically fight the case involving its councillor, it was decided.
title: League to approach UDF against Mayor

text:
There will be considerable progress in land acquisitions in the district in the next six months.

District Collector K. Mohammed Y. Safirulla on Friday told The Hindu that the land acquisition team had been strengthened for the purpose.

There are now six special tahsildars for land acquisition supported by efficient staff. The district has about 100 projects ranging from small roads to major projects such as Kochi Metro involving land acquisition.

LARA clauses

“Compliance with legal mandatory clauses in the Land Acquisition, Rehabilitation and Resettlement Act (LARA) has caused a few months’ lag in the progress of some projects. However, there will be considerable progress in the next six months,” he said.

The changes brought about by LARA include making Social Impact Analysis (SIA) mandatory and limited scope for advance possession of land for development projects. However, Ernakulam was the first district to initiate SIA ahead of development projects, including the acquisition for Kochi Metro, he said.
title: Land acquisition team strengthened

text:
The Kerala High Court has directed the Pathanamthitta district administration to ensure that no quarrying takes place at a private quarry functioning in the Chittar pachayat without a valid permit and environmental clearance.

The directive came on a writ petition filed Shajahan of Chittar.

According to the petitioner, the validity of the licence of the quarry had expired in July 2016. He also pointed out that the quarry owner had obtained the permit without environmental clearance.

The court said that as the validity of the permit had expired in July 2016, the quarry owner could not carry on its operations.

The officials should ensure that no quarrying operation was carried out unless there was a valid permit with an environmental clearance.
title: HC directive against quarrying operations

text:
The 37-ft Pappanji, made by the Kochi Biennale Foundation, will make its journey on Saturday afternoon to the seafront near the Bastion Bungalow where it will be burnt as part of the New Year celebrations at midnight.

Mayor Soumini Jain; K.J. Maxi, Hibi Eden and John Fernandez, MLAs; Deputy Mayor T.J. Vinod; Collector K. Mohammed Y. Safirulla; and cine director Abrid Shine will be present for the burning of the Pappanji, built by artists Reghunadhan K. and K.G. Anto commissioned by the KBF.

Tradition

The burning of the Pappanji is part of a tradition started here in the 1980s.

The celebrations will include an elaborate music show, which will feature singer Faisal Razi of the popular “Poomaram Kondu Kappalundakki” song and other folk singers.
title: Burning of Pappanji today

text:
Fifty volunteers are pedalling their way from Kozhikode to the main venue of the Kochi Muziris Biennale with one lakh discarded ballpoint pens, which will be part of a permanent art installation to come up at Fort Kochi.

The cycle journey, to spread the message of environmental protection and conservation, has been undertaken as part of the ‘Pendrive’ campaign to put discarded plastic pens to good use. The campaign team has so far collected one lakh pens from Malabar region. “This, along with four lakh pens already collected from across the State, will be used for the art work,” said a release in this regard.

Riyas Komu, secretary of the Kochi Biennale Foundation (KBF), said the installation would be on the ‘Immini Balya Onnu’ (A rather big one) conceived by yesteryear Malayalam writer Vaikom Muhammed Basheer.

Estimates suggest that school students alone throw away more than one and a half crore disposable plastic pens in a month in Kerala. “The Pendrive campaign aims to target this throwaway culture and plastic pollution at one go,” said Lakshmi N. Menon, coordinator of the campaign.

“Plastic pens are not considered for recycling due to the presence of nibs and ink. Even eco conscious people who are aware of the effects of plastic pollution and avoid disposable bags and bottles do not see disposable pens with the same criticality. As a result, these pens end up in our water sources and landfills polluting our water and soil. The Pendrive campaign has been instrumental in creating awareness among the general populace and motivating them to return to reusable pens or ink pens,” she said.

She said the campaign as well as the installation took inspiration from the work of Basheer whose pen and imagination encompassed all life forms that cohabit our precious planet, to amalgamate art, literature and environment into a single aspiration aptly named ‘Immini Balya Onnu’.

The Pendrive volunteers are slated to arrive on January 1 at Aspinwall House in Fort Kochi where they will be received by K.J. Maxi, MLA.
title: Green message with discarded pens

text:
Cochin Shipyard Limited (CSL) has completed the construction of a series of 20 Fast Patrol Vessels (FPV) for the Coast Guard three months ahead of schedule.

The last vessel in the series, CGS Ayush, was delivered to the Coast Guard on Friday. The protocol of delivery and acceptance was signed between Suresh Babu N.V., Director (Operations) of CSL, and Commandant (JG) Asheesh Sharma, Commanding Officer-designate of the ship.

The yard was awarded the contract for construction of the 20 ships on October 20, 2010, and delivered the first on September 25, 2013, with each of the rest being delivered in two-month intervals thereafter.

The agile ships are being used for EEZ patrol, anti-piracy and anti-smuggling patrol and search and rescue operations. CGS Ayush will operate from the Coast Guard station at Krishnapattanam.
title: Vessels delivered in time

text:
The sea may turn rough along the Kerala and south Tamil Nadu coast for three days starting December 31, the Indian National Centre for Ocean Information Services has warned.

Low-lying areas of these States may be inundated during the period. The sea may turn rough from 11 p.m. on the day.

A combination of high swell waves, which may reach a height of up to 2 metres, and spring tide would lead to rough seas, a communication from the centre said.

Strong winds

In Tamil Nadu, the centre has predicted strong winds from north-easterly direction with speed occasionally reaching 45-55 kmph along and off the south Tamil Nadu coast. Fishermen have been advised to exercise caution while venturing into the sea.
title: Rough sea likely from today

text:
The State government must intervene and help resolve opposition from the people of Mulavukad and nearby areas so that National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) can begin levying toll from vehicles using the 17-km-long Container Road that links Vallarpadam and Kalamassery, Mansukh Mandaviya, Union Minister of State for Road Transport and Highways, said on Friday.

He was speaking at a review meet held here to assess the progress of various projects undertaken by the agency in the State.

The meeting entrusted K. P. Prabhakaran, chief engineer, PWD (National Highways Wing), with the task of taking up the matter with the State government.

Mr. Mandaviya said that the demands of the people at Mulavukad and Moolampilly (to build service roads, drains etc.,) should be looked into.

A few people were raising new demands with the sole objective of preventing toll collection, he said.

The NHAI has done little despite local residents, commuters and the police demanding reflectors, street lights etc., on the accident-prone stretch where there are half a dozen bridges and haphazardly-parked container lorries.

NHAI officials said that the agency had spent Rs. 600 crore to build the four-lane road and bridges.

The widespread demand for Vyttila and Kundanoor flyovers did not come up for discussion at the meeting.
title: Minister for levying of toll on Container Road

text:
Train services in the Ernakulam-Puthukkad section will be regulated from December 31 up to January 28, except on Mondays and on January 14 and 15, in connection with the track maintenance works being done between Thrissur and Puthukkad railway stations.Thus, train No.56363 - Nilambur Road-Ernakulam Jn. passenger, leaving Nilambur Road at 2.55 p.m., will be short-terminated at Thrissur, while train No.16306 - Kannur-Ernakulam Intercity Express, leaving Kannur at 2.35 pm, will be detained at Thrissur for two hours. Train No.56389 Ernakulam-Kottayam passenger scheduled to leave Ernakulam Jn. at 8.35 p.m. will begin the trip only by 10.35 p.m. Other Ernakulam-bound trains passing through the corridor between 4 p.m. and 10.45 p.m. are likely to get detained for durations from 30 minutes up to two hours during the period.

— Staff Reporter
title: Train services to be regulated

text:
Nastik Nation, an open forum of atheists, has expressed concern over Kerala State Road Transport Corporation (KSRTC) buses displaying advertisements that by and large promote superstitions.

In a memorandum submitted to Chief Minister Pinarayi Vijayan and Transport Minister A.K. Saseendran, national president of the forum Kannan Sivaram said a secular government should ensure that no public property was used for spreading superstitions.

He called upon the authorities to stop providing KSRTC buses for such campaigns as they misguided and misled the people.
title: Forum of atheists raises demand

text:
The police are putting in place stringent curbs on New Year’s eve celebrations on Kozhikode beach. Entry of vehicles will be restricted to the beach after 7 p.m. on Saturday, which is likely to create huge disappointment for those planning a low-cost celebration.

Officials from the Special Branch said the move was part of precautions being taken to prevent clashes by unruly crowds during celebrations. “We have limited number of police officers on duty, and the intention is to ensure a peaceful celebration for all,” they said.

Shadow police teams and women civil police officers in mufti have been entrusted with the responsibility of ensuring the safety of women and children in various public places in the city and its suburbs. The police control room here will have a quick response mechanism for addressing all complaints related to New Year celebrations. Citizens may avail the service through the control room helpline — 100.

All hoteliers in the city have been asked to wind up New Year celebrations by 1.30 a.m. Bar hotels and beer parlours have to stop serving liquor by 11 p.m. as per the State-wide instruction. Policemen, including those from the Armed Reserve camp, will be deployed for ensuring proper compliance of directives by hoteliers.

The City Police Commissioner’s office has said that the rules will be applicable for New Year celebrations planned at resorts, hostels, flats, and apartments. To curb drunk driving, vehicle checking will be carried out at all major traffic junctions. All CCTV cameras under the city police and the Motor Vehicles Department have been readied for flawless night surveillance.

“We have no intention to curb celebrations in the city. The new restrictions planned by the department are to facilitate a peaceful celebration,” said Assistant Commissioner (Kozhikode South) K.P. Abdul Razak. He said the ban on functions after 1.30 a.m was aimed at reducing sound pollution.
title: Police impose curbs on New Year revelry

text:
The State School Arts Festivals have played a major role in preserving traditional art forms. However, there have been complaints from learned quarters that several art forms have been skewered and rules flouted to fit them for capsule formats.

The Akhila Kerala Kolkali Sangham Ekopana Samithi is the latest to complain against the alleged deformation of the art form when adapted for stage.

“Kolkali performances at arts festivals,” said Samithi chairman Nasar Kappad, “often resemble a dance drama. The participating teams often use rhythms and sticks that are not part of the traditional art form. They are very noisy, and the movements are often unscientific.”

Instead of highlighting the existing contents, the teams have been incorporating contents that are not part of the art form. Similar issues are noticed in the Mappila art forms of ‘Duff Muttu’, ‘Oppana’, ‘Vattappattu’, and ‘Arbana Muttu’, Mr. Nasar said. The Samithi maintained that undiscerning judges were a major reason for the inclusion of unscientific features in these art forms. “The judges often are not familiar with the art form and are appointed by influential people,” Mr. Nasar said, adding that they often judged performances based on speed and noise.

As a result, teams that follow the traditional method often return disappointed. The situation forces even trainers to guide their students in such a way that they manage to win competitions.

Stress on tradition

The Samithi has requested the government to take steps to ensure that Kolkali is presented in the traditional format in the forthcoming school arts festival. Realising the importance of the festival, the Samithi has also made a plea to include various types of Kolkali in the festival.
title: ‘Kolkali rules flouted for convenience’

text:
‘Battalion’, a Kollam-based pre-recruitment training agency, whose selection camps at Vadakara and Kozhikode early this week ended in disruption, has accused its rivals of resorting to unethical practices to keep it out of business.

Addressing the media here on Friday, Jeevan Raj, head of the agency, claimed that the unexpected clashes that resulted in the closure of two selection camps of Battalion in Kozhikode district were part of such an enmity that was less noticed amid the pre-planned ruckus.

“We organised the pre-recruitment selection camps in Kozhikode district after circulating all details of the selection procedures among job aspirants and their parents. There was no hidden agenda or attempt to extract money as propagated,” he said, adding that the false propaganda was spearheaded by his business rivals.

Mr. Jeevanraj said his training centre was opened nearly two years ago with the support of experienced ex-servicemen, and that it was facing attacks and smear campaigns by rival training centres.

“Many a time, we noticed the presence of members from rival training units during our selection programmes and attempts by them to trigger protests by job aspirants citing strange topics,” he said.

False propaganda blamed

C.C. Angelos, a retired Additional Sub Inspector and trainer at the pre-recruitment centre, said the false propaganda had created confusion among young army job aspirants and trainees. “We have never claimed that we directly recruit candidates to the army or any other force.

“We only prepare the screened candidates for army tests to enhance their chances,” he pointed out.

M. Baby, an ex-serviceman and trainer at Battalion, said the centre had already trained around 300 candidates from various parts of Kozhikode district, of which 40 had secured placements.

“We collect fee from trainees in accordance with the terms and conditions, and there is nothing hidden in the process. In addition, we provide concession to deserving candidates from poor financial background,” he claimed.

Kollam-based recruitment agency accuses competitors of resorting to unethical practices
title: Irregularities alleged in pre-recruitment

text:
With the objective of showcasing successful farming models and agriculture ventures, the Agriculture Department will host a three-day ‘Kisan Meet’ at Koottalida in Kottur grama panchayat from January 2. Exhibitions, technical sessions on modern farming ventures, and farm-oriented contests will add colour to the meet, which will be opened by Agriculture Minister V.S. Sunil Kumar.

Purushan Kadalundi, MLA, the chief patron of the organising committee, said on Friday that the fair would be part of the Prime Minister’s Krishi Sanjayee Yojana (PMKSY), and that it would help in disseminating the latest agri-related information to the public. Balussery constituency was selected to host the meet taking into account its popularisation of small-scale agriculture farms, he said.

M. Nandini, Principal Agriculture Officer and Director of Agriculture Technology Management Agency (ATMA), said the Kisan Meet was aimed at celebrating the district’s notable achievements in agriculture and efforts by farmers to implement innovative programmes of the Agriculture Department. “In 2016, we managed to expand farming to around 800 hectares of fallow land,” she explained.

V. Prathibha, president of Balussery block panchayat and one of the chief coordinators of the programme, said the meet would offer farmers an opportunity to attend technical sessions on major areas of farming.

Cost-effective farming ventures, seasonal cultivation, and organic farming will be among the topics that will be discussed during the sessions, she said.

As many as 18 stalls, all highlighting successful farming ventures and efforts of successful entrepreneurs, will be set up at the venue. District Kudumbasree Mission and Krishi Vigyan Kendra too will be part of the three-day event.

The meet, beginning on January 2, will have special

sessions on modern agriculture ventures
title: Kisan Meet to promote farming models

text:
Contract employees at various child protection offices across the State are faced with uncertainty regarding their monthly wages, thanks to a few bureaucrats who allegedly messed up the fund flow.

“We may or may not get our wages. When we get, it is sometimes by cheque, sometimes through treasuries and at times through the District Child Protection Officer. There is no certainty,” an employee said on condition of anonymity.

There are 144 contract employees working at various child protection offices in the district. There are 10 staffers in Kozhikode, including two Child Protection Officers, one Legal cum Probation Officer, two social workers, and a counsellor, data entry operator, data analyst, and an accountant.

“Having severed in this position, we expect to have a grade fixed for us. Without a grade, we do not get most of the benefits that government employees avail of. Even leaves are difficult to be availed,” he added.

The employees have been posted under the Centre’s Integrated Child Protection Scheme (ICPS). Hence their salary too comes from the Centre. But it is being monitored by the State government. The Centre had declared a minimum wage for them in February 2016, but it is yet to be implemented in the State. “The State has surpassed Central guidelines in this regard,” District Child Protection Officer Sheeba Mumtaz said.

“As regards contract staff, there is not much hope of getting a permanent position. The Centre has appointed them, but the State can make the appointments permanent, if needed. However it is highly unlikely,” Ms. Mumtaz said.

The contract employees only hope that there will be more clarity on their position in the department and their wages at least in the next financial year.

We expect to have a grade fixed for us. Without a grade, we do not get most of the benefits that government employees avail of

A contract employee
title: ICPS contract workers stare at an uncertain future

text:
One lakh pens

for biennale

Around one lakh discarded pens collected from various parts of the district under the aegis of the District Suchitwa Mission will be sent for the Kochi-Muziris Biennale on Saturday. The pens will be handed over to Green Care Mission at a function to be held at the Kozhikode Beach at 4 p.m. The pens will be taken to Kochi escorted by a cycle rally by Malabar Riders. A variety of programmes, including songs on environmental topics, wall painting titled ‘Green Wall’ and ‘Green thought’, a work made of waste products, will be held on the occasion. The pens will be used to set up an installation at Kochi, a press release said.

— Staff Reporter
title: The Hindu

text:
Interview for post

of medical officer

A written test and interview for the post of medical officer in the Homoeopathy Department on daily wage basis will be held at the District Medical Office (Homoeo) on January 18 at 9.30 a.m. For details, contact 0495 2371748, a press release said.

— Staff Reporter
title: The Hindu

text:
Lecturer vacancy

There is an opening for the post of Lecturer in English at the Koyilandy Regional Centre of Sree Sankaracharya University of Sanskrit. Candidates qualified under UGC norms shall walk in for an interview at the centre at 11.30 a.m. on January 4, 2017 with original documents to prove age and qualifications. Other candidates will be considered in the absence of those with UGC specified qualifications. For details, contact 0496-2695445, a press release said. — Staff Reporter
title: The Hindu

text:
New OP counter

to be opened

Minister for Excise and Labour T.P. Ramakrishnan will inaugurate the new OP counter and parking area at the Thiruvannur Community Health Centre on Saturday. Parakkal Abdulla, MLA, will chair the function. The new facilities were set up under the aegis of the Thodanur block panchayat as part of the hospital’s Phase-III development work. — Staff Reporter
title: Around the city

text:
Regional camps

for fishermen

The Fisheries Department will conduct regional camps in the district from January 9 to explain the benefits of various government-funded housing schemes for fishermen. Chaliyam, Beypore, Elathur, Koyilandy, and Vadakara regions will be covered under the five-day camp. — Staff Reporter
title: Around the city

text:
Minister for Forests and Animal Husbandry K. Raju addresses the gathering after laying the foundation stone for a Milma plant at Moorkanad on Friday.

The government will soon begin insurance schemes for cattle. As many as 40,000 cows will be insured this year, and the remaining will be included in the scheme next year, said Minister for Forests and Animal Husbandry K. Raju here on Friday.

He was speaking after laying the foundation stone for a Milma dairy plant at Moorkanad. The Malappuram dairy plant of Milma being set up at a cost of Rs.60 crore can process and pack 1 lakh litres of milk a day.

The Minister said the government would give 75 per cent of cattle insurance premium as subsidy. While 50 per cent of the premium will be met by the State government, the remaining 25 per cent will be the responsibility of local bodies. Farmers will have to bear 25 per cent.

Mr. Raju said Milma should give top price to milk farmers by reducing the procurement and supply price gap.

He said the High Court had empowered Milma to fix the price of milk. “Therefore, Milma does not have to wait for the permission of the government to offer a better price to the farmers,” he said.

Milma, which makes an annual profit of Rs. 60 crore, can give better price to the farmers by not burdening the consumers, he said.

The Minister said the State could achieve self-sufficiency in milk production in two years. Currently, 70 per cent of the milk

consumed in the State is produced here.

T.A. Ahamed Kabeer, MLA, presided. District panchayat president A.P. Unnikrishnan; councillors V. Sudhakaran and M.K. Rafeeka; Mankada block president Saheeda Elikkattil; Moorkanad panchayat president K. Rajagopalan; Milma chairman P.T. Gopala Kurup; Animal Husbandry Department director George Kutty Jacob; and former MLA Satyan Mokeri were among those who took part in the function.

Currently Milma is distributing milk and other products in Malappuram from its plants in Kozhikode, Wayanad and Palakkad. The

Malappuram dairy plant will bring self-sufficiency for the district in milk and related products.
title: Farmers to get cattle insurance soon

text:
Students from tribal areas apprised Minister for Welfare of Scheduled Castes/Scheduled Tribes A.K. Balan of the non-inclusion of the non-inclusion of tribal language and its rich folklore in the teaching process, resulting in total social alienation of tribal youth. The Minister was here on the second day of the ongoing State tribal students arts and culture meet, Sargotsavam-2016.

“There is a feeling of alienation among us when we get initiated into the world of letters in Malayalam, which is an alien language as far as the tribespeople are concerned,’’ said students of model tribal residential school at Kaniyampatta in Wayanad in response to the queries from the Minister.

The Minister said tribal schools across the State would soon be equipped with tribal teachers who can bridge the gap between different tribal languages and the medium of instruction, Malayalam.

The Minister told the students to engage in extracurricular activities apart from scoring marks in exams as that would help boost their self-confidence.

Residential schools

The students urged the Minister to start more residential institutions for higher studies of tribal children who have completed Plus Two.
title: Tribal students raise language issue

text:
Processing of passion fruits at a unit at the vegetable farm at Nelliampathy in Palakkad. At the 339.12-hectare farm, where orange cultivation was stopped nearly four decades ago, passion fruit is now grown.—Photo: K.K. Mustafah

Thirty-six years after plantations in Nelliampathy stopped cultivation of the area’s unique oranges known for their sweetness and small size, efforts are now on to reintroduce orange farming in the hill station. As a first step, the Agriculture Department has begun cultivating oranges on a 25-acre plot on its vegetable farm located close to the Parambikulam Tiger Reserve.

During the British rule, Nelliampathy oranges had many takers worldwide, including the British royal family. Fresh oranges plucked from Nelliampathy were shipped to England via Kochi harbour.

During the Second World War, the vegetable farm controlled by then princely State of Kochi had supplied oranges and other fruits to fighters positioned elsewhere. By 1980, the plantations in Nelliampathy had stopped cultivating oranges largely because of poor patronisation, decrease in demand, and lack of modern cultivation methods.

“We started orange cultivation last year on a small portion of the farm on an experimental basis. When the result was positive, we suggested the possibility of reintroducing orange cultivation in Nelliampathy to Agriculture Minister V.S. Sunil Kumar. It was his eagerness that prompted us to begin cultivation this year on a large scale,” said farm superintendent E.K. Yusuf.

4,000 saplings

Last week, 4,000 orange saplings were planted on the 25-acre plot. There was a budgetary allocation of Rs.50 lakh for the purpose. Some good varieties have been planted and they should start giving yield from next year.

Mr.Yusuf said cultivation would be extended to more areas in the coming years depending on the yield next year. “Soil moisture and climate are still conducive for orange cultivation. What they require is proper care using modern technology,” said Mr. Yusuf.

Passion fruit now

Though orange cultivation was stopped years ago, the vegetable farm still attracts tourists. Now passion fruit is grown here.

The fruit and its value-added products are a major hit among tourists.

Spread over 339.12 hectares of land, the farm is a major tourist attraction. It also operates a retail outlet where 91 varieties of fruit-based products, including jams and jellies, are available.

Nearly 100 tourists visit the farm daily which is at an altitude of 1,050 m above sea level and receives an average annual rainfall of 3,500 mm. The temperature ranges from 12 to 31 degree Celsius.
title: Nelliampathy oranges back after 36 years

text:
Special Police Officer N. Vijayakumar addressing the new batch of police personnel at the Sabarimala Sannidhanam on Friday.– PHOTO: LEJU KAMAL

The police department has deployed the new batch comprising 2,980 police personnel at Sabarimala Sannidhanam, Pampa, Nilackal, and Erumely on Friday for crowd management during the Makaravilakku pilgrimage.

The Sannidhanam Police Special Officer, N. Vijayakumar, told The Hindu that a total of 1,467 police personnel, comprising 1,325 civil police officers, 100 sub-inspectors, 30 Circle Inspectors, and 12 Deputy Superintendents of Police, were deployed at the holy hillock alone.

The new batch is besides the 64-member National Disaster Response Force and the 140-member Rapid Action Force attached to the Central Reserve Police Force, commandos of the State police, and special police teams from Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu.

Addressing a meeting held at the Valiya Nadappanthal here on Friday afternoon, Mr Vijayakumar has called upon the new batch of police personnel to take their duty at Sabarimala as a service to the pilgrims.

He said the police personnel should show etiquette in words and deeds to the scores of Ayyappa devotees visiting Sabarimala.

They should call every male pilgrim ‘Swami’ and female pilgrim ‘Malikappuram’ giving due respect to them, the Minister said.

Mr Vijayakumar said the police personnel should avoid using mobile phone while on duty and follow the directions given in the Sabarimala duty manual supplied to them.

S. Sreejith, Inspector General of Police, is also camping at Sabarimala to monitor the crowd management on the first day of the Makaravilakku pilgrim season.

The Special Commissioner appointed by the Kerala High Court, M.Manoj, too is camping at Sabarimala Sannidhanam as an observer of the judiciary.

Pilgrim dies at Karimala

A 38-year-old pilgrim, identified as R.K. Nagaraj from Naiyakalpalayam near Pattanam in Coimbatore, died of heart attack at Karimala on the traditional Erumely-Azhutha-Karimala-Pampa path leading to Sabarimala in the wee hours of Friday.

The Eco Development Committee workers took the pilgrim to the Pampa Government Hospital where he was declared dead.

The Ayyappa Seva Sanghom volunteers took the body to Coimbatore in the Sanghom ambulance, later.
title: Strong security cover at Sabarimala

text:
Artefacts on display at an exhibition held as part of the Indian History Congress at Karyavattom.— Photo: C. Gouridasan Nair

As significant as the deliberations of the 77th Indian History Congress (IHC) that concluded in the city on Friday were the different exhibitions held as part of the event.

Each brought the past alive through articles, artefacts, and documents from early to modern periods of national history.

If one of the exhibitions featured the fruits of years of labour by archaeologists, from the early to medieval and modern periods, another was all about the carefully preserved palm leaf manuscripts and yet another on the cultural heritage of Kerala.

Evolution of writing

Almost every venue was teeming with visitors through the duration of the conference and helping them understand the material on display were students of the related departments of the University of Kerala.

At the Manuscripts Library and Research Centre, one could witness the evolution of the art of writing and preservation of written texts dealing with the Vedas, Puranas, Ayurveda, Yagas, besides creative works by eminent writers of different eras in the evolution of Malayalam language and literature.

At the Department of Archaeology, there were the replicas from the Harappan period to the contemporary times, including pot shards, beads, and coins collected from Vizhinjam and Neendakara.

Records

On display at the exhibition on Kerala’s historical heritage were royal proclamations, government records, records of historic decisions, pictures of protected monuments, articles displaying exquisite artistry such as Manichithrathazhu, and the fear-instilling Chithravadhakkoodu , used in erstwhile Travancore for meting out capital punishment.
title: Past comes alive at expos

text:
Vanishing green:With the monsoon playing truant, the heat is taking its toll on the normally green hills, forcing cattle to trudge longer distances for better pastures. A scene from Kuttikkanam near Wagamon.— Photo: S.MahinshaS MAHINSHA

With North-East monsoon signing off with a whimper, the State government is mulling tougher drought mitigation measures, including a water rationing system for households and industries.

The water level is dipping in most reservoirs and irrigation has been suspended in three districts. With large parts of the State facing parched conditions, the government has turned its attention to addressing drinking water shortage. Efforts are on to establish water kiosks in all wards.

Water kiosks in all wards

The Kerala State Disaster Management Authority (KSDMA) has estimated a requirement of 10,900 kiosks across the State.

The government is gearing up to enforce the drought mitigation measures recommended by the KSDMA. Officials said the proposal for a 75 per cent cut in the use of groundwater by industries had not yet been taken seriously. “Most industrial units in the State use groundwater for captive supply. So far, there has not been any serious effort to regulate the use of water. The situation calls for drastic enforcement,” an official said.

The government is also considering a crackdown on wastage of water, with punitive action as a deterrent. As per the system statistics released by the State Load Despatch Centre, the total water storage in hydro electric reservoirs has come down to 47 per cent on Friday, enough to generate just 1,943 million units of electricity.

Last year, the hydroelectric dams in the State had enough water to generate 2,744 mu, while the situation was better in 2014 (3,206 mu) and 2013 (3,646 mu).

Hope in summer rain

According to A. Shainamol, Managing Director, Kerala Water Authority, the storage position in reservoirs used for drinking water supply was enough to tide over the situation till March. “Efforts are on the fast track for completion of ongoing water supply schemes and carrying out repairs wherever necessary. The summer rain in April and May are expected to provide some relief,” she said.

That is something the Groundwater Department is also looking forward to. The groundwater situation in the State is fairly comfortable as of now, except in Chittoor, Malampuzha, and Kasaragod. “The intermittent off season showers will hopefully recharge ground water sources in most water stressed areas,” said Jose James, Director in charge.

The department has taken up a project to repair bore-wells supplying drinking water to parched areas and launched a campaign to promote water conservation.

Meanwhile, the North-East monsoon period has drawn to a close, leaving Kerala with a 61 per cent rainfall deficit. “The failure of the two monsoons this year is responsible for the drought situation,” said V.K. Mini, meteorologist at the Met Centre, here. “The next two months will be dry for the State, posing a challenge in drought management. Thereafter, the summer rain is likely to bring some relief.”

The pre-monsoon period from March 1 to May 31 this year had registered a rainfall deficit of 18 per cent while the South-West monsoon recorded a deficit of 34 per cent.
title: Tough steps to tide over drought

text:
The Public Service Commission has decided to extend by six months the validity of about 200 rank lists that completed three years on Saturday and also those which are set to complete the same tenure by June 30, 2017.

The decision was made at a special meeting of the commission here on Friday following a Cabinet recommendation in this regard.

Briefing reporters about the deliberations at the meeting, commission chairman M.K. Sakeer told reporters that the lists that have already got an extension have not been considered by the commission. Moreover, the validity of the extended lists will automatically lapse on the publication of a new list for the same posts. The normal tenure of a list is three years.

Mr. Sakeer clarified that all lists may not get the benefit of six months. The commission has taken the decision without considering any particular list. Otherwise it may be deemed as if the commission was trying to favour identified beneficiaries. The decision has been made in line with the rules and regulations of the commission and also for those selected for uniformed forces, he said.

Procedures for issuing recruitment advice memos to about 4,000 posts have been completed. Recruitment can further be expedited on adopting e-reporting of vacancies and also rectifying the anomalies in the special rules for various posts.

The government is seriously considering the commission’s requests for more posts to handle the workload, he said.
title: Validity of PSC rank lists extended

text:
Chief Minister Pinarayi Vijayan inaugurating the 84th Sivagiri Pilgrimage at Sivagiri Madhom in Varkala on Friday; and (right) a view of the crowd.— Photo: S. Mahinsha

The 84th Sivagiri Pilgrimage festival began at the Sivagiri Madhom in Varkala on Friday. Chief Minister Pinarayi Vijayan inaugurated the three-day festival. Pilgrims from across the State, clad in yellow costumes, started flocking in large numbers to the pilgrimage centre right from the morning.

The Chief Minister said the teachings and ideals of Sree Narayana Guru had a greater importance now, not just in the country, but across a world torn by terror, violence, and migration.

“Rivers of blood are flowing due to the violent conflicts arising out of religious and racial differences. The feeling of humanism is being drained out of us. It is in thinking about ways to revive such ideas that we understand the importance of the Guru’s teachings,” said the Chief Minister.

He said that the success of the pilgrimage was not in thousands of people attending it, but in them returning to their homes imbibing the Guru’s ideals and practising them in their personal and public lives.

Vishudhananda Swami, president of the Sree Narayana Dharma Sangham Trust, who presided over the function, said the pilgrimage which began decades ago with a handful of people now brought together lakhs of people. He said that moves were being made to twist the Guru’s teachings, shorn of their real ideals.

Leader of the Opposition Ramesh Chennithala; A. Sampath, MP; MLAs V. Joy and O. Rajagopal; and others took part in the inaugural function. In the afternoon, Union Minister of State for Petroleum and Natural Gas Dharmendra Pradhan inaugurated a meet on education. A meet on spirituality held in the evening was presided over by Local Self Government Minister K.T. Jaleel.
title: Greater importance for Guru’s teachings: CM

text:
A team of researchers from the Kerala State Biodiversity Board (KSBB) has reported the sighting of the Great bittern, a bird species that was last spotted in Kerala in 2008.

The bird, which is also known as Eurasian bittern (scientific name: Botaurus stellaris) , from the Vellayani-Punchakari wetlands was spotted by project associate Sujith V. Gopalan and principal scientist Linda John on Thursday. The bird was last spotted at the Kole wetlands in Pullazhi, Thrissur, on May 11, 2008, according to official records. The sighting of the species by the KSBB team was its first photo documentation from the State, official sources said.

Elusive

Mr. Gopalan pointed out that the Great bittern was a wading bird in the Bittern subfamily ( Botaurinae ) of the heron family Ardeidae. The species is an elusive bird and is seldom seen in the open. They prefer to skulk within reed beds and thick vegetations adjoining waterbodies.

The species was sighted during a visit by the researchers of the board as part of a biodiversity documentation of the wetlands. The Vellayani-Punchakari wetland has been home to several birds and is a hotspot for birding.

On the rise

The number of species documented in and around the freshwater lake in the State capital has been on rise for the past many years. An increase of over five species has been reported in 2016 alone. However, this cannot be necessarily viewed as an encouraging trend.

“The increase is primarily due to the fact that the region has been gradually drying owing to climate change or global warming. Bird species such as Hoopoe, which is usually seen in dry regions, were also sighted here recently.

There has been a significant fall in the water level in the Vellayani lake,” he said.

He pointed out that while species such as Black-headed ibis and Painted stork were sighted in the State in the 1990s, they were were perceived as part of the increasing biodiversity in the region. However, it later turned out that such sightings were a warning sign. While an abrupt reversal of the trend is unlikely, mitigation steps that could be undertaken at a local-level include afforestation and measures to bring down carbon footprint.
title: Great bittern spotted in Vellayani wetlands

text:
The State budget for 2017-18 is unlikely to be presented in January. Finance Minister T.M. Thomas Isaac said on Friday that the State government would wait till it got clarity on the Central allocation to the State.

Following the demonetisation of Rs. 1,000 and Rs. 500 notes, there was confusion over the Central allocation to the State. The State government has not yet got a clear perception on the funds to be apportioned by the Centre and hence the budget would not be presented in January, Mr. Isaac said. Welfare pension disbursal disrupted The currency crunch has disrupted the distribution of welfare pensions in different parts of the State. Mr. Isaac’s office informed here that the Reserve Bank of India was unable to provide sufficient currency to distribute the pension as planned earlier.

The government had started the disbursal of a sum of Rs. 506.7 crore from Monday through cooperative banks for the 16-lakh pensioners who had requested to provide pension at home. This had been disrupted. A sum of Rs. 546.8 crore was transferred to the bank accounts of 17.58 lakh pensioners. The government had made special arrangements for providing funds from treasury to the cooperative banks for pension disbursal. But the RBI was unable to provide currency for the purpose. The government had distributed pension and arrears through cooperative banks during Onam without any hitch. Once the fund flow from the treasury dried up, cooperative banks used their cash balance and daily collection, but still could not achieve the target. The daily requirement from December 26 to 31 was pegged at Rs. 100 crore and the government had informed the RBI that it required currency for the purpose. State Bank of Travancore could provide only Rs. 86 crore against the demand for Rs. 164 crore.

Banks could totally provide only Rs. 122 crore against the government’s request for Rs. 214 crore for paying the pension. The RBI had not provided any fund for seven treasuries — Edakkara, Kaduthuruthy, Meenachil, Pallikkathodu, Paravur, Neyyatinkara, and Pala — till December 30.

The State government will wait till it gets a clear picture on the Central allocation

to the State.
title: State budget unlikely in January

text:
Union Minister for Petroleum Dharmendra Pradhan gives lime juice to BJP State president Kummanam Rajasekharan to mark the conclusion of his fast in Thiruvananthapuram on Friday.

Congress president Sonia Gandhi and other leaders of the party are opposing demonetisation since they hold black money deposits, Union Petroleum Minister Dharmendra Pradhan has said.

Ending a 24-hour fast of Bharatiya Janata Party State president Kummanam Rajasekharan in front of the Secretariat on Friday, against the alleged anti-people policies of the State government, Mr.Pradhan said he could not understand why the Left leaders, who claim to be the protectors of the poor, were opposing the reform.

Mr.Pradhan claimed that tax collection had gone up since demonetisation.

The common man was cooperating with Prime Minister Narendra Modi for bringing about financial discipline. There was no space for trade union leaders who acted as middlemen and cheated the common man, he said.

Mr. Rajasekharan demanded that Finance Minister T.M. Thomas Isaac address the problems of the State before criticising Mr. Modi for the economic reform. Dr. Isaac, who is trying to counsel Mr. Modi, could not pay the salary and pensions of the KSRTC employees in time, he said.

Chief Minister Pinarayi Vijayan should clarify the reasons for the public sector undertakings in the State recording huge loss. The BJP would not end its agitation against the State government. It would organise regional rallies from January 8, he said.

Former State presidents V. Muraleedharan and P.K. Krishnadas, general secretaries A.N. Radhakrishnan and M.T. Ramesh spoke.
title: Isaac should address State’s problems first: Kummanam

text:
Even as the government is promoting cashless transactions post-demonetisation, a proposal of the Motor Vehicles Department (MVD) to introduce point of sale terminals (PoS) to collect quarterly tax of transport vehicles has been caught in red tape.

The MVD submitted the proposal to introduce PoS terminals in 73 offices - 18 regional transport offices (RTO) and 55 sub-RTO offices - in February this year.

The State Bank of Travancore even came up with a software for the MVD to roll out cashless transactions for those owning stage carriers, lorries, trucks, taxies, jeeps, and autorickshaws.

The initiative came in the wake of adverse comments by the CAG that the amount being collected quarterly as tax from transport vehicles through Demand Draft (DD) was reaching the account only after a month, which was causing loss to the exchequer.

MVD objective

With the introduction of PoS, the MVD aimed at avoiding queues in banks (to obtain DD) and in RTO offices. The owners of these vehicles can save the money paid in banks for taking DD. Besides, the dependence on touts and agents can be avoided. The quarterly tax for a stage carrier is Rs. 34,000.

An MVD official told The Hindu that the proposal was being held back by the Finance Department citing the T+2 rule. As per the rule, cash collected through a PoS terminal would reach the designated account only next day.

Unlike in the case of mercantile establishment and institutions, the tax collected from the vehicle owners will have to reach accounts of various departments, as cess is also being levied for various purposes. This will need modifications and it can be done, the official admits.

At check-posts

The MVD has now decided to roll out PoS terminals in 19 check-posts across the State and for the enforcement squads on the field. Motorists will be able to pay fine by credit or debit cards if they are booked , the official said.

The file for the PoS terminal is awaiting clearance of the government at a time when an intensive campaign by Akshaya, designated by the Union Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology as the nodal agency for the Go Cashless campaign, to promote digital payment platforms is on.
title: MVD’s cashless campaign in limbo

text:
Union Minister of State for Petroleum and Natural Gas Dharmendra Pradhan explaining about cashless transactions to a customer at a petrol pump at Bakery Junction on Friday.

The benefits of demonetisation measures launched by Prime Minister Narendra Modi has started reaching the grass-roots level and common man, Union Minister of State for Petroleum and Natural Gas Dharmendra Pradhan has said.

Speaking after launching a customer awareness campaign as part of promoting cashless transfer at the BPCL outlet in Bakery Junction here on Friday, Mr. Pradhan said demonetisation measures had a huge impact on the economy and replacing 66 per cent of the withdrawn currency was a big challenge.

“Things are settling down and still there is anxiety among the citizens whether they are getting what is due to them. Restrictions are there in cash withdrawal and it has inconvenienced some. The discomfort has to be resolved. We are thankful to the citizens for supporting the Prime Minister and standing rock solid behind him.”

On the raid on the residence of Tamil Nadu Chief Secretary and the case of BSP, Mr. Pradhan said politicians had lost money following the drive and they were answerable on the deposits in question.

The Union Minister said 82 per cent of the 17,413 contract workers in Kochi Refinery were getting their wages through banks. This was just 24 per cent before demonetisation.

“The workers are getting Rs. 1,000 to Rs. 2,000 more now. Transparency has been assured. The BPCL authorities had said that the remaining contract workers will be brought under bank payment before January next,” he added.

The digital transactions in petrol pumps was just 3 to 4 per cent and it had gone up to 20 per cent. Kerala was not lagging behind and there was multi-fold growth, Mr. Pradhan said.

Executive director, BPCL, Kochi Refinery, Prasad K. Panicker; head, retail, south, BPCL, Santosh Kumar; State head, Kerala and Karnataka, BPCL, Rahul Tandon; chief marketing manager, BPCL, Somachudan; and officials of SBI and Pay TM were present.
title: Benefits of note ban reaching common man: Union Minister

text:
From afar it has the appearance of a compact boat, but one who goes near and enters it would soon realise that the compactness is deceptive as, hidden within the Car Nicobar-class offshore patrol vessel of the Indian Navy, is astounding operational capabilities and fire power.

Not surprisingly, there was a huge turnout of people to see the naval vessel berthed at the Vizhinjam harbour on Friday. Weighing 370 tonnes, INS Kabra was commissioned in 2012, one of the 12 Car Nicobar-class vessels of the Navy. Its uniqueness lies in that it is a water jet-propelled vessel. The ship consists of small, large, and heavy guns with laser rangefinder.

Navigation system

The navigation system includes GPS, electronic and radar system. The ship was made indigeniously by Garden Reach of Kolkata. INS Kabra, which has four captains and 40 sailors, would head to Kochi from Vizhinjam. There was a small exhibition of four amours, 5.56 mm INSAS assault rifle, 9 mm pistol, 9 mm carbine, and 51 mm mortar.

There was a sale of jerseys, T-shirts, sweat shirts, and caps with emblem of the Navy as part of the display.
title: INS Kabra turns a crowd-puller

text:
Signalling a major drive to promote domestic production of vegetables, the government has embarked on a project to wean farmers off the influence of rapacious moneylenders and middlemen.

As a first step, the Kanthalloor-Vattavada region, the vegetable production hub in Idukki district, has been given access to banking services.

The Kerala Gramin Bank has opened a branch with ATM in Vattavada, responding to a long-pending demand of farmers in the border villages who were dependent on Tamil Nadu-based moneylenders. Agriculture Minister V.S. Sunil Kumar inaugurated the branch on Friday.

Monopoly of traders

An official press note issued here said the government had honoured its commitment to break the monopoly of traders across the border who procured vegetables from farmers at cheap rates, only to sell the produce in Kerala at inflated prices. The Gramin Bank, it said, had made arrangements to provide agricultural credit at low rate of interest.

The green card issued by the bank could also be used as a debit card or ATM card to withdraw money.

As many as 310 joint liability groups have been formed by farmers in Vattavada and Kanthalloor to avail themselves of credit and coordinate farming activities.

Incentives

The Minister also distributed incentives to farmer cooperatives in the Vattavada-Kanthalloor region for commercial cultivation of cool clime vegetables.

The government had announced a crop incentive of Rs.2 over and above the procurement price fixed by Horticorp and the Vegetable and Fruit Promotion Council, Keralam (VFPCK).

First of its kind

The press note said Rs.15.95 lakh would be given as incentive to vegetable farmers, the first of its kind in the country.

The project, it added, was aimed at eliminating middlemen and ensuring remunerative price for farmers in the two villages.
title: Banking comes to Vattavada

text:
The Bharatiya Janata Party is launching a Statewide campaign for water conservation in view of the drought situation.

The campaign titled Jalaswaraj will start on January 2 and continue up to the World Environment Day on June 5. As many as 18,000 booth-level committees of the party will take up various activities during the drive.

An official press note issued by the party said 10 lakh saplings would be planted on June 5. As many as 4.5 lakh volunteers would be trained to reach out to 78 lakh households. Vigilance committees would be set up to guard water sources. A total of 10 lakh rainwater harvesting pits and 1,000 check-dams would be constructed and 1,000 ponds cleaned up.

The campaign also involves soil and water conservation programmes, cleaning up of rivers, protection of forests and sacred groves, waste management, rainwater harvesting, and groundwater recharge. Technical committees will be set up to provide assistance in well recharging and watershed protection.

A website would be created for Jalaswaraj. Union Minister for Drinking Water and Rural Development Narendra Singh Thomar will inaugurate the campaign at Sasthamcotta on January 2.
title: BJP to launch water conservation drive

text:
The Cochin International Airport Limited (CIAL) has paid a dividend of Rs. 27.84 crore for 2015-16 to the government.

The demand draft was handed over to Chief Minister Pinarayi Vijayan, who is also the chairman of the company, at the Secretariat on Friday by Minister for Water Resources Mathew T. Thomas, who is also the Director of CIAL.

In 2015-16, CIAL had generated an income of Rs. 524.5 crore. The company had made a profit of Rs. 175.22 crore after tax during the period. Compared to the previous financial year, the CIAL net income had registered a growth of 26.71 per cent and 21.19 per cent in net profit.

The company is giving 25 per cent dividend to its investors. With this, the company had been able to give 178 per cent dividend of the total investment to its shareholders. The company has been giving dividend since 2003-04. As many as 18,200 persons from 36 countries have invested in CIAL. The State has 32.4 per cent equity in the CIAL. As many as 7,500 persons are working in the airport that began commercial flight operations in 1999.

In 2015-16, as many as 77.71 lakh persons travelled to various destinations through and from Nedumbaserry airport. CIAL has fourth place among the airports in the country when international travellers are taken into account and seventh place when total passengers are considered. The Rs. 1,100 crore new international terminal coming up will soon be commissioned.

CIAL Directors K. Roy Paul, A.K. Ramani, Additional Chief Secretary and CIAL MD V.J. Kurien, M.A. Yusuf Ali, N.V. George, E.M. Babu and Company Secretary Saji K. George were present when the DD was handed over.
title: CIAL pays Rs. 27.84-crore dividend

text:
Kerala Pradesh Congress Committee president V.M. Sudheeran has accused Prime Minister Narendra Modi of pushing the country into the hands of unscrupulous corporate entities and black-money hoarders.

Inaugurating a State-level Congress-party sponsored ‘public mock trial’ of the Narendra Modi government, Mr. Sudheeran said the Prime Minister had failed to deliver his promise during the 50-day period he had sought after demonetisation of high-value currency notes. A Prime Minister who could not fulfil his promise to the people should be prepared to resign from office. The currency curbs, which were continuing, had pushed the agricultural, industrial, and labour sector into doldrums and pushed the country backward by 20 years.

The Prime Minister, who had made a fool of himself through demonetisation, was now fooling the people. He had virtually overturned the economic freedom and lives of an entire population, besides causing the death of 150 people. The credibility of the banking system had been wrecked. The Prime Minister had adopted an authoritarian attitude by refusing to the hear the complaints of the Chief Ministers of various States, he said.

The ‘public trial’ was organised by the Congress Block Committees at the instance of the KPCC. DCC president Neyyatinkkara Sanal presided.

The ‘mock trial’ declared Prime Minister Modi ineligible to continue in office on the basis of the ‘deposition’ of six ‘witnesses.’

A panel led by the Communist Party of India (Marxist) [CPI(M)] on Friday emerged victorious in the elections to the governing council of the Kerala State Council for Child Welfare. Its nominees have won all positions in the council.

Former Syndicate member of the University of Kerala and Kadakampally service cooperative bank president S.P. Deepak has been elected general secretary of the council.

Office-bearers

Others elected include Azhikkodan Chandran (second vice-president), P.S. Bharathy (joint secretary), G. Radhakrishnan (treasurer), and O.M. Balakrishnan, A.K. Pashupathy, and R. Raju (executive committee members).

High Court directive

While the elections were held on July 16, the counting of votes had been put on hold on the basis of a Kerala High Court directive following the finding of financial irregularities and bogus memberships issued by the previous administration.

The votes were counted on Friday after the court permitted the process.

After the LDF government came to power, a probe revealed that 868 persons were given lifetime membership at a single go in violation of the rules.

A Crime Branch probe was also instituted into the alleged irregularities.

The election was conducted under the supervision of a returning officer appointed by the court.

The votes cast by those whose memberships were disputed were put in a separate box.

Plea turned down

According to Mr. Deepak, while a United Democratic Front (UDF)-Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) combine had moved the court seeking a stay order into the counting of votes, the plea was turned down.

The victorious panel was handed over authority by council administrator, who is the District Collector. A formal swearing-in will be held on January 3.
title: CPI(M) panel wins polls to child welfare council

The first waste-to-energy plant in Kerala generating electricity from garbage is set to come up at Sulthan Bathery under a public-private partnership.

Chairman of the Sulthan Bathery municipal corporation C.K. Sahadevan and CEO of Didask Bioenergy Private Ltd. Gladstone Philip signed a memorandum of understanding for the project here on Friday.

Minister for Local-Self Government K.T.Jaleel, who was present at the function, said the project would be replicated in other parts of the State if the pilot phase was found successful.

Based on German technology, the plant will be set up by Didask on 37 cents provided by the municipality. The company will charge Re.1 for processing each kg of waste collected by the local body from restaurants, hotels, and meat outlets.

The plant will have the capacity to process five tonnes of garbage every day, producing up to 1,200 units of electricity in the process. Didask will share the profit from the sale of electricity with the municipality for 15 years, after which the plant will be transferred to the local body.

On January 9

An official press note here said the construction of the plant would be inaugurated on January 9.

The Minister said another waste processing plant utilising Japanese technology would come up at Kochi soon, with the Indo-Japan Chamber of Commerce bearing the construction cost.

Mr.Jaleel added that the government had formulated a programme to establish at least one centralised waste processing plant in every district over the next two years.
