text:
Allari Naresh’s films come with small ambitions and no pretensions. A viewer knows what s/he’s in for, from parodies to refurbished comic tracks featuring a long list of comedians who cushion a feeble plot. Intlo Deyyam Nakem Bhayam marks the actor’s foray into horror comedies, adequately tailored to match his strengths. He reprises his typical underdog part, as he plays for a wedding band, chases a girl he spots at a temple and is later forced to be a sorcerer in a haunted mansion.

The laughs are frequent as the director sets up the premise. Shakalaka Shankar and his Jabardasth counterpart control the proceedings well. The laughs are spontaneous, but you can’t escape their crass undertones. Sample lines like ‘ padmasanam ante padma tho asanama ’. As long as director G. Nageswara Reddy is in familiar territory and sticks to the brand of comedy he’s known for, he does fine. It’s the horror comedy formula that he fails to crack.

The narrative flows smoothly as he keeps you guessing about the ghost’s past. When he does bring in the twist, all you witness is a formality waiting to be completed. An aggressive ghost with an unfulfilled wish, traversing one body to the other for her interests, sending intermittent danger signals to the male protagonist, is done to death. This film’s terrain feels like an adulterated mix of most horror comedies you’ve watched this year from Kalavathi and Nayaki to Ekkadiki Pothavu Chinnavada . A positive from the movie is its departure from rhyming one liners. Most of the few one liners are weaved into the story with some purpose. When it comes to parodies though, there’s no stopping the director. The actors’ reference lines are from Baahubali, Kabali, Janatha Garage and Nannaku Prematho . The one eliciting maximum laughs is when Allari Naresh utters Mohan Babu’s Pedarayudu lines, ‘The relationship between a wife and a husband...’

Most performances are loud and perfunctory. One sees Brahmanandam after long and he doesn’t disappoint. Drushyam girl Kruthika deserved better than this outing. It’s high time Allari Naresh moved beyond these templates.

- Srivathsan Nadadhur

Intlo Deyyam Nakem Bhayam

Cast: Allari Naresh, Kruthika, Rajendra Prasad

Director: G. Nageswara Reddy
title: Runs out of fuel soon

text:
We remember Sagar Chandra as a director who dished out a critically acclaimed film Ayyare . Appatlo Okadundevadu is the story of a cricketer, Railway Raju (Sri Vishnu), who has immense potential but is led into crime and also becomes a victim of circumstances. He is denied a place in the team because his sister and brother-in-law have naxal links. And his past of having killed an extortionist haunts him.

To make matters worse, an encounter specialist Imtiaz (Nara Rohith) is baying for his blood. Imtiaz has an axe to grind; his parents were killed by the naxals. Two factors lead us to watching the film — one, Nara Rohith’s recent choice of subjects and second, Sri Vishnu being known as a reasonably good actor. Sadly, the film fails to deliver on the promise.

The story is about Raju’s life, his passion for a sport, his girlfriend, his family which is eliminated and how he suddenly becomes rich and powerful. On the other hand, we see Imtiaz go downhill from being in control. Charges are filed against him and he is suspended.

The plot has a periodic rise and fall of characters, but that hardly moves the audience. The first half shows Rohith as the hero and in the second half, it is Sri Vishnu; but by the time the film ends, we couldn’t care less. It is such a farce to show Imtiaz letting Raju go scotfree just because he gets to know the former had once saved his sister. The entry of Rajeev Kanakala doesn’t impact the story. The story seldom deviates but what is conspicuous is the lack of strong casting. Sri Vishnu who has done noteworthy roles in his earlier films isn’t effective here; he is passive throughout the film. The climax scene where he meets his daughter is a terrible let down. Rohith tests the patience of the viewer through his expressions. Brahmaji is the only who impresses. The female actors are hardly noticeable. The narration moves at a snail’s pace and songs are totally unnecessary in a subject like this. Though the story appears honest at times, it falls steeply as it progresses.

- Y. Sunita Chowdhary

Appatlo Okadundevadu

Cast : Nara Rohith, Sri Vishnu

Music : Sai Karthik

Director : Sagar Chandra
title: Weak content and weaker characters mar the narrative

text:
Allocation of State-level employees of the erstwhile combined State between the two successor States of Andhra Pradesh and Telangana is almost done as the year 2016 draws to a close.

Of 57,167 employees in 153 units to be allocated between the two States, Government of India notified the final allocation for 151 units as recommended by the Kamalnathan State Advisory Committee.

Kamalanathan Committee whose tenure ends on December 31 also made its recommendation for three categories — Deputy Collectors and Special Grade Deputy Collectors; Deputy Superintendent of Police, and Additional SP and non cadre SP and the Excise Superintendents — however, these are stuck due to court cases.

These employees, numbering about 1,100, moved the court against their allocation without finalising their seniority first.

Sources said that the Kamalnathan Committee had allocated the deputy collectors with the approval of both the States but could not notify the tentative allocation because of Court stay.

In the case of DSP, Excise SPs, the tentative allocation has been notified but put on hold for further orders from the Court.

The committee is likely to be given another three month extension to complete the allocation of these categories of employees as well.

Speedy allocation

Compared to the three States that were reorganised (Uttar Pradesh, Bihar and Madhya Pradesh) where staff allocation took years, Andhra Pradesh combined State’s staff allocation was done in a remarkably short time of two years after the guidelines were approved by the GoI in October end of 2014.

The committee Chairman had sworn by consensus and transparency given the kind of regional preferences of the employees post bifurcation.

The staff allocation however has some sticking points that do not under the purview of the committee. For instance, last grade employees comprising attenders and drivers, among others, who were more in Telangana but sent to Andhra Pradesh under the allocation process desperately want to come back to their native State and urge the Chief Minister to keep his word.

The other category is the spouses of State-level employees working in public sector, local body and Central government institutions in one State and State-level employees allocated to another State.

Kamalnathan Committee recommended that the two State governments constitute a committee and evolve guidelines to address the concerns of last grade employees and spouse cases.

Last heard, the committee comprising officials from both the States approved the guidelines. While AP Chief Minister N Chandrababu Naidu apparently gave his consent, the file is pending with Telangana Chief Minister K. Chandrasekhar Rao.
title: Post-bifurcation staff allocation not yet over

text:
When all leads end up in cul-de-sac, even a vehicle number plate becomes a crucial clue.

Investigators are now trying to find out from whom the dacoits of Muthoot Finance’s Ramachandrapuram branch secured the number plate of the black Scorpio vehicle in which they fled. As one lead after the other in the sensational crime is failing to take them anywhere, police are reworking all their strategies.

Offenders normally abandon vehicles after reaching a place they feel safe or secure. “From that point, we stitch up clues and reach them. In this case, the vehicle is still eluding us,” a police officer associated with the investigation of the case said.

Hunt on for number plate maker

On the day Muthoot Finance was looted, police banked hopes on the vehicle number. It eventually turned out to be that of a two-wheeler. Apparently, the gang used fake vehicle number. “But surely they would not have made the number plate. So we’re trying to find out the vehicle number plate maker whom they would have contacted,” said the investigators. Admitting that it could be a shot in the dark, they pointed out that pursuing small or insignificant leads gave breakthroughs in several cases.

Ten special teams

More than 10 special teams are trying to reach the offenders through a different clue. They feel that no lead would further come from the vehicle’s trail angle. After Sedam in Karnataka, the Scorpio headed for Chittapur.

At a ‘T’ junction before Wadi, the Scorpio reportedly turned left to avoid Modgul toll gate. Police surmise the gang would have gone towards Wadi and Gulbarga or Bijapur side. After these points, no video footage of the Scorpio was available anywhere as there were no surveillance cameras on those routes.

First of its kind robbery

Investigators believe the modus operandi of one of the gang members posing as traffic policeman and others as CBI officials and thieves -- was recently adopted by the gang. In recent past, no dacoity or robbery in this fashion was committed.

While looting Muthoot Finance branch at Gulbarga, they drove in a white Scorpio and sped away after collecting jewellery at gunpoint. On learning that members of gangs, which committed similar offences, were arrested in Beed of Maharashtra, they showed the portraits of suspects in Ramachandrapuram case to the police there. However, the ones who were nabbed there have nothing to do with the crime.
title: Police reworking on ways to nab Muthoot Finance burglars

text:
A division bench of the Hyderabad High Court comprising Justice Nagarjuna Reddy and Justice M.S.K. Jaiswal directed the Legal Services Authorities of Andhra Pradesh and Telangana to investigate and find out how ineligible persons were getting the benefits of court fee exemption and the like, under the Legal Service Authority Act.

The bench said that these loopholes need to be plugged. It was dealing with a case filed by M/s. Navya Infracon Projects (I) Private Ltd. The petitioner said that some fishermen did not pay the court fee but their suits were numbered and proceeded. They got exemption from the District Legal Services Authority of Visakhapatnam to the tune of Rs. 18.5 lakh.

The bench asked authorities to examine whether these plaintiffs were really eligible for exemption and said that till the inquiry was over, the suits shall not proceed further. The bench said “it is needless to observe that the plaintiffs’ entitlement for payment of court fee by the Government depends upon the decision of the scrutinizing committee. Till a decision is taken by the Committee, the suit shall not be proceeded with”.

The bench further commented that before parting with this case, it would like to place on record certain ground realities.

“We have come across strong criticism of brazen misuse of benevolent provisions of the Act and the Regulations,” the bench observed.
title: HC for probe into court fee exemption

text:
Along with declaring the cashew hub, Mori, as ‘Digital Village,’ Chief Minister N. Chandrababu Naidu also launched a pilot project of collecting water tax through Mee Seva centres with the aim of simplifying the process for the farmers.

Developed by the East Godavari district administration, the project seeks to bridge the gap between the demand and collection of the tax revenue and curtail inordinate delay in transferring the tax to the Water Users’ Associations (WUAs).

Against the 4.25 lakh hectares of cultivable land in East Godavari district, 2.69 lakh hectares is being irrigated through canals, tanks and lifts. For the remaining 1.56 lakh hectares, farmers depend on sources such as groundwater. For the irrigated extent, the government collects water tax from the farmers through the Revenue Department and disburses the same to the WUAs for maintenance of canals. In the existing system, the VRO issues demand notices to the farmers and collects cash from them. The notices are issued twice a year for kharif and rabi. As per statistics, the tax collection is a mere 37 per cent in the district. As against the total demand of Rs.31.41 crore (including Rs.16.21 crore arrears), only Rs.11.61 crore has been collected so far. Of it, hardly 50 per cent reaches the WUAs, forcing the latter to postpone the canal development works. The lacuna in the collection and disbursement is attributed to insufficient staff in the rural pockets and the workload on the existing employees. “The new system envisages timely generation of demand notices online by the Collectorate itself. The duty of the village-level staff is just to serve the same on the farmers. Against remittance of the tax, the farmers will get valid receipt from the Mee Seva centre,” District Collector H. Arun Kumar told The Hindu .

The Chief Minister launched the project for Alamuru mandal in Rajamahendravaram revenue division from Mori village and evinced interest in replicating the project.

The district administration is making arrangements to expand the new system to the entire district within one month so that tax collection and disbursal will be streamlined.

“The demand notices can be mailed directly to the farmers in the near future, as the ongoing digital literacy campaigns enable the farmers to get access to personalised services on the Internet,” says the Collector.

Against remittance of tax at Mee Seva centre, farmers will get a valid receipt

H. Arun Kumar

District Collector
title: Collection of water tax from farmers made easy

text:
Chief Minister N. Chandrababu Naidu will launch the fourth phase of Janmabhoomi programme in Thadakanapalle village of Kallur mandal in the district on January 2.

District Collector Ch. Vijayamohan, Superintendent of Police A. Ravikrishna, and Joint Collector C. Harikiran visited the area and inspected the arrangements on Friday. Mr. Naidu will inaugurate Muchumarri Lift Irrigation scheme, which would facilitate release of water to about 30 lakh acres through the KC Canal, the Collector said.

He told District Panchayat Officer Anand to lay roads, construct drains, and clean up the area.

The Collector told Panchayat Raj SE Subbarayudu to shift the cattle in the village to the cattle sheds and arrange tree guards for saplings planted on a war-footing. He also directed the officials to clean up the area where Mr. Naidu would address a gram sabha near the Thadakanapalle tank.

He wanted the tank filled by releasing water from the Handri-Neeva project.

Mr. Vijayamohan told Transco SE Bhargava Ramudu to remove the high- tension power line and asked the R&B SE Srinivasa Reddy to construct a helipad.
title: Chief Minister to launch Janmabhoomi on Jan. 2

text:
Sporting masks of Prime Minister Narendra Modi, boy and girl students of Sri Hari Degree College in Kadapa town on Friday took a pledge to promote cashless transactions and Swachh Bharat initiative on the college premises.

In the programme organised by the Suvarna Bharathi Charitable Trust chairman V. Pratap Reddy, the students lauded demonetisation as the right move to curb corruption and said Mr. Modi took a bold step. BJYM district president Pavan, city secretary Lakshman Rao and students took part.
title: Students wear Modi masks, take pledge

text: Pamuleti, 35, an agricultural labourer, died allegedly of snake bite while working in an agricultural field in Thimmapuram village in Mahanandi mandal in Kurnool district on Friday. Pamuleti died while being rushed to hospital. He is survived by wife and two daughters.
title: Farm labourer dies of snake bite

text:
Tension prevailed when Telugu Desam Party and YSR Congress activists entered into a wordy duel and clashed with each other during leasing out of a shop built by the municipality at Yemmiganur in Kurnool district on Friday.

Municipal officials called for applications for leasing out a shop (No. B7) in the muncipal shopping complex. When two YSRC activists Rangaiah and Venkataramudu, went to the municipal office to file applications, TDP leader Paramesh obstructed them and maintained that the shop must be given to a ruling party sympathiser. As the rival groups had heated exchanges and clashed with each other, police rushed to the place and dispersed the groups. A couple of YSRC activists sustained injuries.
title: TDP, YSRC activists clash in Yemmiganur

text:
Sk. Rabeena, a resident of Leguntapadu village in Kovur mandal limits, was found murdered at her residence in the early hours of Friday. Her husband Sk. Kalesaheb allegedly attacked her and slit her throat following prolonged differences over domestic matters.

The police visited the spot and began investigation after registering a case.

The woman was stated to have received fatal knife injuries in her throat. They had two children.
title: Woman found murdered

text:
The Prakasam police will focus on tackling increasing cyber crime in 2017 anticipating exponential increase in the number of digital transactions, Superintendent of Police C.M. Trivikram Varma said on Saturday.

Expressing satisfaction over the efforts of the police to bring down major crimes bearing fruit during 2016, he told a press conference here that a cyber cell would be formed and training provided to the personnel at the sub-divisional level to check criminal activities carried out by means of computers or the Internet.

Stating that electronic surveillance had helped bring down crime rate across the district during this year, he said over a 1,000 CCTVs with GPS tracking system would be installed in different towns in the district during 2017. Already, 90 CCTVs were put in place in Ongole and eight other towns in the district to curb law and order violation, regulation of traffic and prevention and detection of crime, he added.

The pilot Finger Print Identification Networking System (FINS) helped screen over 3,000 suspects so far and nab 20 offenders, thanks to uploading of State-wide data, he said, adding that the Jail Release Monitoring System developed by the National Informatics Centre had helped the district keep track of convicts with the information provided by other districts to curb new offences.

The response time on complaints received through Instant Complaint Logging Internet Kiosks(I-Clik) had been reduced from the earlier seven days to three days. As many as 2,542 complaints were disposed of during 2016, he added.

The e-challans sent to 1.35 lakh motor vehicle offenders using android device had helped detect 34 stolen vehicles, he said.

The e-office launched in the district saw uploading of 186 files to all sections in the District Police Office and transfer of 56 files to the Collector's office digitally and going forward, the district police office would go paperless, he explained.

WhatsApp number

He wanted the public to share information relating to crime on WhatsApp through mobile no: 9440627199.

There had been a 6.98 per cent fall in crime in 2016 over the previous year with robberies decreasing by a maximum of 47.05 per cent. The number of fatal road accidents had declined by 7.04 per cent to 462, leaving 552 dead in 2016 as against 541 in 2015, he said, adding that Rs. 92.28 lakh had been collected as fine from violators of the Motor Vehicles Act.

Referring to trends in crime in a decade, he said crime against women had increased by 24.09 per cent to 955 incidents and crime against SCs and STs by 80.31 per cent to 229 incidents during 2016, while economic offences had come down by 29.09 per cent to 195 incidents compared to the offences in 2006.
title: Prakasam police to form cyber cell to tackle online crime

text:
The Andhra Pradesh Unaided School Managements' Association on Friday urged the State government to provide a hand-holding support to them so as to offer better education to students.

APUSM State president A. Krishna Reddy told a press conference here after its general body meeting that even as the student strength in the State-run educational institutions kept declining over a period, private schools provided quality education to students. Pressing for financial assistance to private schools, APUSM State general secretary G. Pullaih objected to the new fire safety regulations which made it mandatory for the schools to renew every year as against five years earlier. Stating that private schools were no commercial ventures, district president Hanumantha Rao wanted the power tariff to be reduced on a par with domestic connections.

Private schools should be taken into confidence when the State government took any policy decision, said district general secretary K. Madhava Rao.

Plea over recognition

They wanted the recognition given to private schools to be continued without any break for the schools that switched over from Telugu medium to English medium. The private schools should not be brought under the purview of the Right to Education Act and under no circumstances examinations for students postponed without consulting them, they added.
title: Private schools seek financial aid from govt.

text:
In a first of its kind initiative in the State, the Prakasam Zilla Parishad will turn its schools into income-generating centres by roping in differently-abled persons to sell stationery, snacks and other items, according to its chairman Edara Haribabu.

While the schools, many of which were struggling to maintain the campuses well, would get an additional income on a regular basis, the shops manned by differently-abled persons would help them earn a decent living as well, he told a press conference here on Friday.

The Zilla Parishad would arrange for loans to the tune of Rs. 3 lakh from appropriate finance corporations and support the ventures till they become viable.

Selection of beneficiaries

The selection of beneficiaries would be completed by the Mandal Parishad Development Officers in a fortnight. The economic ventures would be supervised by committees headed by the headmasters concerned.

Ready by June

All the proposed shops selling subsidised stationery, snacks and fancy goods would become fully functional by the new academic year, he added.
title: ZP schools to become income-generating centres

text:
The YSR Congress Party will hold a protest on the New Year’s Day to highlight the plight of farmers in the district. The party is opposed to restrictions on sale of paddy and other agricultural produce.

According to the party official spokesperson Yenni Dhanunjay, the government recently ordered farmers to obtain permission from revenue officials for sale of agri-products.

Former Minister and YSR Congress Party State general secretary Dharmana Prasada Rao asked the party leaders to participate in the protest instead of New Year celebrations.

He alleged that rural economy was disturbed at all stages due to the demonetisation policy and the government's new rules.
title: YSRC to stage protest on January 1

text:
Police trying to control those raising slogans against the proposed port during the public hearing at Kona village on Friday.K_N_ MURALI SANKAR

While fishermen and farmers expressed concern over their livelihood, managements of shrimp hatcheries were apprehensive about the adverse impact of environmental pollution on their units due to the proposed all-weather, deepwater, multipurpose seaport in Kona revenue village of Thondangi mandal, during the environmental public hearing conducted at the project site here on Friday.

The Kakinada SEZ Limited of the GMR group proposed to build the port in an extent of 1,879.51 acres with an expected outlay of Rs.2,041.92 crore.

Geographically, it spreads over 11 hamlets and two major panchayats located 35 km from Kakinada and comprises a population of 2.96 lakh. Most of them ekes out a livelihood from fishing, agriculture, and horticulture.

Sarpanches and MPTC members, and employees of the GMR group, besides beneficiaries of its NGO wing, welcomed the port proposal saying that it would help develop the region by generating employment.

On the other hand, fisherfolks and farmers, while being apprehensive about their livelihood, complained that the relief package announced by the promoters was insufficient.

The hearing was held amidst multi-level security put in place by the police, para-military forces, and private security personnel hired by the promoters.

Prohibitory orders were in force in the villages and hamlets to be affected for the last couple of weeks and preventive arrests of leaders of opposition parties were made at Kakinada to ensure smooth conduct of the procedure.

En route the venue, the police conducted vehicle checks and physical frisking of individuals at three levels and prevented the activists of the the Human Rights Forum and other rights groups from entering the venue. Even at the hearing, most of the general public complained that only those who aired positive views were allowed to speak.

They raised slogans against the proposed port many a times, prompting the police to intervene and regulate the crowds.

People such as Ambujalapu Lovaraju of Lakshmudupeta, A. Srinu and Srinivas of Butchiahpeta managed to get a chance to oppose the project citing livelihood concerns and environmental hazards.

President of the All India Hatcheries Association’s Kakinada chapter Ganni Venkateswara Rao said the existence of 200 hatcheries that hired one lakh people and with a registered annual turnover of Rs.1,500 crore would be in question if the port was allowed to be established.

Of the 44 participants, 40 welcomed the port proposal. The general public, however, branded them as “paid artistes.”

Collector H. Arun Kumar, who chaired the proceedings, said that a detailed report, along with the video footage of the hearing, would be sent to the Ministry of Environment and Forests for its consideration.

APPCB Environmental Engineer D. Ravindra Babu and Revenue Divisional Officer Visweswara Rao were present.

Opposition leaders

to visit Kona today

Meanwhile, leaders of opposition parties from East Godavari district decided to visit Kona on Saturday.

Though leaders of the Left parties, the YSR Congress, and the Congress decided to participate in the public hearing, the police took them into custody and sent them to various police stations. They were released only after completion of the public hearing.

Expressing resentment over the police action, activists of the CPI(M) staged a dharna in front of the Collectorate in Kakinada and raised slogans against the government for trying to “suppress” public agitation by using police force.
title: Stakeholders oppose deepwater port at Kona

text:
The sale of 2017 New Year diaries and calendars brought by the TTD has registered an overwhelming response from the devout community.

Of late there has been a growing demand for both the TTD diaries and calendars from the pilgrim fraternity. Sensing the vast potentiality of the market, the TTD had released the 2017 New Year diaries and calendars as early as in the first week of October. The main intention behind the early release was to avoid last minute scrambling.

According to statistics, the TTD as never before has printed about 32 lakh calendars and 10 lakh diaries (two lakh ordinary and 8 lakh deluxe) embossed with elegant designs and images of the presiding deity — Lord Venkateswara — to cater to the requirements of the public. For the first time also had relaxed the restrictions on the bulk sale of the diaries and calendars.

Further for the benefit of the devotees, the TTD has not only made the sale of calendars and diaries available at all its information centres in the country and metropolis like Delhi, Mumbai, Chennai, Bengaluru, Hyderabad and Vijayawada but also had set up electronic Point of Sale (POS) machines at all the selling centres to minimise the inconvenience of the devout in the aftermath of the demonetisation move.

According to TTD Public Relations Officer T. Ravi, more than 80 per cent of the diaries and 70 per cent of the calendars have been sold out and efforts are on to ‘zero’ the sales by the first week of January.

TTD PRO says over 80 p.c. of the diaries and 70 p.c

of the calendars have been sold
title: Sale of TTD New Year diaries and calendars evokes good response

text:
Red sanders smuggling in the Seshachalam forests declined in 2016, going by official statistics.

Thirty woodcutters were killed in exchange of fire between 2012 and 2015. The number of cases booked this year is 392, a sharp fall from 752 last year. The wood seized from smugglers and dumps is to the tune of 234 tonnes against 356 tonnes last year, and the number of vehicles seized is also down from 474 to 310.

Though the figures are impressive compared to the previous year, the bitter fact is that they are still far from satisfactory. The major stumbling blocks are connivance of forest/police staff, ageing field staff, absence of recruitment, inability to tap technology and local villagers’ support to woodcutters.

“Cooperation by insiders in department and ration supply by local people are major hurdles, but we are going ahead with confidence,” says M. Kantha Rao, Deputy Inspector General of Police, Red sanders Anti-Smuggling Task Force (RSASTF).

The department is collecting Call Detail Record (CDR) of all suspicious elements to identify the ‘black sheep’. The task force police station established this year registered 29 cases, seized 495 logs and 13 vehicles.

Greying workforce

The major impediment is the greying foresters, as the average age is 54 years. Sixty per cent of field staff are above 50 years of age and a whopping 47 per cent of posts remain vacant.

“No progress can be achieved unless these issues are addressed,” explains Deputy Conservator of Forest B.N.N. Murthy. The operational strength of the task force is a paltry 150 armed staff, while the forest staff strength in the red sanders area is just 350 men against the requirement of 1,500. The proposal to have more armed base camps for close surveillance remains on paper.

At present, cameras are present only in 15-18 locations in the porous forest. The mega plan to infuse technology has also suffered a setback, as the proposal to add 450 web-enabled CCTV cameras in 250 locations, the entry/exit points into forest, is also pending with the government.
title: Red sanders smuggling declines in Seshachalam

text:
Customers take a look at bouquets and baskets made of exotic flowers imported from Kenya and Holland, at a florist in Tirupati on Friday, ahead of the New Year’s eve.—Photo: K.V. POORNACHANDRA KUMARK_V_POORNACHANDRA_KUMAR

Currency crisis, loss of business, liquidity crunch and other words that became the ‘in’ thing in the economy after demonetisation gave way to celebration and bash ahead of the New Year festivities. With the New Year’s eve round the corner, star hotels, event managers, decorators, bakers and florists are having their hands full.

For the first time ever, exotic flowers imported from Europe and Africa have made their presence felt in the temple city. Cymbidium, Sunset safari, Protea bargibera, Banksia mix, Pincushion, Calla lilly, Ornithogalum, lisianthus (all from Holland), Ruscus, Alstromeria, Hypericum berry, Spider mum, steel grass, bear grass (all from Kenya) and Bird of Paradise (Thailand) are used to make eye-catching floral arrangements.

“Bouquets and baskets are available in the price range of Rs.100 to Rs. 5,000. The flow of walk-in customers is steady and surprisingly, nobody has ever asked us about a swiping machine,” says C.B.V. Saikumar Reddy of Blue Petals, a leading florist.

Meanwhile, star hotels are throwing up lavish dinners and musical nites. Comedy stars Chammak Chandra and Jabardast Ramu, who tickled the funny bone in ETV’s ‘Jabardast’ comedy show, will perform at Fortune Kences.

Similarly, Fortune Select Grand Ridge is holding New Year bash at its ball room, where the star line-up includes anchor Vindhya Visakha and singer Anjana Sowmya, while the ‘Rock n Roll show’ with DJ at its Neptune Bar is sure to add fizz to the show. The hotels are getting bookings for the night show.
title: Demonetisation fails to dampen New Year celebrations

text:
Passengers take selfies in front of the Tirupati-Visakhapatnam double-decker train ahead of its inaugural run at Tirupati railway station on Friday. —Photo: K.V.. Poornachandra KumarK_V_POORNACHANDRA_KUMAR

As the Train No.22708 Tirupati-Visakhapatnam Double-Decker AC Express chugged out of the railway station here on Friday after it was formally flagged off Railway Minister Suresh Prabhu and Chief Minister N. Chandrababu Naidu via remote video link from two different destinations, questions arose on its viability through consistent occupancy, which translates into profitability.

People have a genuine reason for delight as this train fills the void in the high-density traffic route between the two destinations linking the two ends of the new State, where the demand for new trains has always remained unsaturated. The second reason for delight is the fancy-looking fully air-conditioned rake with bright red and yellow colours and the elegant-looking interiors. More than that, the double decker seating facility is all set to increase the craze for travel.

But the dream to travel in a double-decker train is feared to be short-lived and hence may not yield repeat travellers. It may be recalled that similar double- decker trains in the Kacheguda - Tirupati and Kacheguda - Guntur routes were withdrawn for lack of patronage.

The absence of berths makes it look like a chair car and as such commuters might avoid opting it for long distance travel. With regard to the fare, passengers will have to cough up charges equivalent to third AC, though they do not get a berth.

The only silver lining is the high demand in the short distance and as such officials pin hope on the commuters in the Tirupati-Vijayawada and Vijayawada-Visakhapatnam sections.

It will be a second option for travellers who fail to get reservation in other trains. The railways also hope to attract those travelling by bus.

Questions arise on its viability. Officials hope for patronage from short distance travellers
title: Will the double-decker train prove to be a ‘double delight’?

text:
By remotely laying the foundation for the Nadikudi-Srikalahasti railway line from New Delhi on Friday, Railway Minister Suresh Prabhu set the stage for what K.C. Sivaramakrishnan, who headed the Expert Committee on Andhra Pradesh Capital, had described in his report as the “Kalahasti spine” that would “emerge as an important zone of development.”

The 309-km-long line was in fact sanctioned in 2011-12, but figured in the Railway Budget of 2014-15. It was estimated to cost approximately Rs.2,300 crore.

Mr. Sivaramakrishnan, whose mandate was to “study alternatives for the new capital of A.P,” identified ‘Nadikudi-Kalahasti spine’ (land situated along the proposed Nadikudi-Srikalahasti railway line) as one of the three sub-regions that are crucial for “distributed development” of A.P.

He had, in one of his articles published in The Hindu , observed that: “AP will become a better-knit geographic and economic entity if the Chief Minister concentrates on some of the very important projects, including those in which the Central Government’s support has been assured, such as the coastal corridor, a gas pipeline and its transmission to Rayalaseema, the Nadikudi-Srikalahasti railway line, and development of some of the railway lines east to west.”

Coming to the present, the Railways allocated Rs.110 crore for the project in 2015-16 and Rs.180 crore in 2016-17.

The new line takes off at Piduguralla station on the existing Secunderabad-Guntur rail route and connects to Venkatagiri station in Gudur-Srikalahasti section. It is recognised as a viable alternative to Kazipet-Vijayawada and Vijayawada-Gudur-Tirupati/Chennai grand trunk rail route. These routes will be de-congested upon completion of the new line, which will also serve as the shortest route between Guntur and Tirupati, besides improving connectivity from the remote areas of Guntur, Prakasam, and Nellore districts to Amaravati.

The new line, for which Railway Minister laid foundation remotely, will improve connectivity to Amaravati
title: Fillip to ‘Nadikudi-Kalahasti spine’

text:
City Police Commissioner D. Gautam Sawang has said that dances and unauthorised activities have been banned in hotels and restaurants during New Year celebrations, and warned that severe action would be taken against those violating the orders.

Conveying New Year greetings to the public, Mr. Sawang appealed to the citizens to celebrate the year end and welcome the new year with joy and happiness without causing inconvenience to the people.

The Commissioner said the establishments which planned to organise events in connection with the New Year celebrations have been requested to obtain permission from the police, and liquor shops should not do business beyond the stipulated time.

People have been are requested not to burst crackers on road, resort to eve-teasing, indulge in rash and drunk driving, and should not participate in drag racings. Parents are requested to keep a watch on the activities of their wards.

294 imprisoned

The Police Commissioner said 3,063 persons were booked on drunk and drive charges, of which 294 drivers were jailed and the court imposed fine on 2,769 persons.

The police will intensify patrolling and organise special drives at different points in the city on Saturday night to prevent drunken driving and road accidents. The police will book those who create nuisance at public places during the New Year celebrations, Mr. Sawang warned in a statement.

Traffic restrictions

Traffic police will impose restrictions on M.G Road (Bandar Road) from 6 p.m. on Saturday to 2 a.m, and vehicular traffic has been banned on the flyover near Police Control Room. Public may call ‘Dial 100’ in any emergency, the Commissioner said.
title: Police ban dances in hotels during New Year festivities

text:
DCP G. Pala Raju presenting the ATM thieves before the media in Vijayawada on Friday.

The Two Town Police arrested two thieves of a four-member gang, who committed thefts at Automated Teller Machines (ATMs) of many banks. They seized three mobile phones, 15 SIM cards, two ATM cards and other material from the accused.

Two other accused, Md. Basith and Dinesh, are absconding. Police are trying to find out whether any other persons are involved in the racket.

Disclosing this to the newsmen here on Friday, Deputy Commissioner of Police (Law and Order) G. Pala Raju said the suspects M. Ramesh Gandhi, a degree student of West Godavari district, and Sk. Srinivasulu of Kadapa district were habituated to horse racing and cricket betting.

The modus operandi of the accused is to move around ATMs, collect details of ATM cards of different banks while the customers are drawing the amount. They later used to draw the amount by using apps of different banks and wallets and transfer the amount into Basith and Dinesh’s accounts. Later, they shared the booty.

Ramesh Gandhi was earlier arrested by the Tirupati police, and Srinivasulu was apprehended by Gannavaram (Krishna district) and Kadapa police on similar charges and were released from jail.

The duo met at Pandit Nehru Bus Station and committed thefts. Following a complaint lodged by a person of Vijayawada, alleging that Rs. 20,000 was drawn from his account on December 13, without his knowledge, the team led by West Zone Assistant Commissioner of Police G. Rama Krishna investigated the case and busted the racket.

Cases have been registered against the accused under Information Technology Act and other sections. A hunt is on for the remaining accused, Mr. Pala Raju added.
title: Two held for stealing money from people’s accounts

text:
The Congress party has asked the Union government to make public the names of all persons, institutions and entities that deposited Rs. 25 lakh or more in bank accounts in the six months preceding the announcement of demonetisation on November 8.

Rajya Sabha member K.C. Ramamurthy, who has been appointed State coordinator for the party campaign to promote awareness on the full impact of demonetisation, told mediapersons here on Friday that the party was demanding that the Centre make public details of the process of consultation and preparedness that was followed prior to the implementation of demonetisation.

The government should tell the people why experts, economists or the RBI were not consulted before unleashing these “draconian” policies on the people.

He said the Centre should come out with a White Paper giving details about the amount of black money unearthed since November 8. Details of the economic loss to the nation on account of demonetisation and the number of jobs lost should be given, he said.

The government should also tell the people the number of lives lost in relation to demonetisation and its response to it.

He said the Congress was demanding immediate removal of all restriction on cash withdrawal. In case the restrictions could not be removed, a special interest of 18 per cent should be paid to the account holders. All charges on digital or online transactions should be removed immediately.

The party demanded that an income tax and sales tax rebate of 50 per cent be given to small shopkeepers and business, Mr. Ramamurthy said.

Karnataka MLC V.S. Ugrappa said that the fundamental rights of the people were being infringed upon by the Union Government through demonetisation. The State committee on the campaign against demonetisation met here on Friday, he said.
title: ‘Reveal big transactions done before Nov. 8’

text:
Students of Andhra Loyola Institute of Engineering and Technology participating in cultural programmes titled Ventura-2016 - 17, in Vijayawada on Friday.— PHOTO: V RAJUV_RAJU.

Besides academics, students should take active part in co-curricular activities, said P. Trimurthy, Chief Adviser, Andhra Pradesh State Skill Development Corporation (APSSDC).

He was addressing a function organised in connection with the valedictory of Ventura-2K16-2K17, a cultural fest at Fr. Devaiah auditorium on the premises of Andhra Loyola College (ALC) on Friday.

The event was put together by management, faculty and students of Andhra Loyola Institute of Engineering and Technology.

A cultural programme presented by students included mime, group dance, flower arrangement, singing competition and skit among other activities.

Cultural coordinator Fr. M.L. Thomas, Director Fr. Francis Xavier and Principal of the institute O. Mahesh were among others who participated.

Prizes were given to winners of different activities organised on the occasion.
title: Students told to expand horizons

text:
Ramesh Educational Society and M.L.N. Trust, in association with Ramesh Hospitals, Guntur, has announced financial assistance for expensive procedures like heart, liver and kidney transplantations, bypass surgeries, angiograms, angioplasty and other general and laparoscopic surgeries, knee joint, hip joint, paediatric heart surgeries and treatment of acute medical conditions.

This offer is open only to people belonging to low and middle income groups as “a new year gift”.

Ramesh Hospitals group chief operating officer P Gopi Krishna, in a press release here on Friday said that financial assistance would also be extended for expensive investigations like MRI and CT scans.

Families with annual income of less than Rs. 5 lakh would be extended 20 per cent discount and those with annual income of between Rs. 5 lakh and Rs. 10 lakh were eligible to 10 per cent discount on these procedures and investigations.

Those interested in further details could call 9705154399 or 7287000999, Mr. Gopi Krishna said.
title: New Year gift to low, middle income families

text:
It was surely ‘divine’ intervention. A few days after Yelda Yadhi Reddy purchased silver ornaments for the idols of the Muthylampadu Kodandarama temple, 500-rupee notes were scrapped.

“Lord Rama saved me,” he says. Reddy is by no standard a tax evader or a black money hoarder. On the contrary, he is a “temple beggar”. He has been seeking alms at the entrance of temples for the past one and half decades.

A homeless person, Reddy does not even have a bank account. The change he received from devotees he exchanged for notes of larger denomination and kept them with him. “If I did not give it away to the temple, all the money would have been worthless,” he said with his limited understanding.

Reddy shot into the limelight when he offered Rs. 1 lakh to the Muthylampadu Shirdi Saibaba temple less than a year ago.

Narrating the story of his 76-year-old life, Reddy said that he ran away from home in a hamlet near Posampadu village in Nalgonda district at the age of 10. He went to Hyderabad, but could not “adjust there and moved to Vijayawada”. He eked out a living as a rickshaw-puller for nearly four decades, and when his knees gave way, he was forced to beg. First he began begging outside the Kodandarama Temple, but was forced to move because not many people visited it. The number of devotees that came to the nearby Shirdi Saibaba Temple was large and they were generous. He got enough for his sustenance and could even save some money. Over 12 years, he collected Rs. 1 lakh. A severe bout of illness made him realise that he should give away to god the money that was with him, he claims.

The celebrity status gained after his donation to the Saibaba Temple increased his income. While it took over a decade to save his first lakh, he saved his second lakh in just seven to eight months. In accordance to his earlier decision, he bought two kg silver for making four crowns to the four deities. Including the making charges, the crowns cost him Rs 1.2 lakh.
title: ‘Temple beggar’ contributes his mite

text:
Keen on promoting the concept of cycling among public and to protect the environment from toxic gases, Capital Region Development Authority (CRDA), as part of its second formation day celebrations, organised a cycle rally from Indira Gandhi Municipal Stadium to its office at Lenin Centre here on Friday.

The employees of the CRDA, responsible for building the new capital, Amaravati, took up cycling to promote the activity in the new capital. The CRDA employees reached their office from the stadium passing through Benz Circle and M.G. Road.

CRDA Commissioner Cherukuri Sreedhar said that Amaravati would be a healthy and pollution-free city with employees using cycle as community transportation. He said that CRDA had tied up with the All India Bicycling Federation to promote the use of cycles in Amaravati. “The roads in Amaravati will have dedicated tracks for bicycles,” he added. The CRDA employees also organised blood donation camp at the CRDA office in association with the Indian Red Cross Society. CRDA additional commissioner V Ramamanohara Rao said many causalities in road accidents were due to non-availability of blood.

CRDA additional commissioner Dr A Mallikharjuna and other senior officers of the CRDA, employees participated in the programme.
title: CRDA takes out cycle rally

text:
A train engine went off the tracks at the railway yard here on Friday. However, no casualties were reported. The railway officials are tight-lipped over the incident.

According to sources in the railways, the engine went off the tracks during shunting and tilted on one side. The alert staff, who rushed to the spot, put the engine on the tracks and are investigating on the reasons for the incident. Three trains were delayed for some time following the incident, it was learnt.

The incident created panic among the South Central Railway (SCR) officials as the incident happened when Railway Minister Suresh Prabhu was inaugurating a slew of programmes online, along with Chief Minister N. Chandrababu Naidu, Union Civil Aviation Minister P. Ashok Gajapati Raju and other ministers and MPs at Railway Institute here.

“On knowing about the incident, we rushed to the yard and rectified the problem. The engineering, safety, signalling and other department officers were participating in the inauguration programme when the incident occurred,” said an SCR official.
title: Engine goes off tracks, sends railway officials into a tizzy

text:
Former Minister and TDP MLC Somireddy Chandramohan Reddy met Director-General of Police (DGP) N. Sambasiva Rao here on Friday seeking action against Sarvepalli MLA and YSR Congress Nellore district president Kakani Govardhan Reddy for allegedly making false allegations against him and his family.

The MLC in his complaint alleged that Mr. Govardhan Reddy created fake documents against him and accused him of amassing illegal assets, worth about Rs. 1,000 crore, in Singapore, Thailand, Malaysia, Kuala Lumpur and Hong Kong and was threatening his family.

“The MLA created fake documents by resorting to forgery and cyber crime. I met Chief Minister N. Chandrababu Naidu and explained the situation. The DGP assured to probe the documents purportedly obtained from different foreign banks,” Mr. Chandramohan Reddy told The Hindu .

The MLC lodged a complaint with the Nellore Rural police a couple of days ago, and sought action against the MLA for making baseless allegations against him.
title: Ex-Minister meets DGP, seeks action against MLA Kakani

text: Leaders of the National Alliance of People’s Movements (NAPM) from Andhra Pradesh and Telangana have joined their national counterparts in protest against the ‘arbitrary’ arrest of fact-finding team of Telangana Democratic Front (TDF) by the Chhattisgarh police. text:
Transport Minister Sidda Raghava Rao speaking at the annual review meeting of the Transport Department in Vijayawada on Friday.— Photo: Ch. Vijaya BhaskarCH_VIJAYA BHASKAR

The Transport Department will take steps to control fares in the APSRTC and private buses during Sankranti festival. Officials will hold discussions with the private bus operators in this regard in the first week of January, said Transport Minister Sidda Raghava Rao.

Participating in the annual review meeting with the Transport Department authorities here on Friday, the Minister said he would also speak to APSRTC Managing Director M. Malakondaiah and do justice to the commuters.

Speaking on illegal operations in the State, the Minister directed the Deputy Transport Commissioners (DTCs) and other officers to conduct surprise checks and book those who are operating buses illegally. He asked the officers to cooperate in generating revenue.

‘Conduct raids’

“Private buses should not act as cargo services. But, many buses are violating the rules and causing accidents by transporting inflammable material. DTCs should check the vehicles and book the violators,” the Minister said.

Reacting to corruption in the department, the Minister expressed concern over ACB traps and raids on some Transport Department officers and employees. Due to some tainted staff, the reputation of the department is getting damaged, the Minister said and asked the staff to be honest.

Unauthorised operations

As regards performance, the Minister said the department achieved 20 per cent growth and West Godavari, Anantapur and Kadapa districts stood top while Krishna, Kurnool and Vizianagaram were poor in the performance. Mr. Raghava Rao stressed the need on road safety to minimise accidents.

Asked about unauthorised operations of some stage carriers and the allegations of Telangana public representatives on private buses, Transport Commissioner N. Balasubramanyam clarified that all the private travel buses being operated from A.P. have permits. Two Orange buses which came from Telangana State were booked and prosecuted.

“Some private buses operating from other States are not visiting the States where they get registered during the origin and destination points and violating the rules. We will conduct raids on such operators,” said Mr. Balasubramanyam. Officers from all over the State participated in the review meeting.

Transport Minister

directs officials

to take action

against

illegal operators
title: Will control fares in RTC, private buses during Sankranti: Sidda

text:
GVMC Commissioner M. Hari Narayanan giving details of year round-up at a press conference in Visakhapatnam on Friday.— PHOTO: C.V. SUBRAHMANYAM

Standing fifth among 75 cities in the Swachh Bharat Survekshan and coming out with infrastructure for hosting major events including the International Fleet Review and BRICS summit were among the high points of 2016 for GVMC.

Having constructed nearly 13,000 individual toilets and 81 public and community toilets, the city was declared open defecation free.

With a view to meeting the parameters laid down in Solid Waste Management Rules 2016 it began collecting waste separated into wet and dry in 72 colonies of as many wards.

To ready the infrastructure particularly roads, pavements and greenery, about Rs.90 crore was spent ahead of the IFR.

Roads widened

In an effort to improve drains and safety, the national highway and roads were widened and all major drains improved and covered to prevent any accidents spending a total of Rs.22 crore. Recycling plastic and using it to substitute 7 per cent of bitumen roads are being laid.

“Gearing up successfully for a major event like IFR and emerging as one of the top cities in Swachh Bharat Survekshan are among the high points of 2016,” Municipal Commissioner M. Hari Narayanan told The Hindu .

“Giving top priority to improvement of infrastructure and sanitation, Rs.200 crore has been spent,” he said.

Garbage compactors for better and quicker transportation of garbage collected were acquired and road-sweeping machines hired. Dumper bins, steel bins and bobcat vehicles were acquired.

Giving priority to remediating the Kapuluppada dumpyard, efforts are on to bio-mine it and go for scientific landfill. On the health front, the dispensaries and urban health centres were converted into telemedicine facilities providing specialist services via video conferencing.

With its pioneering efforts in setting up ‘Saukaryam’ centres for tax payments and other civic services and online property tax payments, GVMC received the Digital India award from Union Minister for IT Ravi Shankar Prasad.

The flip side

On the flip side, BRTS still awaits full operationalisation. GVMC managed to maintain the water situation but resorting to pumping of water from the dead storage level from Yeleru reservoir, one of the major sources, for a long time.

Rs. 200 crore was spent on infrastructure and sanitation improvement during the year.

M. Hari Narayanan

Municipal Commissioner
title: Significant strides in cleanliness

text:
Even as the city goes into a celebration mode to herald New Year, the last few days have given anxious moments to event managers, hotels and business establishments with an overall drop in sales and a dull response to New Year’s eve events as an effect of demonetisation.

Queries are coming in for the event at The Park but a very few have materialised into real transactions. “Last year we hosted a crowd of 1,000 people. But the overall sentiments have been affected this time. Saturday will be a crucial day for us to see the final response,” said Sadiq Rizvi, the hotel’s food and beverage manager. The hotel, however, is planning its New Year’s eve party on the usual grand scale with the Reveillon Rio theme and the special highlight will be a laser show. For the first time Vizag will see a 24 watt laser show performance,” said Ajit Singh Garcha, the hotel’s general manager.

At The Gateway, preparations are in full swing to host ‘Samvatsara’ - the New Year’s eve party. But the underlying worry is palpable.

According to Kiran Bussari, general manager of The Gateway, the sale of passes this year has not been encouraging. “We are keeping our fingers crossed and gearing up for the big bash,” he added. This time, several mid-segment hotels are keeping the celebrations on a low key going by the overall gloomy market sentiments. One of the business hotels that earlier planned to host a party at Vizag Convention Madhurawada had to cancel the plan due to low patronage. Small and big business establishments echo a similar story. For wholesale flower vendors, New Year’s eve is one of the biggest revenue generating periods in the year. But this year, their sales have plummeted by over 80 per cent. “It has been the worst phase for us in the past decade. Last year same day, we sold flowers worth Rs. 40,000 on a single day. I somehow did a sale of Rs 7,000 on Friday. On Saturday, too, we are not that hopeful of making up for the loss,” said T. Gemini, a wholesale flower dealer who has kept a stall on the footpath near Dutt Island.

Streets decked up

While the city streets were decked up with cheerful lights to usher in 2017 on a positive note, for the hotels and business establishments the final ray of hope lies on how fast they can buck up on December 31 to wrap up an eventful year.
title: City gears up for New Year bash under demonetisation shadow

text:
Coordination between the police and other security agencies in the Left Wing Extremists (LWE)-affected states paved the way for major strikes against Maoists this year, said Rahul Dev Sharma, Superintendent of Police, Visakhapatnam, at the annual press conference here on Friday.

In 2015 there were nine incidents of exchange of fire, seven in Visakhapatanam and two in Odisha, and this year there were six such incidents of which four were in Visakhapatnam district and two in Odisha. But the number of Maoists killed in the exchanges of fire were 35 this year compared to just one in 2015, the SP pointed out.

Apart from the killing of 30 Maoists in major exchange of fire at Ramgarh in the cut-off area of Andhra- Odisha Border in one single strike, five others were neutralised during the year.

The Ramgarh encounter was a joint operation between the AP and Odisha police. While the strikes were made by the elite anti-Naxal force Greyhouds it was well coordinated by the Odisha police, including sharing of intelligence inputs.

The coordinated effort began after Home Minister Rajnath Singh held a meeting with the police and paramilitary top bosses in April this year in Visakhapatnam.

According to Mr. Rahul Dev Sharma, the 35 slain Maoists include three SZCMs (State Zonal Committee Members), 10 DCMs (Divisional Committee Members) and five ACMs (Area Committee Members). The Malkangiri-Koraput-Visakhapatnam-Border (MKVB) division and the East division suffered huge losses due to the strikes, he said.

Apart from exchanges of fire in 2016, sixty-one Maoists, including five cadres, 42 militia members and 14 sympathisers were arrested. The surrenders include 10 Maoist cadres and 23 militia members.

On the police side there was just one casualty and three civilians were killed by the Maoists during the year, said Mr. Rahul Dev Sharma.

Coming to other crimes there were three murders for gain, 48 murders, three cases of robbery, 20 cases of house breaking by day, 110 cases of house breaking by night and 28 cases of rioting.

Property offences

There were 314 property offences and of which 164 were detected. In crime against women, 348 cases were registered which include three dowry deaths, 14 cases of abetment of suicide, 131 cases of women harassment, 34 cases of rape and 134 cases of outrage of modesty. In 2015, the total number of cases was 318.
title: Coordinated effort resulted in major strikes, says SP

text:
The advances in the field of mobile communication technology can be leveraged to not only create awareness but also motivate patients, especially those in the rural areas, to keep lifestyle disorders at bay, opined Geetha Prasadini, Additional Director and State Programme Officer of National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Disease and Stroke (NPCDCS), Andhra Pradesh.

She launched m-Power Heart Project, a research project to test the effectiveness of an m-health technology-enabled trained nurse-led intervention, in presence of D. Prabhakaran, vice-president, policy and research, Public Health Foundation of India (PHFI), and M. Bhaskara Rao, co-investigator of the project, at a programme here on Friday.

Addressing the delegates, Dr. Geetha said that lifestyle diseases were being seen at an early age now-a-days. These Non-Communicable Diseases (NCDs) were now seen in the lower strata of society also.

Smart phones have literally invaded not only middle class but also homes of the poor, both in urban and rural areas, and the mobile health app brought out by PHFI could be gainfully employed to alert the patients to go for check-ups and also to use drugs from time-to-time.

Govt. initiatives

She briefed about various initiatives launched by the State government like Swastha Vaidya Vahini and Chandranna Sanchara Chikitsa programmes. Under the guidelines of the Government of India every patient, above 30 years of age, should be screened for lifestyle diseases, she added.

Dr. Prabhakaran said that the burden of cardio vascular diseases (CVDs) was high in India. Hypertension was the leading risk factors for CVDs but its control rate was very low. He felt that training Community Health Workers (CHWs) and nurse care coordinators to handle m-health technology would go a long way in the education and treatment of patients.

Quoting figures from a community-based survey conducted by PHFI in Visakhapatnam district, Dr. Bhaskara Rao said that the prevalence of hypertension was high both in urban (37.5 per cent) and rural (22.6 per cent) and attributed it to unhealthy diet, lack of physical activity, smoking, alcohol and stress.

PHFI Project Manager Nikhil SV outlined the features of the m-Power project and said that the user-friendly app could be accessed by patient both online and offline.

District Coordinator of Hospital Services BK Naik spoke.

District Medical and Health Officer J. Sarojini was present.
title: This app keeps you healthy

text:
A view of the VUDA Children’s Theatre in the city.— Photo: c.v. subrahmanyam

It has been an eventful year for VUDA with several of its projects, including the city central park and children arena, getting completed.

“Fifteen to 16 projects have started generating revenue and this has lifted the burden on VUDA. The criticism against it about projects continuing for long has been erased,” VUDA Vice-Chairman T. Baburao Naidu told The Hindu .

Among the other projects completed during the year were Buddhavanam, two shopping complexes at Sitammadhara and M.V.P. Colony, indoor stadium at Bheemunipatnam and Rao Gopalrao stadium at Anakapalle, improvement of greenery at airport before IFR and the park at Panduragapuram.

Mr. Baburao Naidu said auction of plots at Dakamarri joint venture layout pending for a long time was taken up during the year. Issues at Harita township were brought to its logical conclusion, he said.

Tourism

On the tourism front, VUDA took up total redevelopment of Padmapuram Gardens spread over 46 acres at Araku and developed tourism attractions at Matsyagedda in the Agency area spending Rs.42 lakh.

“I have taken personal interest in deciding the landscaping design for children’s arena and city central park,” Mr. Baburao Naidu said.

Though he would have liked work to start on the IT Tower, a joint venture of VUDA-STPI, it did not take off.

Though VUDA promised to allot housing plots at lower rates at the Dakamarri layout, the final process has not been completed with it awaiting government approval on some issues.
title: An eventful year for VUDA

Launching the smart city projects and getting underground drainage for Gajuwaka, Malkauram and Pendurti will be on top of the priority list of GVMC for the next year.

Outlining the priorities for 2017, Municipal Commissioner M. Hari Narayanan told a press conference here that detailed project reports (DPRs) for underground drainage in the three areas were being vetted by AP Urban Infrastructure Asset Management Company and would be taken forward during the coming year in coordination with the company.

The Command and Control Centre, modernising of schools and ‘complete street’ projects under smart city would also be grounded during the coming year, the Commissioner said.

For command and control centre, request for proposal had been floated and for modernisation of three schools, it would be initiated soon, the Commissioner said.

Necesssary action would be taken against those not using cellars for parking.

text:
The demonetisation move by Prime Minister Narendra Modi has made even the police rush to the respective banks on Friday to deposit the residue of old notes that were left with them. The demonetisation scheme was announced by the Prime Minister on November 8, and since then the police, both the city and the district, have been instructing all police stations to deposit the old notes in the denominations of Rs. 500 and Rs. 1000, which have been removed from circulation.

The deadline

December 30 was given as the deadline to deposit all old notes in banks, and in tune with that the police officials were seen rushing to the bank to clear the reserve on Friday. According to ADCP (administration) Venkateswara Rao, since the demonetisation was announced, the city police deposited old notes to the tune of Rs. 3.10 lakh, including Rs. 4 lakh on Friday.

Cash reserve

The cash reserve for the police is from the fines that they collect and seizures during raids.

In the case of the district police, since the network is far and wide, the police stations hold the reserve.

The SHO of each station was advised to deposit the cash by December 30, and it was done, said the Superintendent of Police Rahul Dev Sharma.

Though the exact figure is yet to be ascertained, it is estimated that about Rs. 50 lakh was deposited.

Except the FDR receipts and small change, all currency in the denominations of Rs. 500 and Rs. 1000 was deposited, said the SP.
title: Deposit of old notes: Police too make last-minute rush

text:
The Indian Naval Diving Team from the Eastern Naval Command (ENC) has recovered the body of a 25-year-old man, who drowned in the waterfalls at Sariya village of Jeenababu panchayat in Anantagiri mandal in the district.

Special team

The ENC headquarters sent a specialised team of divers to help in the search effort, as soon as it received a request from the District Collector on December 28 informing that a person drowned in the waterfall on December 21 and the rescue efforts by the locals were unsuccessful.

Intensive operation

The team undertook extensive diving operations for hours in the most hazardous conditions and successfully recovered the body. The deceased was identified as Nammi Lovaraju, son of Kanaka Raju. The body was handed over to the district administration for handing over it to the relatives.
title: Naval divers retrieve body of youth

text:
After overcoming challenges faced by it due to industrial slump during the year, Visakhapatnam Port is looking for sustaining its growth tempo and increasing its cargo significantly during the New Year.

“Our efforts on aggressive marketing, incentives offered in terms of levies and improvement in efficiency parameters as per recommendation of Boston Consulting Group (BCG) have paid off well,” Visakhapatnam Port Trust Deputy Chairman P.L. Haranadh told The Hindu .

The port handled 44.7 million tonne till December 25 and is expected to achieve 61 million tonne, the target set for 2016-17 compared to 57 million tonne handled last fiscal, an increase by four million tonne.

Till date, it handled a throughput of 3.3 million tonne over the corresponding period last year. By year-end, it is likely to go up to four million tonne.

“We have received a growth rate of eight per cent in cargo volume, which we will continue in the next fiscal also,” he said. The port was successful in putting a stop to dip in cargo, which was witnessed during the past three to four years.

The port received iron ore of 3.36 million tonne as on date last year which went up to 7.87 million tonne, an increase by 4.1 million tonne. This was due to revival of export agreement by the MMTC with the governments of Japan and South Korea.

Aggressive marketing

Admitting that the formation of Business Development Team to understand the customers’ requirements have led to adhering to world-class benchmarking, he said container traffic increased significantly from 3.5 million tonne to 4.75 million tonne during the calendar year.Other cargoes mainly gypsum, bauxite ore, petroleum coke and manganese ore increased from last year’s 6.9 to 8.4 million tonne.

Cargo handling and railway terminal charges were slashed by 50 per cent. In addition to this, the port is offering additional 50 per cent making it zero charge if the client achieved an incremental growth of 20 per cent.

Mr. Haranadh said as per the report prepared by the BCG under the initiative of VPT Chairman M.T. Krishna Babu, the pre-berthing detention time of ships had been cut from 1.7 day to 0.7 day and turnaround time from 4.2 days to 3.7 days. “Most of the delay in berthing is taking place due to documentation problem. If everything is ready, we are ready to berth a vessel in two hours as we believe that an hour saved is not mere statistics but it helps the clients to save crores of rupees.”

VPT Deputy Chairman says efforts on aggressive marketing, incentives offered in terms of levies and improvement in efficiency have paid off well
title: Pro-active measures put Visakhapatnam Port on a firm position

text:
Prime Minister Narendra Modi, after announcement of demonetisation, promised restoration of normalcy in 50 days, and went on to say that he would face any punishment given by people if he failed to do so. Since people continue to suffer, what kind of punishment Mr. Modi would like to face, AICC spokesman P.C. Chacko sought to know as the deadline expired on Friday.

Ninety-nine per cent of the people were suffering, 110 persons died while waiting in queues for withdrawing their own money from banks, and demonetisation proved to be a miserable failure, Mr. Chacko said at a press conference here.

He demanded that the Prime Minister lift all controls on withdrawal of money from banks.

Only 5.76 lakh crore out of 16.6 lakh crore currency notes (out of which Rs.500 and Rs.1,000 notes accounted for 14.6 lakh crore) had been replaced. “This means, two-thirds of notes are not in circulation,” he said.

The objectives Mr. Modi cited for demonetising high-value notes had not been achieved since the number of terrorists was on the rise and black money was not unearthed on a large scale. “This is because only six per cent of the wealth of black money holders is in cash,” he said

The plan to remove fake currency too failed going by the RBI statement that after demonetisation of 14.6 lakh crore currency notes, 14 lakh crore notes had been deposited in banks.

The Congress had taken up a campaign in support of the people who were suffering due to demonetisation, he said and added that the party would organise demonstrations in front of Collectorates in all districts on January 6 and the Mahila Congress would conduct protest programmes in all districts on January 9. An all-India convention would be held in Delhi on January 11.

APCC general secretary and former Government Whip Dronamraju Srinivasa Rao was present.
title: Demonetisation failed to serve purpose: Cong.

text:
Rise in road accidents, especially on the 80-km stretch from Visakhapatnam to Payakaraopeta, has become a worrying factor for the district police.

In 2015, out of a total of 303 fatal accidents there were 331 deaths and this year the number of fatal accidents went up to 335 resulting in 375 deaths. “This is the one area where we need to concentrate more,” said Rahul Dev Sharma, Superintendent of Police, Visakhapatnam,

“We have identified 28 black spots in this stretch and it is now up to all the stake holders such as police, NHAI and VUDA to come out with an action plan. The work has been initiated,” he said. According to him, the problematic area is Nakkapalli. The NH 16 practically cuts through the town and there is no service road on this stretch of the NH. Residents of the town just walk across the NH and directly drive into the NH from the intersection road, where there are no speed-breakers.
title: Rise in road accidents worries police

text:

In a minor accident, a contract worker suffered injuries on board INS Rajput, a Rajput class destroyer berthed at Naval Dockyard in Eastern Naval Command, here on Friday.

According to naval officials, the worker was doing some welding work at an elevated position when due to a flash of fire in the welding equipment he slipped and fell from the ladder. He suffered a fracture in one of the legs.

He was admitted to naval hospital for treatment and is said to be out of danger.

As precautionary measure the workers and staff were evacuated.

text:
Members at the Zilla Parishad general body meeting on Friday targeted officials, particularly those of the Civil Supplies Department, for their inaction on reported irregularities going on unhindered at the paddy procurement centres (PPC) in the district.

Soon after the meeting began, Peedika Rajanna Dora, MLA (Salur), pointed out irregularities at some of the centres in his constituency and sought to know the official action taken in this regard.

The claim of officials that 178 PPCs were opened to lift 4 lakh tonne of paddy was proved wrong after members of G.L. Puram and Bhogapuram ZPTCs complained to Chairperson Sobha Swati Rani and Collector Vivek Yadav that not a centre was opened in their respective mandals.

Moreover, some of the members have complained that allotment of PPCs to farmers was improper as they are forced to transport their produce to far off centres in other mandals for sale thus incurring heavy expenditure on transport and labour charges. In order to avoid hardships, the farmers were depending on middle men who were directly transporting paddy to rice mills, they alleged, adding, the officials at PPCs were “managing” to produce truck sheets for billing.

Collector seeks report

Reacting to the allegations, Collector Vivek Yadav asked the District Supply Officer (DSO) to visit the PPCs and also mills and submit a report for action if the millers stocked more than the allotted quota for milling.

The Collector asked ZP CEO Raja Kumari to probe the allegation of Komarada ZPTC member (YSRCP) that the MPDO locked her office room after she complained to the Collector seeking an inquiry into embezzlement of grants by him.

The meeting also discussed unfinished school buildings and other issues.
title: Civil Supplies officials pulled up for procurement ‘irregularities’

text:
There’s a long history of video games being made into films. We’ve had everything from Prince of Persia to Lara Croft, and more recently Warcraft .

However, the one thing they all have in common is their inability to recreate the magic of their original game series. Perhaps this was due to polarised views of the game developers and the actual filmmakers. In a welcome move, video game publisher Ubisoft’s film division, Ubisoft Motion Pictures, decided to enter the arena with the live-action feature Assassin’s Creed . Based on the eponymous game, the film is the first time a publisher is involved in the making of a video game film. Naturally, expectations were high, especially when stars such as Michael Fassbender and Marion Cotillard were announced as leads.

Not living up to legacy

Unfortunately, the film has done little to take forward the game series’ legacy. Instead of having the game’s actual protagonist Desmond Miles in the film, Ubisoft sought to create an entirely new character named Callum Lynch (Fassbender) to tell the audience of the conflict between the Knights Templar and the Assassin’s Creed. For centuries, a group of assassins has been protecting the Apple of Eden, which contains the DNA to free will. In present day, Lynch — a descendent of Aguilar de Nerha, a member of a secret order of assassins — is a death row convict. He escapes execution thanks to Abstergo Industries, the modern-day embodiment of the Templar Order. The company has developed a machine, the Animus, which uses Lynch to access Aguilar’s memories to find the Apple of Eden. The machine transports Lynch into the body of Aguilar and his world.

The premise of the film is pretty much the same as the game. Its execution, however, lacks the finesse, intrigue and excitement the series is renowned for. Indeed, the plot is perhaps too complex to be reimagined within the span of a couple of hours. The characters arcs are too complicated, often left unexplained. For instance, Aguilar’s lover and partner Maria (Ariane Labed) is barely introduced. She just pops up, and a kiss shared between the two is a moment of realisation for the audience.

Then there’s the recreation of the Assassin’s Creed universe — which includes the world of the Spanish Inquisition — where director Justin Kurzel (famous for his previous collaboration with Cotillard and Fassbender in 2015’s Macbeth ) makes a few amateur mistakes.

For one, his constant back and forth between present-day Lynch (in the Animus macine) and his embodiment of Aguilar is very jarring. We don’t get to enjoy the old-world combat sequences that make the game thrilling. And when we return to Lynch strapped into the Animus, we’re yearning to return to Aguilar’s world.

With barely enough time to explain the plot, Kurzel in the end resorts to oversimplifying the principles that the game is much loved for . For instance, rather than explain what the game’s famous Leap of Faith manoeuvre, the director has Abstergo Industries’s head scientist Sophia Rikkin (an absolutely wasted Cotillard) merely mouth the words.

There’s plenty wrong with Assassin’s Creed and very little that’s right. Fans of the game will perhaps be happy with the recreation of their favourite characters on the big screen. But that’s about it. The uninitiated, though, will walk away confused. You’ve been warned.

- Deborah Cornelious

Assassin’s Creed

Director: Justin Kurzel

Starring: Michael Fassbender, Marion Cotillard, Jeremy Irons, Brendan Gleeson, Charlotte Rampling and Michael K. Williams.

Runtime: 116 mins
title: This game should have stayed put
