text:
Having made my first trip to China this year, my friends and family had expected me to visit Beijing, The Great Wall or the Forbidden City. Not having gone to any of these places, the question on everyone’s mind was “so what else is there to see in China?” Well, it was a whole different world out there, from giant pandas to UNESCO World Heritage Sites like the Jiuzhaigou National Park, which is a 72,000-hectare biosphere reserve, and Huanglong, which is the world-famous travertine landscape to the highest railway line in the world.

The best experience for me was travelling on the Qinghai Railway (Qinghai, pronounced as Chinghai, is a high-altitude Tibetan plateau). This railway line was built to connect the Tibetan city of Lhasa to China’s vast rail network. The journey of 1,956 km is covered in 21 hours. Though spread across various elevations, the Tanggula railway station, at an elevation of 5,068 m (16,627 feet), makes it the highest railway station in the world. We crossed 675 bridges through 10 tunnels and 44 stations before reaching our destination at Xining. Another significant fact about the line is that 550 km of it is laid on permafrost (rock or soil that’s solid icy during winter but mushy in summer).

We boarded the train in Lhasa, Tibet, where the train arrived 45 minutes prior to departure. As I entered the carriage, it seemed like just another first-class Indian train compartment. The corridor of the compartment is lined with foldable seats to let travellers get a better view from the windows. Small oxygen vents are placed at every few feet on the corridor to maintain the level of oxygen inside the train that’s moving at such a high elevation. The air at these altitudes is much thinner, with the oxygen level being 40 to 50 per cent lower than that at sea level. Just visiting the plateau can make people pass out; hard physical activity at these heights can even prove fatal. We learnt that a major part of the construction from Lhasa to Golmud (1,142 km) was completed in five years.

As the train passed along the plateau, I was thrilled to see the beauty outside while sitting in the comfort of my warm cabin. We spotted a number of yaks grazing on what looked like snow-covered grass, the rare Tibetan antelope, a few wild asses and many snow-capped mountains. We passed by the beautiful and magnificent Cona Lake, which is sprawled over 409 square metres. Such flat sites at a height averaging 4,500 meters explained why the Tibetan plateau is often referred to as the ‘Roof of the world’. The only disappointment during the trip was not being able to catch a glimpse of the Tanggula railway station (the highest station in the word). The train does not stop at this station. We were eagerly waiting to take snaps of the station when the train passed by it, but unfortunately, found a goods train blocking our view. All the passengers sighed in disappointment.

Some pointers for those who intend to try this 21-hour experience:

lPack light. There isn’t much space to accommodate big suitcases in the compact coupe.

lCarry binoculars and a good camera with telephoto lens.

lIf you’re a vegetarian, carry instant noodles or ready-to-eat Indian food, as hot water is available on the train.

lCarry sachets of coffee, tea and milk powder, as only yak milk is available. You can try yak yoghurt that tastes almost similar to cow’s milk yoghurt, except it is much sweeter.

lAvoid buying oxygen cans or oxygenated water, as there are plenty of oxygen outlets on the train, even in the coupes. Each couple gets four oxygen outlets; oxygen tubes are available on request.

The oxygen level at these altitudes is 40 to 50 per cent lower than it is at sea level
title: Somewhere over the rail line

text:
“What are you doing on New Year’s Eve?” Admit it, there’s too much pressure when that question is asked. Especially when it’s almost D-Day and you still haven’t a clue. While it’s perfectly all right to stay home and watch TV or go out for a quiet meal, there are those for whom ringing in the new year is all about loud music, partying and dancing the night away. For them, the options are plenty. But now, with everything being about trying out new adventures, there are quite a few who want a more exclusive experience. For them, we list the five most luxurious ways of celebrating the new year in Chennai.

Turn to page 8

From page 1

Fitfor a king

How about booking the most expensive room in the city? Sounds great, but here’s a word of advice: You may need to save up for it. For example, the presidential suite at The Leela Palace, one of the most expensive rooms in the city, is all yours for Rs. 2,50,000 for a night.

Yes, we don’t blame you if you thought it was the rate for a month.

And along with that hefty price tag come opulence and luxury. The room measures 4,842 sq. ft., and includes a master bedroom, a washroom with Jacuzzi, a second bedroom, a living room where you can entertain your guests with perhaps a bottle of Moet & Chandon from one of the three mini bars, before the party moves to the personal dining area for 10.

And if you feel too stuffed after the party, feel free to use your private gym or pop over to your personal spa to get rid of those wine cramps.

Silver chairs, mother of pearl coating, silk robes and the scent of exotic flowers add to the luxe experience.

Sail to a new beginning

San Francisco, Dubai, Maldives... they’re all big on yacht parties. Some yachts are big enough to have vintage-themed balls and masquerade dances. Sounds intriguing? There’s no reason why you shouldn’t try it out as well. Chennai’s blue sea has more than just catamarans and speed boats bobbing about.

Quite a few companies rent out yachts for get-togethers or a quiet rendezvous. Usher in your new year glamorously, lounging on one of these yachts in the Bay of Bengal, with the silver moon and crashing waves for company, and a bottle of bubbly. Abhishek Roy, who runs Blue Mile, says he’s already received bookings for New Year’s Eve and the first of January. Shortly, he plans to start renting out his yacht for overnight stays as well. Prices vary and usually begin at about Rs. 10,000.

Pamper your senses

The perfect way to welcome the new year is by treating yourself to a relaxing day at the spa. And while you’re at it, might as well make it a royal experience. Why not try the Royal Bliss Package (priced at Rs. 10,000 plus taxes) at Kaya Kalp at ITC Grand Chola then? One of the most expensive spa treatments in town, the 150-minute session promises to leave you feeling rejuvenated. With an ayurvedic exfoliation, a Kaya Kalp massage and a deep cleaning facial, this spa treatment is for hotel guests and members only.

The guest is welcomed with a special drink made with ginger, lemon and basil leaf, before the signature treatment begins with a luxury foot ritual with rose petals, a sea salt scrub and an ayurvedic red sandal scrub to squeeze out dead skin. This is followed by the Kaya Kalp massage and a deep cleaning facial. And by the time you’re done being pampered, there’s some refreshment and herbal tea to look forward to.

Now that’s a day well spent.

Royal repast

Why must your celebrations end with New Year’s Eve? Let the party continue on January 1 as well, as you take your loved one for a romantic dinner overlooking the Bay of Bengal at Vivanta by Taj – Fisherman’s Cove. Called Watch Tower Dining, the meal can be arranged only upon prior reservation. According to the hotel, the Watch Tower redefines intimacy with a captivating experience on the white sands. The experience begins the moment the guest arrives at the hotel, and is met by a charming cart to be driven to the venue. A personal butler receives you with a welcome drink and shell garlands, before helping you get comfortable in the machan overlooking the bay. What follows is an exclusive four-course meal, customised for you by the chef. It’s the perfect way to get away from the maddening crowds and revel in your very own private nook. The Watch Tower dinner is priced at Rs. 30,000 plus taxes, excluding beverages.

Arrive in style

If you’ve got luxury on your mind this New Year’s, how can your ride be any less? But that certainly doesn’t mean you have to burn a hole in your pocket trying to buy a fancy set of wheels. With luxury car rental services like Luxury8 and Eco Rent A Car, your options are pretty varied. According to P.N. Ranbir, manager sales at Luxury8, one of the most expensive cars in their stable is the Jaguar XJL. “It’s the top-end model and is priced at Rs. 1 crore 80 lakh.” But you can zip around town on this set of wheels for about Rs. 25,000 for eight hours or 80 kilometres, and with a chauffeur to boot. The car has already been booked for New Year’s, according to Ranbir. And if you’re looking to rent it for outstation travel, Ranbir says it can be arranged at a price of Rs. 250 per km.
title: Ring in the new

text:
’Tis the season for not just joy but for horror too. But wait, there are some laughs as well.

We’re talking about Mo , the Tamil film that hits screens this week. Directed by debutant Bhuvan Nullan, this film falls under the horror-comedy genre, one that has proved to be successful for Kollywood for a while now.

The teaser of the film, which released in November, established the genre. It opens with Nagesh and Balaiah in that epic ‘horror film’ scene in the 1964 flick Kadhalikka Neramillai and intersperses that interestingly with scenes from Mo .

“That was the plan for the teaser from the time I started work on this project,” smiles Bhuvan, a mechanical engineering graduate, who was smitten by filmmaking, “That scene is epic for anyone who has followed Tamil cinema. Every horror filmmaker relates to that. I knew that juxtaposing that with my scenes will work in favour of my film.”

Apart from popular actors, like Aishwarya Rajesh, Suresh Ravi, Yogi Babu, Mime Gopi and Darbuka Siva, that he’s roped in, Bhuvan believes that the content itself would attract audiences. “I know that there have been many horror-comedies in the recent past, but I firmly believe that Mo will stand out,” says Bhuvan, who had earlier assisted Selva of Naan Avan Illai fame and directed a few short films before bagging his first feature.

That conviction stems from the fact that the ‘pei’ factor in the film is more fun than fear. “In every horror film, the ghost usually has a back story — about how it came into being — and why it takes revenge on someone. Here, the reason is quite silly… but a lot of fun,” he says, giving us a sneak peek into the film’s story.

The team parked itself in a school in Sriperumbudur for a couple of weeks (“that’s where 60 per cent of the shoot got done”) and wrapped up the entire film in a month.

“The location plays a vital factor in a script like this,” explains the filmmaker.

S.R.

‘Was scared during shoot’

She plays a ghost herself in the film, but Aishwarya Rajesh was actually scared out of her wits during the shoot of Mo . “The general perception is that while watching horror films is scary, shooting for them is fun. However, that wasn’t exactly the case with this film. We shot in a school that has been shut for many years now, and we mostly shot at night. So, despite donning the role of a ghost, I was quite scared when I heard weird sounds,” says the actor, who is a big fan of English films like The Conjuring and Lights Out .

The location plays a vital role in a horror film — we shot extensively in a school in Sriperumbudur

Bhuvan Nullan
title: The funny ghost

text:
Hello fellow-earthlings, we did it! We went around the sun one more time. What I don’t understand is, why are we celebrating it as if it is some sort of an achievement by us humans. Clearly, we didn’t have a choice no? Gravity held us here and so we stayed. Otherwise, Chennai folks would have drifted off to another planet and put their kids into a ‘strict’ engineering college in Jupiter or some such. That would’ve been a real achievement.

But I digress. I wanted to talk about celebrating New Year’s. Or more specifically, about New Year’s Eve parties. Now, if you were raised in Chennai, there is only one way of celebrating New Year’s. You don’t. Boss, who in their right mind spends money to usher in the New Year yaar! I understand that we have all been told people are supposed to do ‘cool’ things. Like sliding chest-down along a table like Kamal Haasan, screaming ‘Hi everybodyyy’ in S.P. Balasubrahmanyam’s voice, but you only ended up crashing on your younger sibling sitting on the other side of the table, thereby earning a thunderous thud on your back by one of your parents. Not the ideal way to welcome a New Year.

Or trying to be like the ‘cool’ kids in the movie Anjali , who wear sneakers inside the house, sneak out of their apartments in the middle of the night and go around the city singing songs with strangers. Boss, which Chennai kid could go out and do such a thing I just cannot imagine! I tried doing that once (it was not even New Year’s Eve and it was not even midnight) and yet I was caught in the act before even moving out of the bed, for I was sleeping next to my grandmother, who slept with her eyes open. In the days before technology, my grandmother was a CCTV camera, GPS monitoring system and voice-based alarm mechanism all rolled into one.

So on December 31, at best, our apartment residents association would put up a ‘variety show’ and distribute potato chips and Rasna. So much for ‘partying’. A few years later, while in college, there were rumours about how my friend’s friend’s cousin’s neighbours were part of this ‘awesome’ New Year party, and how they all counted down and rang in the New Year in great style. Interestingly, no one you knew directly ever went to these parties. There was also this ‘cool gang’ that boasted of having gone to Goa to party all the way through New Year’s Eve. There were also terms such as ‘farm house parties’, ‘beach house parties’ thrown at us poor kids, who didn’t even understand what they meant. It was all a grand mystery, and yet I badly wanted to be a part of it.

While all my parents wanted was a simple university rank and a gold medal out of me, all I wanted was to get invited to at least one New Year party. It was around this age when the newspapers were also full of advertisements with captions such as ‘New Year Bash’ or ‘New Year Gala’. Entry for such parties was priced slightly less than the going rate for a kidney or a liver, which unfortunately were already pledged for my engineering education. It became my life’s goal to attend at least one New Year party.

Now, many years later, even though I earn enough to afford an occasional litre of petrol, the mysterious New Year party continues to elude me. A few days back, I came across another ad that said ‘New Year’s eve midnight dinner buffet’ and my first thought was, ‘Who in their right mind eats dinner buffet at midnight?’ A few seconds later, my second thought was ‘OK, I have to go to this buffet now’. I decided to splurge and called up the fine-dining restaurant to reserve a table for two. The manager promised me a table at 10 p.m. sharp on December 31, 2018. I laughingly appreciated his sense of humour, to which he replied, with the seriousness of a cardiac-surgeon, that their restaurant was booked for the next two years.

What?! Who are these strange human beings who reserve dinner tables two years in advance? I politely cancelled my reservation and decided to try other places for mediocre mass-cooked food and diluted drinks at hyper-inflated prices. I received a similar response everywhere. People had already signed up to spend unnecessary amounts of money, thereby denying me the chance to do the same.

So, I am waiting as the earth begins one more revolution around the sun. Hopefully, next year, I will be invited to a ‘New Year Gala Bash.’ And while we wait for another 365 days, here’s wishing everyone a great laughter-filled 2017.

The Local Tea Party is a popular blogger from Chennai, known for his quirky prose. He prefers to be known by his handle (@localteaparty ).

Entry for such parties was priced slightly less than the going rate for a kidney or a liver
title: Why party on New Year’s?

text:
quirky gearActors Sundeep Kishan, Rashi Khanna, Varun Tej, Lavanya Tripathi and Nani show the way with funky party gear at a recent do; LED accessories

Almost everyone wants to ring in the New Year with a little do. And what’s the fun of it without much ado? So, while midnight is still distant, let’s run a quick check on what we need to do for a fun party.

Keep it colourful : More often than not, everyone wants a break from the routine on the first day of the year. No one likes the idea of a heap of dishes waiting to be done, so go disposable and opt for colourful pint glasses, shot tubes, shooters and even Martini glasses.

While at it, look for a dip platter and dinner plates that are unbreakable. Want to look fantastically upbeat with the décor? Then go for the glow glasses.

Dress right : House parties are the coolest because one need not worry much the dress code.

Just be dressed for the occasion. Keep it fun, keep it whacky. Get the Afro wigs; they may not be new but they are still going strong on the trendsetting charts. The coloured Afros are the most popular, but plain ones also add to a new look.

Hair bands : You can be Minnie Mouse, Rudolph, an angel or a stylish devil. LED-lit hair bands are the easiest party gear to grab to make a style statement.

The battery-operated LED light glows and makes a pretty picture in the dark. With the boomerang app you sure can earn a few hundred likes with these. Bunny ears are also never out of fashion to look silly and fun.

Glow jewellery: Want to look like a glow worm? Forget make-up and make-up glitter.

Instead, opt for glow jewellery like ear rings, rings and necklaces. You are sure to make heads turn with them.

LED frames: Wear the hearts that glow or frames that have LED straws through the frame. The streaming light makes a party fashion statement without disturbing the view. Some frames also come with faces of cartoon characters, but they are probably best suited for a Halloween party.

LED straws : Keep them scattered around the place of party.

The coloured sticks will glow and add decent light around the area without having to think of altering the lights around the house. When the night is meant to be danced away, no one wants to be under bright lights.

Whistle it in: Finally when the clock strikes 12, no one complains of the noise. So go ahead, keep the horns and whistles ready and ring in 2017 with a bang.
title: Go ahead, have a blast

text:
If you haven’t hopped on to the velvet train yet, tonight’s your chance. Those flirty ruffles in shirts and balloon sleeves aren’t the only outcome of the global Victorian fashion obsession we’ve been experiencing all season. Fashion critics say the luxe fabric will star at all New Year’s Eve parties that matter, on both men and women. “This time of the year, expect OTT. Look for voluminous sleeves, ‘80s details and a lot of bling. Fortunately, the makeup is toned down, with just a strong mouth or brow. And the hair stays natural with a messy pulled-back look,” begins Krishna Mukhi, stylist and former Fashion Features Director atHarper’s Bazaar India.

Here’s breaking down the dress code for the night ahead:

Velvet reloaded: Metal and velvet — you could do either one or both. High-octane glamour from Balmain, Gucci and Givenchy make the cut this season, but if you are partial to Indian designers, Huemn, the inventive Rajesh Pratap Singh and Atsu are the labels to hunt down. “Huemn did ‘80s nostalgia very well at fashion weeks this year, with distinctive fur accents,” continues Krishna. At the online fashion address, Pernia’s Pop-Up Shop, the label’s black-and-gold cutdana embroidered gown, at Rs. 65,500, is a keeper. Meanwhile, the store’s founder, Pernia Qureshi, also votes for Atsu’s panelled, lace-up and one-shoulder wrap dresses in black. “Atsu’s clothes are feminine and chic and they fit like a glove. Both he and Shivan & Narresh did their best collection at Lakme this year,” she insists. Her website has had many takers for Shivan & Narresh’s palazzos with gold skein work.

Berry fantastic: Blackest blackcurrant it is. Deep, dark and dramatic hues were undeniably the biggest trend for lips this season, and Krishna references the berry-like mouths on show at Rodarte, Marni and Erdem. “Many of our Indian designers did it too, but the most striking of all were the lacquered black-cherry pouts at Louis Vuitton and Dior, the latter created with Dior’s Rouge Dior in Poison coated with Dior Addict Ultra Gloss for a mirror finish. My personal favourite, though, is MAC’s Cyber,” she adds.

For the eyes, glitter and metallic updates are inevitable in the corner of the eye or near the cheekbones, but we’re betting on the berry eye (wine shades) seen on Emanuel Ungaro’s models at Paris Fashion Week earlier this year.

Boots on board: You can’t take thigh-high boots and slits out of the party circuit, but chunky platforms and strappy feminine sandals are definitely in. “If you plan to go partying in flats, they must have an element of glamour, with jewelled or faux leather detail. There is baroque too, toned down,” says Krishna, pulling out images of velvet loafers from Miu Miu.

Instant shine : For pocket-friendly last-minute purchases, like Bansri’s body harness or Outhouse’s chokers, try Pernia’s Pop-Up Shop and multi-designer stores like Amethyst and Evoluzione.

Men’s style

Jacket check : “Carry the right attitude. This is the best accessory any man can ever possess!” is sartorial savant Rohit Bal’s blunt advice to our party-ready man. Some cajoling later, “It depends on what kind of party it is. I would suggested fitted and flared anarkali shapes under a sherwani or a long jacket for an occasion. A well-fitted leather jacket made to your size is a must-have. You can carry it off in a number of ways.” Another winner, Huemn’s bomber jackets from Amazon India Fashion Week in October.

The custom suit : Borrow a few pointers on dressing sharp from Mumbai’s suit expert, Troy Costa – everyone from actor Aamir Khan to Randeep Hooda is a fan. Someone else who swears by the “best to be overdressed rather than underdressed” rule is Abhishek Paatni, the only new-age designer invited to showcase at GQ ’s Fashion Nights this month. “A custom peak lapel velvet blazer with a cotton shirt and pants would be my party look. To accessorise, throw in a lapel pin and a square. A nice pair of Oxford shoes in patent leather will complete your look,” he promises.

Male metallic: While tweed, wool, leather, suede and scuba will continue to rock the dance floor, Rajesh Pratap Singh’s metal jacket is the most defining look of 2016. Check out artist Subodh Gupta in the ‘steel’ suit if you need convincing.

Mind the extras: Shantanu & Nikhil revived brooches for men, but in an edgier avatar, at GQ ’s Fashion Nights. The magazine’s editor, Che Kurrien, says Tom Ford’s reinvention of a classic fragrance, the Tobacco Vanille, wins hands down this season. And for some quirk, he suggests you take the Adidas Originals Tubular X sneakers for a spin tonight. Top photographer and Kingfisher Calendar man, Atul Kasbekar, insists on self-tied bow ties, if you are going formal. “Tom Ford has a brilliant pre-tied bow that looks like you’ve knotted it. And because it’s so cool, it costs 175 pounds at Selfridges!” he concludes.
title: Through the cocktail hour

text:
While 2016 might have brought with it an unusual sense of despondency — especially in global politics — it also delivered good cheer from an unexpected source: television shows have been thriving internationally. For the first time in recent memory, the number of memorable new shows this year far outstripped the number of new films released.

Some fear this embarrassment of riches on television cannot be sustained. A recent study by FX, an American cable channel, revealed that the number of shows in the US increased by 94 per cent from 2009 to 2015. This growth is now being driven largely by streaming services such as Hulu, Netflix, and Amazon Prime Video, all of which have invested heavily in producing original content. According to Janney, a financial services firm, Netflix set aside $5 billion for producing original content in 2016.

Indian viewers, of course, could barely be less pleased — after all, both Netflix and Amazon Video arrived this year. Even as we rejoice and look forward to more in 2017, here is a look at some of the shows that captivated us in 2016:

Planet Earth II

It is hard to believe David Attenborough is 90. His distinct voice — with its signature crackle — permeates the second coming of BBC’s Planet Earth . It has been ten years since the last edition enthralled viewers. Much has changed in the world since then, Attenborough informs us. It is much more fragile; much more in need of appreciation and conservation. Planet Earth II goes beyond the previous show — which itself had gone far beyond anything that came before it — in order to show us the magnificence of the natural world. (It was filmed in three years by a camera crew of 22 in 40 countries.) Across six episodes, steered by Attenborough’s authoritative narration, Planet Earth II transcends the medium and shows us a planet of immense richness, and a heart-breakingly uncertain future. Frequently, we are chastened by the realisation that, in the struggle for survival, our planet can be unforgivingly cruel too.

Fleabag

The best television drama of the year is also the shortest. At about 162 minutes, which really is feature-film length, Fleabag is eminently viewable in a single dash. Phoebe Waller-Bridge must certainly be the find of the year. She directs, writes (the show is an adaption of her own play), and also acts as the eponymous Fleabag — an obnoxious, conflicted misfit who struggles to find her feet in London after a personal tragedy. Deceptively simple, yet layered, Fleabag offers a wealth of vantage points. At the level of comedy, the gags are fresh, occasionally uncomfortable, and mostly dark in their humour. The digs come fast and furious — at straitjacketed family life; at familial relationships; at men who consider women beneath them; at women who accept infidelity, and find themselves paralysed by inaction. The most devastating indictment remains for Fleabag, who must make peace with her own horridness.

Full Frontal with Samantha Bee

Full Frontal with Samantha Bee is unique for being a news comedy show hosted by a woman. Right at the beginning of the first episode, Bee fields questions from men: “Is it hard breaking into the boys’ club? What does it feel like being a woman on a late night show?” These questions in themselves answer what a break from tradition this show is—and, indeed, how important.

Samantha Bee was the longest-tenured correspondent on The Daily Show with Jon Stewart. She brings her mighty experience to her own show, but wears it with lightness. The witty one-liners fly off her sleeve; more devastating are the moments of exposition taken entirely from real news footage. Unlike other late night shows, Bee takes a hard look at women’s issues consistently — from abortion laws, to the long-suffering wives of politicians, to Kansas’s dress code for women in the Senate (“your state’s got 99 problems, but a bitch ain’t one”). Along with Phoebe Waller-Bridge and Krysten Ritter (Marvel’s Jessica Jones), Samantha Bee makes up the triumvirate of excellence in television. If recent shows are any indication, gone are the days, hopefully, of women playing second fiddle, or, at best, one of an ensemble. Last Week Tonight with John Oliver , which shares the studio with the show, at last has a worthy, and necessary, compatriot.

Atlanta

It’s likely that half-way into the first episode of Atlanta , viewers might — with some guilt — note that it’s very hard to spot a single white character in the show. By the end of the first season, that feeling becomes a distant memory, and one revels in the feeling of having watched something quite original and edifying. Atlanta is a perceptive look at the struggles of two African-American rappers to make it in America. It wears its identity lightly but never turns away from issues that matter —police brutality, internet trolling, mental illness and the never-ending quest for love.

Here’s an exercise: try thinking of the most popular shows of the last 20 years. Chosen at random, one would arrive at perhaps the following: Seinfeld, Friends, The Big Bang Theory, Two and a Half Men, The West Wing, How I Met Your Mother . Atlanta holds its own against the best, and is another nail in the coffin for TV shows run by white men. What’s more, it’s written and directed by Donald Glover, who plays one of the two leads. Watch out for him in next year’s Spiderman: Homecoming , and the under-production Han Solo Star Wars film.

The Night Manager

Tom Hiddleston and Hugh Laurie star in a six-episode cat-and-mouse thriller—an adaptation of John le Carre’s 1993 novel of the same name. Fans of Hiddleston and Laurie (who isn’t?) barely need to be persuaded to watch the show. For those who aren’t, it’s a showcase for both men’s considerable acting talents and should win them new admirers. The basic plot is trite (seeking revenge for the death of a loved one by infiltrating an arms dealer’s inner circle) and has seen multiple iterations over the years. But sharp, edge-of-the-seat writing, gorgeous camera-work, and the two leading men elevate the source material.

Hiddleston, as the hurt lover, broods quietly, biding his time to pounce upon Laurie, the egregious arms dealer. Laurie, for his part, ensconced in his outrageously beautiful villa (or is it a fortress?) in Spain, perfects a swagger that accompanies a steel-cold heart. One of the stars of the show (to the delight of Fleabag fans) is Olivia Colman, who plays a pregnant intelligence officer. Perfectly cast as the obnoxious stepmother in Fleabag , she offers a strong case for being cast in more shows.

Also Watch Stranger Things, The Crown, Westworld, Marvel’s Jessica Jones, The Night Of.
title: Idiot box no more

text:
“Don’t let that cat in here.” My normally placid mother-in-law was very vehement.

“But, ma,” I argued, “cats are like that. You can’t blame her for being what she is.”

“She’s evil,” was the implacable response.

This was an ongoing argument every time we spotted The Silly Cat, as we called her. At first, amma hadn’t been so vociferous in her condemnation of the brindled feline. The cat wandered in and out of the house and the school grounds. One morning, we discovered that her sleeping quarters were the top of amma’s cupboard. We’d been sitting on the bed, idly chatting, when a head rose above the boxes stacked on the cupboard. A baleful glare fixed us and The Silly Cat rose and stretched luxuriously before making her way out. When it was tea time, she would beg for biscuits or potato chips. If we didn’t give them to her, she’d just climb up to wherever we’d stored them and help herself. Then came the day when amma discovered The Silly Cat under her bed, chewing on the remains of a kitten. I insisted that the kitten had probably died and the cat was just disposing off the carcass. There was just an eloquent shudder in reply.

Amma definitely preferred the dogs. Jimmy, the mongrel, had walked into the premises, as a three or four year old, 10 years ago and never left. No animal can enter without Jimmy giving us warning. But he didn’t think humans were worth bothering about. So, we occasionally found assorted drunks, who tried to use the school as a thoroughfare into the village, wandering around the campus.

Jimmy’s pet aversion was being subjected to the indignity of a bath. He believed that bathing was only for sissy dogs. In the early days, before he knew better, he was caught and cleaned forcibly. It was a trying time for both Jimmy and the bather. Soon better sense prevailed. People left Jimmy alone, except when it was time for vaccination.

A few years later came three-year-old Lyca. An abandoned golden Labrador, she found herself a home by the simple expedient of jumping into amma’s car as if she had every right to be there when amma visited an animal shelter. My mother-in-law didn’t have the heart to tell her she didn’t belong. So she did the next best thing; she brought Lyca home. Jimmy was cautious at first but soon learnt that Lyca was no bark and no bite.

As the skinny frame filled out, Lyca was the perfect example of how beautiful her breed could be. But the filling out process didn’t stop and Lyca now resembles a beached whale. Every now and then, especially when the vet threatens us with dire consequences, we try to put Lyca on a diet. It’s hard because none of us is really good at dieting. Lyca is also a past master at finding herself something to eat. If she’s not inveigling the crows to drop her something that we’d rather she not eat, she’s coaxing our neighbour into sharing his food with her.

The third dog, a dachshund cross, is smaller than either Jimmy or Lyca. Even as a pup, the little fellow had loads of attitude. He would walk around with his head up, as if trying to reach Lyca’s or Jimmy’s height, unafraid of anything or anyone. When he first came, amma and I named him Chocolate. What we didn’t take into account was the Kabali fever raging at that time. The non-teaching staff, who were very amused by his antics and with whom he spent much of the day, began referring to him as Kabali. So he was Kabali during the day and Chocolate in the evenings. That strut alone should have warned us. Soon he wouldn’t even look up at our cries of ‘Chocolate’. Why would he answer to a namby-pamby Chocolate when he had a more macho name in Kabali? Amma and I struggled for a bit but eventually gave up.

It was Kabali who helped us with Lean Lyca campaign. He wanted to play and he didn’t see why his two canine friends couldn’t join him. Jimmy, now at least 13 years old, only wants to warm his ancient bones in the sun and not have to mentor a cocky young pup. Lyca just wanted to digest her last meal, which had probably been eaten five minutes ago. Kabali would dash in, ears and tail flying, and fling himself on Jimmy or Lyca. Jimmy would allow the pup to worry his stomach or throat for a bit and then warn him off. Lyca would try to run away, or rather waddle away, with Kabali hanging on to her tail or her ears. Lyca certainly lost some weight thanks to play time.

Now that Kabali is in the process of growing up, we are thinking of looking for a pup who will fill the gap when Jimmy eventually decides he’s had enough of this life.

Why would he answer to a namby-pamby Chocolate when he had a more macho name in Kabali?
title: The silly cat and other stories

text:
An avalanche of new content stormed our television screens in 2016. But some shows stood taller than the rest.

Here are the 10 best shows of 2016, in no particular order.

The Crown : The Crown traces the life of a young Queen Elizabeth II, as she struggles to balance the monumental responsibility that has been thrust on her, with her once ‘regular’ life. Claire Foy is stunning as a young woman with an immense burden on her shoulders. The show is visually arresting, tightly-scripted and is proof that story-telling is, and always will be, superior to big-budget special effects. (Netflix)

Westworld : What happens when robots created for human pleasure discover consciousness? Worse, what happens when they realise the magnitude of the abuse they’ve been put through? A mind-bending storyline with equally confounding twists and a cast that reads like an honour roll, no show this year is capable of making you stay up at night the way Westworld does. (Hotstar, Star World Premiere HD)

Stranger Things : The Eighties are back with this eerie sci-fi mystery that plays like a Stephen King novel. Stranger Things boasts of not only Winona Ryder (who is flawless as a distraught mother trying to make sense of aliens in her backyard), but also the most lovable 10-year-olds in recent television history. (Netflix)

The Night Of: Dark and gripping, The Night Of is, to borrow from the show, a subtle beast. Naz Khan finds himself accused of a gory murder, and it doesn’t help that he has no recollection of events. Riz Ahmed, John Turturro and Bill Camp are fantastic in this courtroom drama that makes no mince of discussing racial prejudice and Islamophobia in the backdrop of the American justice system. (Hotstar, Star World Premiere HD)

The Night Manager : John le Carre’s riveting espionage novel is brought to life by this lavish BBC production, which has some sublime acting performances. Hugh Laurie transforms into Richard ‘The Worst Man In The World’ Roper, a billionaire weapons dealer, and Olivia Colman is brilliant as Angela Burr, the determined British enforcement agent who’s out to catch him. As for Tom Hiddleston, the show may as well be one which cements his place as the next James Bond.

Game of Thrones (Season 6) : The sixth season of Game of Thrones premièred this year, with each episode having a bigger revelation than the next. With resurrections, family reunions and sweet revenge, the season was probably the fastest moving in terms of storyline after the first, and the final episodeswere masterpieces. (Hotstar, Star World Premiere HD)

The People v. O.J. Simpson: American Crime Story : This miniseries that swept the Emmys this year resurrects the real courtroom drama of the infamous murder trial that shook 90s America. The screenplay will have you on the edge of your seat. (Hotstar, Star World Premiere HD)

Black Mirror : The show is a compilation of six episodes, each narrating a different (horror) story detailing our relationships, and growing reliance on technology. Whether it’s the story of killer robotic bees or a future where your worth is measured in ‘likes’, Black Mirror will have you looking at your phones very differently. (Netflix)

Better Call Saul (Season 2) : The show might be only two seasons old, but the spin-off has already outdone its much-celebrated original, Breaking Bad . The series about a small-time lawyer’s path to becoming an ace con-man has excellent story-telling, sharp dialogue, terrific acting, and is one of the best shows on TV right now. (Colors Infinity)

The Americans (Season 4) : The thriller series about two Russian spies living average American lives during the peak of the Cold War only got better this year. Keri Russell and Matthew Rhys give extraordinary performances, yet again, as the show dives deeper into the complex themes of identity, patriotism and family, with a few wigs thrown in. (Hotstar, Star World Premiere HD)
title: The 10 Best Shows of 2016

text:
California-based rapper-songwriter Svetha Rao, was in Bengaluru as part of her music tour. The singer, also known as Raja Kumari, is famous for her style of blending Indian classical elements with hip-hop. She talks passionately about her work.

“Song-writing is indispensable to the craft of music. It has helped me cement what my artistry sounds like,” starts the singer, who then goes back in time and recalls her experinec with some of the big names from the music industry.

“Working with Iggy Azalea was a crazy experience, especially hearing my own voice blaring out of the speakers. The Fallout Boy was my first platinum record, they were instrumental in making my work international. I always looked up to Gwen Stefani and just to be in the same room with her and have her respect my opinion, musically, boosted my confidence.”

The singer was honoured with the BMI Awards and was also nominated for the Grammys.

“The legitimacy that is brought on by such an award is immeasurable,” beams the artiste.

Talking about being a female rapper, she goes on, “I like being one of the few women in a man’s game. I grew up with two brothers. Most friends even today are boys, but the intention is that my music reaches everybody. One of my biggest inspirations is Lauren Hill. Her music didn’t apply specifically to women or men but to everybody.”

“I am inspired by everybody around me. Every day is a school day. Be present in the moment is important for drawing creativity,” she adds.

Though Raja Kumari is brought up in California, her work is focused in India. “When it comes to giving back, I feel I must give back to my people first.

My heart will always be here. I want to stay true to my roots.”

She adds that she is a big fan of A.R. Rahman and is “influenced by him when it comes to music. He is my guru. The soundtracks of Bombay, Roja and Rangeela have impacted me. Often, when I do fusions, I draw inspirations from him.”

Speaking of her stage name, she says, “They used to call me IP (Indian Princess) in California. And, ‘I-Pee’ is not exactly what one wants to be called in her record labels,” she laughs. “I wanted my name to be connected to my origin.”

About her future plans, Raja Kumari says she will be “working with Vivian Divine, a well-known rapper in India.”

“I received so much affection and enthusiasm from the audience here, that I look forward to coming back more often.”
title: Princess of pop

text:
Rishi Kapoor has sailed through many avatars on screen from the charming baby-faced lover and twinkle-toed singing star in the Seventies and Eighties to the politely cold-blooded trafficker in Agnipath and the cantankerous old man in this year’s Kapoor & Sons .

Very much like his twitter persona, the 64-year-old actor is free, frank and forthright in his take on everything from method acting to marriage. Excerpts

Have you always been so outspoken?

Are you referring to my conversation two minutes ago or to my comments on Twitter?

On Twitter

Twitter for me is fun. I don’t take it too seriously. I like to make people happy. Most often I am the butt of the joke. I don’t make fun of people. I try not to hurt anyone. I don’t resent anyone. If, however, I have hurt anyone, I apologise, I say I am sorry. I have become sceptical about voicing my opinions now and only come out if I see injustice like in the case of my niece’s child.

Don’t they say being outspoken and non-diplomatic in Bollywood is like committing hara-kiri?

No, this is who I am. Standards are set all the time of what is acceptable and what is not.

Did you always want to become an actor?

As far as I can remember. I come from a family of actors. We are steeped in it. I am thankful to god that I have been able to carry the legacy forward.

Are you a method actor?

Not at all! I am a spontaneous actor, an instant coffee, instant noodle kind of actor. I respect all schools of acting. When my son wanted to study at Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute, I told him it was his call. I believe in this day and age, spontaneity works. All the younger generation are spontaneous actors.

I’ve been told by mimicry artistes that I am a very difficult actor to imitate because I do not have a particular style. In my generation, all the actors had their individual styles, I didn’t. People could imitate my dances because they were choreographed but not my acting. Acting is like riding a bicycle.

They say once you learn to ride, even if you haven’t ridden for years, when you get on a bicycle, you might wobble for a bit and then you find your balance. Acting is like that you never lose your craft. There are no good or bad actors, only actors and non-actors.

You are known to be impatient and short tempered…

Yes, but for Kapoor & Sons , I’d sit in a chair for make-up for hours on end. You tell me does that make me patient or impatient?

It depends, yes I am irritable and if you ask me to stare at this poster for 15 minutes I would lose patience. I was willing to put in the time for Kapoor & Sons because of passion. I am a man of the moment. I do not have nerves of steel to quietly take whatever life dishes out.

Have you regretted any of your outbursts?

Never.

What is it about acting that still excites you after all these years?

I had reached saturation with singing and dancing around trees. I wasn’t enjoying myself. Now I play characters — good, evil I enjoy them all. I enjoy the process of acting, of reinventing myself.

Could you name some of your memorable performances?

No, I leave that for others to judge. Good, bad, indifferent, I chose to act in those movies. No one put a gun to my temple and forced me to act. I acted in those films to the best of my capacity. It is my job and I have to do it well. Acting in a film is not a favour, that is what I am paid to do. I tell my son also, you are supposed to be good, you have been paid for it.

What does marriage mean to you?

It is a commitment. Neetu and I played according to the rules we set. I have been accused of not allowing Neetu to act after marriage. That is not true.

In a marriage, one person is the breadwinner and the other is a homemaker.

In our marriage, I was the breadwinner and I am very lucky Neetu was the homemaker. I know I am a difficult and painful man. Neetu was the shock absorber and I am thankful for that. She has kept me going.

Are you a people person?

I have to be, but I am not overtly friendly, I am not very accessible to fans, I do not seek attention. It is a failing, but that is how I am.

Do you watch films?

Of course I do! Cinema is my second mother.

You are publishing your autobiography Khullam Khulla: Rishi Kapoor Uncensored …

I am excited and nervous about it. I have been working on it for three years. It is published by Harper Collins and will be launched at The Hindu Lit for Life 2017.

I am looking forward to it. While there have been books on the Kapoors, there has never been one by a Kapoor. There is nothing boring in the book, but don’t look for scandal and sensation in it. I talk about my life, my failures, successes, all facets of films, things I’ve enjoyed.

Do you think nationalism is vastly different from patriotism?

To me, they are the same. I love my country. What I am is thanks to this land and the people.

You have come often to Bangalore. Do you have a favourite Bangalore memory/place?

Oh there are so many in Bangalore and Karnataka. We shot Mera Naam Joker in Mysore, Bobby in Bangalore, Zehreela Insaan, the remake of the famous Kannada film Naagarahaavu , in Chitradurga, parts of Satyam Shivam Sundaram , Prem Rog … Karnataka was a favourite of RK Studios. The greenery, the warmth of the people, the gulmohars flowering in April and May…

I haven’t shot here in the past 20 years and I am saddened that the greenery has been replaced by a concrete jungle but I hope some of the charm still survives.

Rishi Kapoor will speak at The Hindu Lit for Life 2017.

text:
Salman Khan says he likes to live healthy and tries to stick to a balanced diet. The star, who turned a year older on December 27, launched his personal app to be in touch with his fans and share his workout regime. “I cycle, swim, gym and eat the right kind of food. I sleep late, as I don’t get sleep easily. The kind of food you eat is as important as your workout. I avoid processed and sugary food,” says the actor. The Sultan star says his diet is high in protein. “My all-time favourite is the yellow daal that my mother cooks. My favourite dishes include rajma, chawal and roti. For breakfast, I eat four egg whites and some low-fat milk. Pre-workout, I have a protein shake and two egg whites. Post workout, it is a protein bar, oats, almonds and three egg whites. Lunch is largely meat and includes mutton, fried fish, salad and lots of fruit. Dinner can be anything — chicken, fish, vegetables, or soup.”

Salman says he religiously workouts to maintain a healthy body. “I work out daily and follow a disciplined regimen that consists of weight training and cardio. I usually focus on — biceps, triceps, abs, legs and back. I can do multiple sit-ups, push-ups or crunches at a time.”
title: Salman’s fitness secret

text:
Recently in Coorg on vacation, I looked up at the sky, and the privilege of being stared back by a million dazzling stars was just too much to take in for my Delhi-choked life. Like always, such grandeur of envisioning a world vast and beyond always leaves me heavy in the throes of an existential crisis. That or the lack of a 4G network – both.

In the midst of all those ‘why are we here’ and ‘what does it all matter’ questions, I can’t help but wonder about the pettiness that we occupy ourselves with. How we allow ourselves to fall for beliefs and notions that are nothing but a man-made construct. Religion. Time. Money. And somewhere down the pecking order, the belief that whisky is superior to whiskey.

Now, we understand the purist’s obsession with single malts and the special scoff they reserve for anything that isn’t. One is also not entirely unfamiliar with the new, almost-hipster Bourbon brigade, who put down the Scotch enthusiasts like an endangered species. And let’s not forget the new-age revolutionaries who will back any whisky (or whiskey) as long as it comes from a seemingly obscure country: India. Iceland. Italy. Even France! How about Tasmania down under?

But we often forget a country that sits on the cusp of all these factions: Irish whiskey. While it is true that most famous Irish distilleries were set up by Scotsmen, let’s not forget that, historically, the art of distilling was brought by Irish monks to the Gaelic Bravehearts in the first place.

That said, the Irish style of whiskey is unique and very different from any else found around the world. To generalise, Scotch tends to be smoky and toasty, and Bourbon, at the other end of the spectrum, leans towards vanilla and butterscotch, and most other styles (Japanese and such) emulate one of the two with the local weather and master blender providing the nuanced differentiation.

Irish whiskey then, by the same generalisation, is fairly neutral. It is smooth without being toasty, fruity without being ripe. It doesn’t do peat, nor does it do new charred casks. Their idea of whiskey is to make a flavourful easy beverage that does well by itself and also marries well in cocktails. It should appeal to the novice, but also have complexity enough to engage the seasoned tippler. Recently, I was privy to an extended tasting by a popular Irish whiskey brand, Jameson, and these notes are pretty much from my scribbles on that evening.

But flavour aside, what I really like about them is how they have chosen to reach out to their patrons: no stuffy tastings, no elaborate meal pairings, or men in kilts being paraded through banquets full of thirsty aficionados. Instead, they are looking at more contemporary events and animations to engage people. Even an underground music fest was fair ground for them! Who would have thought that one day we would be enjoying the up-tempo beats of top international DJs with a measure of Jameson and ginger ale?

And that is precisely how we should take life: always ready for the unexpected. To enjoy each unanticipated moment without classifying or judging. And as long as the glass has a double pour in it, don’t worry whether it’s whisky or whiskey.
title: A matter of E

text:
I took my first selfie 11 years ago when I had just created my blog and needed a profile picture to go with it. It was taken with a webcam that was slightly bigger than a ping-pong ball, and whose resolution was poorer than the camera of the cheapest phone you get today. But the fact that you could take your own picture at the click of the mouse was mighty exciting, and so, purely in memory of those happy days, I have retained that picture on my blog, even though I barely resemble the man in it.

Thereafter, I took countless other selfies with the conventional camera, especially when wife and I would travel: I would put one arm around her and hold the camera with the other, pointing the lens in our direction and — with some mental calculation — making sure we were in the frame. Since we couldn’t see ourselves on the display screen, we did not adjust our hair or alter our expressions to look our best: we merely smiled and looked at the lens. Some of our happiest pictures — whether spontaneously happy or happily spontaneous, I am not sure — were self-clicked in this fashion.

So, what the kids are doing today, I have been doing for more than a decade now; only that I did not know back then that such a self-clicked photograph would soon acquire a name, recognised by even the Oxford dictionary: selfie. Needless to say, the venerated dictionary, in keeping with the changing times, defines the ‘selfie stick’ as well, that too with great clarity: ‘A device in the form of a rod on which a camera or a smartphone may be mounted, enabling the person holding it to take a photograph of themselves from a wider angle than if holding the camera or smartphone in their hand.’

Selfies are a way of life today. Many of us aren’t even sure whether we live to selfie — or selfie to live? I have taken the liberty to use selfie as a verb because that’s how it is, isn’t it? I mean, the smartphone-owning society is split into two these days: people who live healthy so that they look naturally good when selfies are taken, and people who feel healthy when their selfies earn widespread admiration on social media.

I don’t know which category I belong to, but I would certainly find it very worrisome if I appeared to be ‘smart’ and ‘fit’ — even if not so in real life — with the help of the lens. The lens is capable of lying through its teeth, provided you know in which angle to hold the phone: a tubby man, therefore, can look trim — and once the ‘likes’ start pouring in, he actually begins to believe that he is in great shape when he isn’t.

We now live in a world of illusions — or maya — something that the sages had always cautioned us against: a protruding tummy looks flat, whereas a perfect pair of feminine lips protrudes. Tonight, when you go partying, no matter where you go, look around: you will find countless pairs of lips protruding as the cameras are turned into the selfie mode — that is, if you are already not among those who like to pout.

The practice has become so common that no one any longer bats an eyelid when they find a young woman suddenly stopping in the middle of anywhere and aiming the phone at herself to pout at the screen. As for the woman, during those few moments she spends clicking selfies, she becomes so oblivious to the people around her, as if she were in front of the restroom mirror.

But: why pout when clicking a selfie? That, to me, shall remain the unanswered question from 2016, even as I wish you a Happy 2017.
title: Happy 2017! But why do you pout?

text:
New Year’s Eve brings with it the inevitable and rather unavoidable question: “What are your resolutions going to be?” With the New Year being symbolic of new opportunities, new adventures and new choices, we have to agree this question makes us ponder over the past year’s events.

However, house and home resolutions always tend to get sidelined. What are those small changes that would make our home a touch cosier and more streamlined? I’ve noted down three key resolutions. Let’s call them “spacelutions” for the fun of it, shall we? And the best part about house and home resolutions is you don’t have to stop eating chocolate to achieve any of them!

Declutter

Start by assessing all that you currently own and that’s on display. Be it vases, photo frames, knick knack bowls, candles, and more. Once you take stock of it all, it becomes easier to cull what you truly want to keep. I love to pepper my living room with photos, but I do always make a mental note to keep it in check, so it doesn’t make the space overwhelming. Similarly, maybe you don’t need to display all your showpieces at once. Choose your current favourite and make that your star piece.

Once you’ve got your key décor elements in place, vow to clean up those drawers that hold forgotten notes, old bills, bookmarks, medicines and more. Make catch-all baskets and trinket trays your best friend. Streamlining spaces that are visible is easy enough. But only once those little nooks and crannies are spruced up too do you feel like you can tick this resolution off your new year to-do list.

Stay get-together ready, always

At the turn of the new year, each of us vow to put in effort into spending quality time with our loved ones. So why not lend your home space that inviting feel? Starting in the new year, vow to make every living space get-together and guest-friendly.

Small and simple changes help you achieve this in the most seamless of ways. Make sure that vase in your living room always has a bunch of fresh flowers. Take stock of old magazines that tend to pile up in the bathroom or bedroom and stow them away to give to the old paper mart. This helps in keeping your home clutter-free ever so often. Ensure you always have a clean set of bed and bath linen ready in the guest bedroom in case a relative pops by for a short stay. I also always fluff and switch up my couch and floor cushions so that they’re always a tad lived-in and not entirely stiff for when guests pop over.

Keep your décor elements seasonal

If you keep flowers at your foyer, apart from the year-round rotation of roses, orchids, and lilies, switch up and opt for flowers that are seasonal.

Similarly for scented candles – in the summers, opt for tropical and sunny scents; maybe even choose tropical-inspired pieces to go with.

Pick rain forest-esque scents for the monsoon and pine and cinnamon for the winters for that cosy, toasty feel. Doing this helps in bringing in and reflecting the current season indoors too.

The simplest things make the most impact. These are just three of many quick things you can do to get closer to a more ‘spacelution’-friendly home; one that is more inviting, more seasonal and definitely more clutter-free!

Have a sparkling 2017!
authors: Sussanne Khan Is Style Editor At The Label Life
title: Housekeeping tips

text:
Bring on the bling

If you’re the kind that loves some sparkle and shine, there’s no better day than New Year’s Eve to wear a metallic dress. Designer Niyati Manoj says: “Go for a sequinned bodycon or wear a champagne-hued shiny floor-length gown. Jewel-toned outfits are popular. However, if you’d rather play safe with a LBD, ensure you choose metallic shades for your eye shadow. Complete your look with a few coats of mascara for lush lashes and classic red lipstick.”

Vampy burgundy lips

This New Year’s Eve look to Hollywood celebs for make-up inspiration. Shay Mitchell and Demi Lovato nailed this trend not too long ago. If you love the nude-lips look and are willing to reinvent the classic smoky eye, Jennifer Lopez would serve as your ultimate muse.

Classic curls

This look can be created at home with a simple curling iron or even with a hair straightener. “You could either make a side/centre parting. To glam up your appearance, create a subtle pouf just above the crown of your head, and then allow your classic shiny curls to cascade delicately. Add a stylish headpiece/hair accessory if you wish,” suggests Ariba Khan, a city-based hairstylist.
title: Fashion & Makeup

text:
continued from Page 1

Musical chairs

If kids are going to form a good chunk of your guest list at your NYE party, at least one or two age group appropriate games must be played. Your go-to game is musical chairs.

Whose resolution is that, anyway?

This could be a fun game to play, especially if most of them know each other at least moderately well. You could all gather around the table, have each person write out their resolution anonymously on a piece of paper and drop it into a common box. As each resolution is read out by the host, the others are supposed to match the resolution with the maker. The person with the highest number of correct guesses is declared the winner.

Picolo with a twist

If it is an adults only party that you’re hosting and you’re familiar with Picolo, one of the most popular internet drinking games today, you could play your version of it using events from your friends’ lives that have occurred in the past year.

For example, if Shanti went through a breakup this year, those who didn’t meet her in person to console her, could be asked to take four sips each of their drink, and so on.
title: Coimbatore

text:
Raftaar’s knack for telling stories through rap has pervaded different cultures. Having already sung in Malayalam, Tamil, Telugu, Punjabi and Hindi, in his latest song “Dhaakad” for Dangal , he captures the conviction of the sisters, while narrating their journey from their stint as amateur wrestlers to their entry into the Olympics. Through his throaty rough voice as he sings in Haryanvi manifesting the rugged landscape of the arenas, with clouds of dust surrounding the sisters as they stride forward, Raftaar’s proclivity to use the medium of music to tell stories is restated.

However, soon Raftaar is switching space! He has collaborated with Mortem Tyldum for the upcoming sci-fi movie Passengers, which features Jennifer Lawrence and Chris Pratt in a space journey. His song “Aadat”, recorded in the same studio as the movie. After composing a song titled “Mother Nature” for the UN Climate Change Summit in 2014, this is his second big overseas project.

Calling himself a ‘storyteller’ and ‘poet’ instead of a rapper, the autodidact in him comes alive as he talks about his humble beginnings and flair for rhyming he realised early in childhood. With a singsong yet stentorian voice, the weight in his voice justifies compositions like “Dhaakad” and “Stand Up”.

Here Raftaar talks about his first Hollywood project, his beginnings as a singer and the changing trends in the music industry.

How was the experience of working with the Passengers team? What led to the composition?

The entire process went in raftaar! It happened quite fast. I was in Goa and had to come to Mumbai the next day. The same night I got a call from the Passengers team asking me to compose a song for them. They said they wanted my signature elements in the composition. I couldn't believe in the beginning. I thought maybe it’s a Hindi version of Passengers or some other project in the same name. But, when I told it’s the same movieI got super excited.

No matter how successful you get with your art, you should always crave for more. Next day, I was on a flight to the US and wrote the song. We reached the studio where the movie was shot and recorded in the same studio. Within a span of 24 hours, everything was done, the video was edited as well.

The movie is about space and connection. How does your composition fit in?

It surely is about space, but it’s more than that. It’s about two people living in a secluded place. And Chris makes a beautiful statement in the film. He says that even if they were surrounded by people in a heavenly setting, he would have still chosen Jennifer. This is really hard hitting, and I have conveyed the emotions through my song.

The best part is that this it is my first love song. All my songs in the past have either been inspirational or party numbers. This is for the first time I have sung something romantic.

How was this experience different from composing a song in India?

For me, it was definitely not different. I did the same things I do for a Bollywood movie or a composition back home. But, for them, having a Hindi song in a Hollywood movie is different.

What's your signature style? What’s the thread that connects all your songs?

I am a storyteller. If you listen to my songs, I always try to convey a story, send messages across. Even “Aadat” follows the same pattern. I am telling the story of Pratt and Lawrence in the movie. If you pay attention to the lyrics, you’ll easily get the storyline of the movie.

What are the current trends and patterns you see in the music industry?

See, there is nothing permanent in the industry. Romantic songs come and fade away and some other genre takes over, and then there are times when people like listening to Sufi music. It’s really tough to make anything survive for long in this atmosphere characterised by transience. This generation is so fast and people want to listen to new stuff constantly.

What makes a rapper different from any other singer?

The element of storytelling for sure. A singer would normally use a piece of lyrics, combine it with chorus and indulge in a lot of repetition. However, rappers have the power to utter 16-32 bars of poetry straight away. It's straight storytelling. It's straight delivery of everything you want to say. We’re poets, bro! I call myself a poet with a bit of swagger, I never call myself a rapper.

You sing in multiple languages. Which is the language you connect to the most and like to sing in?

I have sung “Dhaakad” in Tamil and Telugu as well. I am a Keralite (his real name is Dilin Nair) and my first language is Malayalam. I have studied in a boarding school in Haryana and also know Punjabi. So, if you see, no language in specific is my favourite. But, Hindi comes naturally to me and is my comfort zone. I feel quite comfortable with Haryanvi and Punjabi as well. And, even if someone asks me to sing in Bengali and is ready to help me with it, I'll go ahead and do it.

What's your biggest inspiration?

Well, it’s my own struggle. I encountered rap when I listened to Eminem and Linkin Park for the first time in 9th standard. And, in childhood I was really good at rhyming. From realising that I am good at it in the 2nd standard to realising that it’s much more than that; it's about being skilled, having word-play, and telling stories. I used to check out videos online and watch English music channels on TV regularly. I come from a very humble background. Both my parents were working. I had to come out of that social bracket and achieve something better. That pushed me to do it.

Who’s your favourite singer or rapper?

My favourite rapper is Jayceon Terrell Taylor, who goes by the stage name The Game. I also have his name tattooed on my hand.

You've sung different kinds of songs ranging from inspirational to party. What's your most preferred type?

I love doing songs like “Dhaakad” and “Toh Dishoom”. Both of them are filled with messages. Talking about the income group I come from, it’s very difficult to balance a glamourous lifestyle with my roots. But, honestly if given a choice, I would always want to do songs with messages.

What are the associations and plans you have for 2017?

My song with A.R. Rahman is coming out soon. I have also done a dance song for Jolly LLB-2 , which is also their title track. There is also a song with Sunny Deol that I am doing. The first song I ever sang and danced on as a kid was from Narsimha , a Sunny Deol movie. Now, it feels great to be standing with him in a song and singing for him.

What advice would you have for budding artists?

I always say the same thing. Be a wannabe. That's because if now you’re a wannabe, one day you’ll be somebody. Just the will to be somebody is very important. So, be a wannabe.
title: Meet the ‘Dhaakad’ singer

text:
Just as much as people are eager to read new books by their favourite authors, they are also keen to know what some of the bestselling writers are reading between long spells of writing. So we picked five top-notch authors – Ravi Subramanian, Preeti Shenoy, Anuja Chauhan, Salil Tripathi and Bhaskar Ghosh – and asked them to share what was on the top of their minds in 2016. We didn’t limit them by time lines, numbers, geography, literary forms and genres. It was a tad difficult to convince them as Salil was in London in the midst of writing a book on Gujaratis and Ravi was on a holiday in a computer-free environment. Finally, what we get is a fine mix of fiction, non-fiction, translated works and graphic novels. Some are guided by taste, some by immediate concerns. It is amazing to know how Ian McEwan’s novella helped Bhaskar Ghosh settle in after a journey and how Ravi, a banker who writes about tales of intrigue and betrayal in financial world, picks “Ramayana for Children” to relax. And sometimes even children play a role in introducing seasoned authors to new forms as Preeti and Anuja admit.

Anuja Chauhan

I spent this year writing basically because I had a book submission deadline on the 30th of November, but I promised myself I would make up for it by reading like a madman in December. Nowadays, my go-to person on what to read is my 21-year-old daughter.

The Handmaid's Tale by Margaret Atwood: A dark, disturbing take set in a Christian-Talibanised sort of America, all about what happens if a nation starts to take a holy book too literally. I found it troubling and angering and it reinforced all the issues I already have with organised religion.

Fangirl by Rainbow Rowell I thoroughly enjoyed the book which was another one of my daughter’s recommendations, which proved yet again that it’s wrong to label books as either literary or commercial because it was so light and so deep all at once.

Then, as part of my research for “Baaz”, my novel about the Air Force, I read “India's Wars” by Arjun Subramaniam, which was informative as well as absorbing. “Eagles Over Bangladesh” by PVS Jagan and Samir Chopra, which is filled with wonderfully detailed and anecdotal accounts of the air battle between India and Pakistan in 1971.

Books that I read this year which were published in 2016 include “Harry Potter and the Cursed Child” (which I bought first-day first-show, finished in two hours and felt thoroughly dissatisfied with) and my mother-in-law Margaret Alva's autobiography “Courage and Commitment”, which gives a great ringside view of the working of the Congress Party in the 70s and 80s.
title: The author’s choice

text:
“I took to cycling by chance. In January this year, I was bowled over by the new and fitter look of a work associate of mine. He told me that cycling on the Ring Road of our small town Rourkela, Odisha, had done the magic, and the cycling bug bit me instantly.

After a quick research on equipment, I bought a cycle and the necessary gear, like helmet, gloves, jersey, lights, and most importantly, cycling shorts — life savers, especially for long-distance riding.

I began by cycling 15 to 20 km within the industrial town, and gradually built up my stamina to cycle 50 km. It gave me the confidence and courage to go pedalling beyond city limits. I began exploring places — forest areas and no-traffic zones — normally inaccessible to four-wheelers. Chirping birds and lavish greenery were luxuries I was not able to afford inside the city.

Nature appreciation overtook my fitness drive as I realised no matter how many ever times I cycled the same route, it felt different. I even learnt to mend punctures.

I founded a small group called Rourkela Riders and began exploring new destinations in the vicinity, and cycled at least 100 km thrice a week. Running the family business did not allow me much time to pursue cycling, even though I wanted to.

My turning point came when I registered for Brevet, a cycle marathon with specified distances and a time limit. In association with Audax India, a national organisation for cycling affiliated to ACP France, I went on my first brevet ride on November 20. The picturesque countryside with panoramic views of hills and jungles covered the 200 km from Rourkela to Barbil (with its rich iron ore deposits) and back, and I was required to complete the distance in 13.5 hours. I left at 5.30 a.m. and was back by 5 p.m., much ahead of the stipulated time.

The feeling of elation made me sign up for the next brevet challenge from Rourkela to Puri and back — 400 km in 27 hours.

It was a humongous task because I had to cycle non-stop through the day and night on a busy highway. A group of 13, including cyclists from Rourkela and Bhubaneshwar, set out early on December 10. It was a foggy morning with low visibility that slowed us down, but by dinner time we had covered 270 km. We suffered a setback when one of our cyclists was hit by a car.

I was 20 km ahead when I rushed back in a support car. It took us three hours to stabilise him.

The incident dampened our spirit, but I decided to continue with the expedition, without asking for injury time out. And I made it well within the stipulated time — in 26 hours — by sheer determination.

Since then, my motivation to cycle has been at a new high. Cycling has changed my life in a way I had never imagined.

Apart from physical fitness, it has boosted my mental strength and earned me fame. In 2016, I totally clocked 5,000-plus km and have signed up for the 600-km brevet on January 15 from Vizag to Rajahmundry, to be completed in 40 hours.

Kushal Agarwal is a 29-year-old businessman based in Rourkela.

(As told toSOMA BASU)
title: Two wheels to freedom

text:
Maheep Singh is known as the Gujarati Sardar in comedy circles. Being older than the average stand-up artist in India, his wacky outlook on everyday aspects of life combined with a straight faced dead pan delivery has made Maheep a stand out face in Indian stand up circuit.

When asked about what he feels about the New Year, he remarks, “For me, my year ended on 28th December. Now, there is no pressure on me. People, unnecessarily put themselves under a lot of pressure and stress just so that they can show others that they had fun. All this stress I have done away with.”

He jokingly continues, “In India, people take stress for things that we don’t even know about or practise. I see that on Christmas, some Sharmaji will propose to his girlfriend. I don’t get it. Same with the Valentine’s Day, I believe 20 percent of marriages are proposed because of the pressure of February 14. Someday I want to see people in the US be this serious about celebrating Janmashtami or Ganesh Chaturthi.”

Maheep’s humour encapsulates a lot of self-deprecating humour which was evidenced when we asked him how 2016 went for him. “As a person, 2016 has been very good to me. I firmly believe that if you are an optimist or an enthusiast, you will be disappointed more. I am neither of those. When I take the Metro in the morning, if I get a seat, I am very happy. This is true with ugly people also, they are always happy, whereas good looking people are sad because they keep expecting people to compliment them. Ugly people don’t expect anything, so they are happy with whatever they get. Since not only am I ugly, I am also pessimistic, I have had a wonderful year!”

But for Maheep, who regards Charlie Chaplin and Johnny Walker as his favourite comedians, 2016 also gave him ample material for his performance. “As a comedian I have to thank all the politicians for continuing to give us such good material.”

The talk turned towards demonetisation, and how a comedian handles it. “The regular citizen in me agrees with it. But the comedian in me is enjoying it a lot. So earlier I never used to go to the ATM much. There was never too much need for it. But now since it is not so available and human tendency is to go after the things which we can’t easily get, I have jumped with the bandwagon and stand in queues for the ATM way more than I did before the currency change. This is because whenever you stand at the ATM queue, you always get some material as something or the other keeps happening, while you wait. For example, if you don’t choose English on the ATM machine, the person behind you will judge you. I have seen blue collar workers who have never spoken a word of English choosing English in the ATM machine. I have seen this happening.”

He adds, “I don’t have much money, because let’s face it, I am a comedian. But when I stand at that ATM queue and I get to complain about the upper limits of cash withdrawal, it makes me feel I belong. The reality is very different as the upper limit is really how much money I might have in my entire account.”

But India wasn’t the only country to be joked at this year. “I firmly believe that the person most surprised by the US election is Donald Trump himself. I also think he is the most scared. I keep expecting him to make an announcement saying that all this was a joke.”

(Maheep Singh will perform at The Roseate House, New Delhi on the New Year’s Eve.)
title: Was it a joke?
