We donated $1000 from the money Facebook gave us to a boy with autism
title: Kicha and his American adventure

text:
As the year comes to a close and the party season approaches, let’s look back at what shaped the makeup and hair trends of 2016.

Glitter Lip

This year saw the return of the metallic lip. Metallic lip colours look especially good when added to the centre of your lip. After you apply your regular lipstick, use a metallic liquid lipstick right at the centre and blend it into your base lipstick gently. This gives dimension and interest to a bold lip.

If you want to take it one step further, the glitter lip is for you. Make sure you have a make-up remover handy, because it can get a bit messy. Start with lining your lips and filling it with lipstick; a more glossy lipstick with opaque colour payoff is key. It will ensure that the glitter adheres to it. Once you have applied your lipstick, pick out your favourite glitter pigment and dab carefully within the lines of your lips, with a brush of your ring finger.

Chrome and holographic nails

Probably, the most social media-friendly trend of 2016 has to be the almost mirror-like chrome or holographic nails. While you could always get a super-metallic nail polish that would work great for parties, this particular manicure looks almost magical. It involves buffing holographic pigment over painted nails and then letting them set in an LED nail drier for longevity. While this may seem like a lot of effort for your nails, the result is always spectacular and something everyone must try at least once.

Metallic eyes

Do you sense a theme yet? Highly-pigmented, opaque, super-metallic and almost wet-looking eyeshadow is a definite must-have this party season. Foiled eyeshadows, or pigments and sparkles, can all be used to achieve this very popular look. To give your eyes even more dimension, use a lighter, more metallic colour in the centre of your lids to really make them look wet. You can also ditch the mattes and go in for fully-metallic smoky eyes, which would make a great statement with a matte lip. You could also try your regular eyeshadows for this look, using a product such as Too Faced Glitter Glue or MAC’s Fix +.

Graphic eyeliner

Eyeliner has been around for ages, and with every season, much like everything else, something new comes along. This season, the graphic eyeliner is back, making more heads turn than ever. There isn’t any right or wrong in this. It’s about having fun, creating a gap in your regular feline flick, or just drawing a simple line on the water line and nothing else; it’s about the stark contrast of bare skin and something a little bit out of the ordinary. Personally, graphic liner paired with a statement lip and nude skin would be my perfect holiday look, this year.

Statement ponytails

Of course, with all these make-up options, we can’t leave out hair, now, can we?

Of all the hairstyles that adorned the runways and red carpets, the sleek, glossy pulled-back high ponytail was my favourite. Not only does a high ponytail suit most faces, it makes your life so much easier. Your hair could be greasy and unwashed, but you can still pull this off with minimum effort. Straighten the ends of your hair, so it looks neat and polished. Using products on your roots to comb and pull back your hair into a ponytail ensures that it looks sleek even after a long night of dancing and sweating. Once done, spray it with hairspray for extra grit and longevity.
title: Best of 2016

text:
Chennai is no stranger to natural disasters. Right from the tsunami in 2004 to this year’s cyclone Vardah, the city has endured many large-scale calamities.

One may think that natural calamities have a lasting impact on the real estate sector, but the truth is that in the long run, it has little or no bearing.

In the aftermath of the tsunami, many had expected prices along the coastal corridors of the city to take a hit, but it never happened. Micro markets along Chennai’s coastline such as the East Coast Road, Besant Nagar, and MRC Nagar had been on the front-line, and experts anticipated that buyers would stay away from these markets entirely. But in the last decade they have witnessed tremendous growth and are amongst the most expensive residential localities in the city today. For instance MRC Nagar, which occupies a good chunk of Chennai’s coastline, has seen an astronomical price appreciation of 60 per cent year-on-year in the past decade. An apartment in MRC Nagar which was selling at Rs. 3,000 to 4,000 per sq.ft. a decade ago, is priced at Rs. 18000 to 20,000 a sq.ft. today.

Even an apartment in Besant Nagar ranges between Rs. 14,0000 and Rs. 17,000 a sq.ft.

Another example of property prices remaining stable after a natural disaster is the one-year period between the floods of December 2015 until today. There were many localities around the city which bore the brunt of the floods, and experts predicted a fall in property prices in affected localities. In reality, the floods hardly made a dent on pricing. Some of the worst affected localities such as West Mambalam, Kotturpuram, and Ramapuram have either shown stability or marginal appreciation in property prices.

Hence, going by data from the past, the damage caused by cyclone Vardah to the sector will be negligible.

There are, however, a few precautions that can be taken which will help one to minimise losses incurred during such disasters. It is always best to avoid choosing low lying areas when you are narrowing down localities for your home. There are a number of home insurance schemes which offer a wide range of coverage for both builders and buyers. In the light of recent calamities, both man-made and natural, it is best to be safe than sorry.

The writer is CEO, Indiaproperty.com

Avoid choosing

low-lying areas when narrowing down on localities, and pick a good insurance scheme
title: Post Vardah, market remains stable

text:
An efficient public transport system is a key pre-requisite for the sustained development of a city. It helps citizens meet their travel needs in an economical, safe, and energy-efficient manner. However, cities in India have not invested adequately in developing good quality public transport systems. Only 63 of the 458 Indian cities with more than 1,00,000 inhabitants have a formal city bus system. Within this, 15 cities also have a bus or rail based mass rapid transit system. Even where cities have formal public transport systems, the level of investment support is limited to intermittent efforts in augmenting capacities and covering funding backlogs of bus operators. Many cities lack sustained institutional and financial support to strengthen their bus systems.

As a result, most cities have witnessed a deterioration in the capacity and quality of their bus services. Such inadequacies are being partially addressed by informal Intermediate Public Transport (IPT) services like taxis, informal shared auto-rickshaws providing shuttle services, school buses, and chartered bus services.

At the same time, cities continue to build wider roads, flyovers and expressways. This has provided short-term relief from congestion. But on the flip side, they induce people to use private modes like cars and two-wheelers, which leads to more congestion, fuel consumption and air pollution.

Clearly, more cars on the road are not a sustainable solution in the long run. A better opportunity is to build better and high quality public transport services that meet India’s developmental and environmental objectives. Given their low costs per passenger, flexibility in operations and ease in implementation, bus systems provide the best solution for India to scale up public transport systems across all cities. In line with this assessment, the Shakti Sustainable Energy Foundation, in partnership with Delhi Integrated Multi-Modal Transit Systems (DIMTS), recently carried out a comprehensive review of the existing performance of bus systems in India to understand their current drawbacks and identify a roadmap for their improvement.

The study covers city bus systems in 12 cities of varying population sizes, geographic locations and level of progressiveness of bus systems. Data regarding the operational and financial characteristics of these bus systems has been analysed to understand their comparative performance. The study also carried out detailed interactions with the senior management of these organisations to identify the existing gaps in their practices and the key barriers faced in addressing them.

The key gaps identified in the operations, planning, and management of the bus systems are classified into six key areas: Strategic planning, supporting infrastructure, financing, use of technology, operational efficiency, and institutional frameworks. The lack of long-term strategic planning and adequate financing is observed as a key gap area across all the cities. As a result, all the cities are observed to have a shortage in the bus fleet required to meet their mobility needs. On the remaining categories, cities are observed to be at varying levels of efficiency.

While cities like Bengaluru and Ahmedabad are working towards installing state of the art Intelligent Transport Systems (ITS) to improve their services, cities like Kanpur and Raipur are struggling to put all their buses in operation due to lack of adequate staff for management. The institutional framework within which the buses operate has an impact on their operations. The city buses managed as a part of the State Road Transport Undertakings (STU) are given a lower priority compared to the STUs’ inter-city operations. At the same time, the city buses managed by Special Purpose Vehicles (SPV) created specifically for city operations suffer from a shortage in technical and financial capacity to manage bus systems.

Additionally, specific gaps in issues like Management Information Systems (MIS), fleet and crew management, human resources, fare mechanisms and data analytics of each of the cities have also been identified.

The study has developed a roadmap to address these gaps. This includes short, medium, and long term measures that are needed to revitalise bus systems in Indian cities. The short to medium term recommendations provided to the cities involve specific solutions to address the existing gaps through adoption of national and international best practices. The long-term solutions will need a more comprehensive approach that covers all aspects of planning, operations and management of city bus systems. Therefore, the development of a long-term vision and a business plan to achieve it is recommended to be taken up by all bus operating agencies.

In addition to the improvements needed by the bus operators, the enabling policy and regulatory reforms to be taken up by the concerned national, state and city-level government authorities have been identified.

The report has also identified various areas of intervention where leadership and innovations can be sourced from independent think tanks, research groups and start-ups working on the subject. Improving city bus systems is a key enabler in achieving the urban development vision of India and will need sustained institutional and political support at various levels of governance.

The full report can be downloaded at the following link: http://shaktifoundation.in/

initiative/roadmap-

improving-city-bus-systems-

india/.

The authors are part of the Transport Program at the New Delhi-based Shakti Sustainable Energy Foundation
title: How to improve city bus systems

text:
If your home hasn’t been home sweet home these days, perhaps it’s time for a change. And could there be a better time for change than the coming New Year. If you are planning to change your décor in 2017, re-do these trends that have been done to death in 2016.

Cutesy wall sayings

Sure we understand that they brighten up the wall, make you smile when you read them and show what’s on your mind, but how long can your walls sport decals that say ‘Hello Gorgeous’ or ‘Life isn’t about finding yourself, it’s about creating yourself?’ Have a heart, for this isn’t art.

Weird style statements

It’s imperative to make sure that your home reflects your personality but doing it by upending books on the shelf or sticking posters on the windows to avoid curtains doesn’t say much about you. Look for genuine style statements – may be colour blocking or a statement piece of furniture.

Marble flooring

Time was when marble flooring was synonymous with style and elegance. Thankfully, that’s no longer the case and designers are exploring other flooring. In 2017, why not let something different be underfoot? It could be wood, terracotta tiles or even concrete.

Chalkboard walls

They seemed to be the best outlet for your child’s – and your own – creativity, but these walls or even panels have had their share of fame. Instead, why not try covering your wall with cork or rubber for an innovative and large memo board?

Neon colours

Bright colours may make spaces pop, but how long can you live with overbright pinks, oranges and greens. Let neons rule the gym – you need the energy there – but choosing harmonious colours will make your home a haven.

Mason jars

Jars were everywhere in 2016. We sipped in them in restaurants, ate in them at bakeries and received them as gifts or favours. And then we also tried our hand at DIY crafts with them. Let 2017 be the year you say bye to mason jars and explore other alternatives such as clear, streamlined vases.

Mooch magic

Just like the owl ruled the home décor kingdom in 2015, it was the mooch that took centre stage this year. Be it on bed linen, table linen, posters or wallpaper, designers OD’d on the moustache motif. No one will complain if the next year is a mooch-less one.

The retro look

Colourful, retro-inspired appliances may have been the rage, but it’s time to look at elegant and sleek designs. Opt for brushed metal finishes, subtle colours and stylish accessories.
title: Trends to bid adieu to in 2016

text:
Nearly 80 per cent of Indian buildings are made of mud and biomass, states Architect Gopal Shankar of Habitat Technology Group. A recipient of the Padma Shri award for his environment sensitive work, Shankar’s designs are totally tuned to earth, the structures using mud blocks, rammed earth, and filler slab roofs along with salvaged materials wherever possible. The social architect that he is, the language of his design and construction techniques is strongly low cost and environment responsive.

Shankar believes in getting his hands soiled, where he can physically feel the earth, discover the versatility of various materials by physically experiencing them. His designs exude simplicity yet a masterly handling of the spaces, the volumes and angles expertly done, revealing an intuitive as well as a master’s touch. While mud is certainly versatile, it has its own inherent drawbacks. Hence why the obsession with it as the predominant material in his structures?

“Mud certainly has its own challenges such as being attacked by termites and losing strength if drenched, yet these can be worked around. Mud has fascinating features, the vocabulary of the material being so sensuous as it is easily mouldable even with bare hands. You need to physically experience it to understand its innate strength. In terms of visual appeal the multiple colours and textures it offers can be irresistible”, he says. “Mud has its own inherent tensile strength but there is no proper documentation of the technique of using it”, he laments.

Having been inspired as a young architect by the unconventional structures and designs of Laurie Baker, Shankar moved on to reflect this source of inspiration in all his designs and manner of construction. His first project, executed three decades ago, was completed at an unbelievable cost of Rs. 11,000, using low cost construction techniques. A significant part of his work continues to be large scale social housing where low cost construction techniques have been employed. His social projects have brought him many awards that include the UNDP award for the best post-tsunami rehabilitation work in India besides the national award for the Best Eco City design in 2015.

No columns

When invited to execute a project in Dhaka, Shankar came up with an earth building which incidentally is the largest of its kind in the world. The six-storey load bearing mud structure spanning six lakh sq. ft displays a total absence of columns. “We used locally available mud in construction and the pale yellow clay that was used for mud plaster offers a beautiful, differential hue to the building”, says Shankar. “The region gets eight to nine months of heavy rains, yet the mud structure has been standing strong for the last 10 years”, he smiles.

His residence, built totally in mud, is yet another fine example of the versatility of mud and low cost construction techniques. Fluid in design and planning of spaces, the mud blocks and rammed earth structure standing at two levels flows magnificently, the smooth curves, mud vaulted roofs, strategic vents and punctures letting copious natural light and ventilation into the interiors. “The mud blocks have been used without a binding material, by opting for the inter-locking system”, explains Shankar.

It is common to assume that low cost techniques would offer a dowdy ambience. “This is nothing but a myth”, says Shankar. He points to a residential project where such techniques were opted for. Built on a cramped site that had an uneven gradient, the design was structured to lend an expansive feel by making it free flowing. The spaces are multi-levelled, where the functional spaces are deftly demarcated.

Aesthetics

A rock prevailing in the site is retained, the interiors designed craftily around it. The aesthetics of the structure and interiors reflects no connection with the low cost building techniques adopted.

Shankar’s office reflects similar techniques.

Built on a narrow strip of land with a sharp gradient that is 30 ft. higher on one end, the multi-level spaces reflect a mastery of strokes that handles the constraints of the site while adopting the use of mud blocks, rammed earth and mud plaster with its mud texture to erect a structure sans the conventional columns.

“This is the strength of mud,” smiles Shankar.

‘Mud has its own inherent tensile strength but there is no proper documentation of the technique of using it.’
title: Building ‘mouldable’ houses

text:
Everyone is talking money – demonetisation, political agenda, cash crunch, hoarding new currency, impacts on daily life, IT raids, eradicating black money and hoping for a white future. Rich and poor people alike are finding the daily needs hard to come by with little money in hand, irrespective of how much they have in bank balance or in old currency. We all know there is less money in market; hence business is not as usual.

While so much has been spoken and written about the impact of demonetisation on varied facets of life, hardly anyone has touched upon its impact on ecology and resources. It is strange but true that cash crunch is beneficial to nature.

On a few fronts, the present cash crunch is comparable to the economic recession of the recent past, faced mainly in the west, with some implications for India too. People faced reducing income, challenge of loan repayments, increased unsold inventories, money getting blocked and financial uncertainties looming large. Between all the social tension it created, one of the benefits was reduced consumption, hence earth resources saved, energy used efficiently and wastage reduced.

On a similar note, the recent demonetisation in the country has impacted larger issues of ecology positively. With no ready cash to spend, people have been buying and spending less, of course impacting on everything from tourism to rituals. Incidentally, lesser business does not necessarily mean shops and restaurants are facing losses. They earn less, in turn spend less hoping to extend the new currency they got for as long as they can.

Of course, many people living on daily wages are suffering, for they are already living on minimum daily income and cannot manage with further reduced cash inflow.

Money and materialistic lifestyle are directly proportional, where our lifestyle demands that we earn more money. In turn, income meets the expenditure, increasing production. People earning well may appear to have larger sums with them compared to the rest with lower incomes, but their monthly savings in percentage figure could be often comparable.

This suggests that higher income group spends more, while those with lower income spend less, each spending proportional to their income categories.

A paradox

As such, it is a paradox where money and market fuel each other, which together increase the consumption patterns.

We know that increased consumption is good for economy, but ecologically it is disastrous, irrespective of whether the consumption is for our present needs, future savings or mere personal greed. The rich may have the financial affordability to spend, but our fragile Earth cannot afford to take anymore of our wasteful life.

So, if the present crisis due to demonetisation has reduced our shopping, travelling, holidaying, partying, conferencing, manufacturing, in general spending, it has reduced the consumption of resources.

It could be temporary, until the money flow restores again; yet it is beneficial to nature. Can we ensure this benefit lasts long enough to save the climate?

(The writer is an architect working for eco-friendly designs and can be contacted at varanashi@gmail.com)
title: Some respite for the environment?

text:
In India’s highly dynamic market environment, change and innovation have become essential for the survival of any business. The housing sector has been no exception. Let us examine five factors that stand out in this respect:

1. Increasing focus on affordable ticket sizes

Across most Indian cities, the financial ‘sweet spot’ for home buyers is seen to be in the range of Rs. 50-70 lakh. In hyper-expensive Mumbai, ticket sizes of around Rs. 1 crore are popular with buyers because of the higher wealth creation and therefore purchasing power there. However, as of 3Q16, there has been a rise in apartments priced under Rs. 1 crore in Mumbai, as well.

The proportion of increase in units launched in Mumbai in the under Rs. 1 crore ticket size increased more than the proportion of the overall rise in unit launches.

Mumbai serves as a good example to illustrate the rising affordability trend because it is the toughest market in the country, and yet could see more launches in this segment. Other cities will, therefore, fare even better than Mumbai in terms of decreasing housing ticket sizes.

To keep the price tags of their offerings attractive, developers have been reducing the average carpet area of apartments across cities. For example, the average apartment sizes in Mumbai and Bengaluru have, in recent years, shrunk by 12 per cent and 30 per cent respectively .

2. Configurations revolution

When it comes to the most preferred configurations, 1-BHK flats remain the most popular in Mumbai, while 2-BHKs rule in most other cities such as Delhi-NCR, Bengaluru, Pune, and Hyderabad.

Of course, affordability is the main reason behind the popularity of smaller flats in Mumbai. Most of these smaller configurations are priced around Rs. 1 crore, which is considered ‘affordable’ by Mumbai standards.

Moreover, selling these units later on is easier than selling bigger configurations, as there are always more people looking to buy 1-BHK flats in Mumbai than there are units available. In other cities, the same logic applies to the 2-BHK configuration. As real estate in most cities is cheaper than in Mumbai, home buyers can afford to and do buy bigger configurations.

3. More developers entering affordable segment

The Modi government’s focus on affordable housing has helped in making this segment more palatable to developers. The erstwhile aversion to being tagged as ‘low-income housing builder’ has waned, and even larger players are openly entering this market segment.

After the recent demonetisation move, land prices will plummet - more so in the tier-II, III cities and the fringe areas of metros.

This, too, will aid the cause of making homes more affordable in India. While developers are already constructing smaller-sized units on the outskirts of cities, the government must step in by improving the connectivity of these outskirts to respective city centres.

4. Basic amenities

Home buyers expect decent amenities in their housing projects, regardless of whether they are townships or standalone buildings. While townships offer many amenities, sufficient parking, a small garden and play area, good security and power backup are now increasingly being seen even in standalone residential buildings.

Buyers are no longer willing to settle for amenities-starved projects and expect the basic facilities even if their purchasing power is on the lower side.

With more and more developers of modest-sized residential projects heeding this demand, the rest have been left with no choice but to follow suit.

5. Social media

Dissatisfied home buyers have been using social media effectively to demand redress of their grievances.

Developers have realised the power of social media in brand image management, and many have started responding to buyers’ posts or queries in real time.

At the same time, they have realised the potential of targeting possible buyers with advertisements while they are online.
title: Trends shaping residential realty

text:
As the year draws to a close it is time to take a quick stock of the way we dealt with water and what opportunities lie in the future. The monsoon State of Kerala, famous for its torrential rains, is reeling under drought. The next six months promise to be tough and emergency plans to manage the drought are being put in place.

In the Cauvery basin too the rainfall was abysmal. The south-west monsoon failed and the north-east played truant . The dispute between Karnataka and Tamil Nadu reached a fever pitch. Even the Supreme Court found it tough to maintain a sense of peace and proportion in the matter.

Once again the dams of the Cauvery are broadly empty and a long, hot summer awaits. The city of Bengaluru is on the edge of a precipice for meeting its water needs.

On the other hand the very city did something with waste-water which caught the international media’s attention. Lakes started to foam and even caught fire, filled as they were with untreated sewage and industrial effluents.

Fizz over?

While citizens’ action, aided by courts, ramped up, the legislature panel identifying encroachments of water bodies and the waterways connecting them is yet to come out with its report.

Sporadic actions to clean the waterways by demolishing buildings have stopped and it looks like the fizz in the bottle is over.

At the national level, the flagship Swachch Bharat Abhiyan and the Clean Ganga movement have rolled along. The former fast becoming a toilet construction programme and the latter, struggling in finding an approach to clean the holy and mighty river.

The other rivers of India of course are mere water sources to be dammed and exploited and then to dump raw waste-water in.

Our lack of connect and empathy with our water bodies is fast reaching a point of no return, if it has not so already. Sporadic individual and community efforts, howsoever heroic, have not been woven into a large fabric of redemption. We putter along somehow believing that things can be managed.

We hope that in 2017 we will get our governance and institutions right.

We simply have lacked the imagination to create the right architecture, capacitated, empowered , responsible and transparent to engage in looking at the big picture and driving coordinated small action towards satisfactory solutions.

For example, can the state set up at least one river basin institution and one river flowing, clean and free to reach the sea? Can we not create or resuscitate the institution called the JSYS to rejuvenate all our tanks ? How about reviving our traditional water tanks and wells? The district of Bidar showed the way. Will it be sustained and spread to other districts?

One must conserve water, harvest rainwater, recycle waste-water and one must also engage in community actions such as reviving lakes and streams. One must also pressure the government to get its act right and quickly. Otherwise the deck chairs of the Titanic can be rearranged beautifully but the iceberg approaches.

Here is wishing good action for good rains, good streams, good rivers, good wells, good wetlands and good forests for a waterwise world.

S.Vishwanath
title: Thiruvananthapuram

text:
The last quarter of 2016 has been a major slowdown for most sectors, with real estate taking the biggest blow. With the introduction of several policies and reforms, the government has stirred up the economy, causing waves of change across the nation. As we sign off today, here’s a quick look at 2016 and its effect on 2017.

Economic Outlook 2016

India recorded Gross Domestic Product (GDP) growth at 7.3% between July-September, 2016, with sectors such as Manufacturing, Public Administration, Defence, Finance, Insurance, and Real Estate being the main growth drivers. The inflation rate (Consumer Price Index) decline continued, reducing from 5.69% in January to 4.2% by November; and was primarily due to ease in food inflation.

We also witnessed increased FDI or foreign direct investment of up to $ 32,181 million, a rise of 21% in comparison to the same period in 2015. The FDI in real estate was recorded at $ 141 million, a 7% growth since last year.

Plethora of

policy changes

The government announced a number of policy initiatives in 2016. The Real Estate (Regulation and Development) Act, 2016 was passed, to protect the interest of home buyers and bring transparency to the sector, thereby also increasing funding/financing opportunities for all.

The government also redefined the EWS and LIG qualifying parameters from Rs. 1 lakh to Rs. 3 lakh and from Rs.3 lakh to Rs.6 lakh. “Housing for all by 2022” mission was introduced, wherein 305 cities and towns were identified across the nation for construction of affordable houses.

The mission enables buyers to get subvention scheme loans (end user or buyer is lent money) from banks at a mere 6.5% interest rate while the state/union territory concerned is tasked with fixing the upper ceiling on the sale price The buyer could get up to 90% loan to value ratio on home loans up to Rs. 30 lakh. An additional interest deduction of Rs. 50,000 per annum was available for first time home buyers for loans up to Rs. 35 lakh provided the house cost does not exceed Rs.50 lakh.

The scheme not only benefits the buyer but also the developers, as they get 100% deduction of tax from profits subject to certain conditions, along with exemption of service tax on materials, services and construction of affordable houses up to 60 sq. m under any scheme of the Central or State government including PPP schemes.

The government also passed the Benami Transactions (Prohibition) Amendment Act, 2016, to identify benami transactions and prohibit them in future. Violation of the Act is punishable with imprisonment of up to seven years and fine. It prohibits the real owner from recovering the property that is held in another person’s name on paper while it gets confiscated by the government without any compensation to the violators.

While New Delhi and Mumbai market may observe corrections in the total number of transactions up to 30% across all sectors, markets like Bengaluru will see correction of 15-20%.

Here’s taking a closer looking at the Bengaluru real estate market in 2016.

Office space

The absorption rate of office spaces remained vibrant across 2016. Although there were limited supply infusions that led to reduction in the vacancy levels, new developments saw completion. during the year comprising of pre-committed supply. There was a heavy spike in rentals due to lower vacancy levels on Outer Ring Road. Bangalore North witnessed quite a few major developments with availability of space.

Retail

In 2016, only one mall became operational in the city. The World GT Mall (0.3 million sq. ft) and RMZ Galleria (0.45 million sq. ft) are currently under construction and are expected to get completed by Q1 2017. Leasing activities continued in both high street and mall developments, with stable rentals.

Residential

There were several new launches across the city, mostly apartments under Rs. 50 lakh price bracket. There was a significant downfall in the luxury housing segment, while demand was high for properties worth less than Rs. 1 crore. The capital values for completed as well as under-construction projects continued to remain stable, thus there was no significant shift/change in the micro-location prices.

A look at the

upcoming year

As per a International Monetary Fund (IMF) forecast, India’s GDP growth is projected at 7.6% for 2016 and 2017. The impact of demonetisation & relaxation in FDI regulations along with increased incentives for affordable housing will likely unfold by the next three to four quarters.

The Outer Ring Road is likely to witness shortage of space as most under-construction projects are pre-committed. Bangalore North, with significant new office completions, as a consequence, will witness more traction. Softening of demand in Whitefield is likely on account of the upcoming metro rail work.

On the residential front, new launches are likely to remain conservative. This is mainly attributed to the recent policies/restrictions, high levels of unsold inventory as well as high price points.

The demand for the less than Rs. 1 crore segment is likely to strengthen on account of continued lowering in home loan interest rates, thereby increasing the affordability factor. Capital values are, however, expected to remain stable as per current levels and the main deciding variable will be the unit sizes. Developers are likely to offer higher number of units with smaller dimensions to capitalise on demand.

On the retail front, retailers are exhibiting cautiousness with regard to their future expansion plans; and are likely to remain in status quo in the upcoming quarters.

We will most likely witness retail expansion in the food & beverage segment.

With all these recent reforms, policy changes and demonetisation drive, transformation of RE sector is afoot and , 2017 will be a ‘Year of Hope' for buyers as well as developers.

The sector will witness minimization of risks, boost in buyers’ confidence, and encourage overall transparency & accountability.

Shrinivas Rao

The impact of demonetisation & relaxation in FDI regulations is likely to unfold by the next three to four quarters.
title: A mixed bag for real estate

text:
The city of Bhopal , the capital of Madhya Pradesh , is spick and span for now. The Swachch Bharat mission has been taken seriously and the Corporation is doing its best to get citizens involved in the cleanliness spirit.

As you go around the city you cannot help be awed by the two magnificent water-bodies that make up the Bhopal Wetlands, a Ramsar designated one and a magnificent heritage.

The Chota Talab or the small lake, is a deeper and natural water body. Here are fountains and oarsmen practising rowing. In the evening a beautiful sight.

The larger lake, the Bada Talab, is reputedly a 1000-year-old man-made one. Built by Raja Bhoj, the funder of Bhopal, it is a magnificent 32 sq. km water-spread and the eye cannot see the end of the lake.

Here too from the boating club, boats can be hired and time spent on the water A small island hosts the ‘dargah’ or tomb of a Sufi saint. Birds fill the trees here, roosting at night.

Constant endeavour

The city of Bhopal has been blessed with this water and depends to an extent on it for its daily requirements. A project funded by the Japanese International Cooperation Assistance has helped improve the shoreline, develop a park and a walking track all along, divert sewage and prevent flooding by strengthening the embankment.

The project is now over, yet maintaining an urban lake is not a project but a constant endeavour calling for eternal vigilance.

As ones walk around the smaller lake one notices a small channel brining raw sewage into it.

The waters in the small patch have eutrophied and a smell hangs in the air.

Quick action is called for but are the citizens vigilant and have they a good rapport with the authorities ?

The large lake dried up twice, in 2002 and 2008, says the young man who is rowing me to the tomb of the Sufi saint. Is the catchment being managed well enough, is debris being dumped in the channels which lead to the lake, is a catchment management system in place with the right institution created for it ?

Again, it is community interaction which will play a crucial role in preserving this functional heritage.

Step-wells

One searches for Baolis or step-wells in old Bhopal. Of the four that one could ask for to see, two have completely disappeared.

Filled by land sharks and over one, a tower has been built.

Of the remaining two, water was being pumped from one till a couple of months ago till the pump broke down.

It has not been repaired nor is the step-well clean. Unless a partnership is struck with the neighbouring community , it is unlikely that the well will be maintained and may meet the fate of the other two.

The last Baoli is under the ASI and they are doing their best to repair and rehabilitate a magnificent structure, still full of water.

It would have been best if these four and more step-wells had been brought back to life as living and functional heritage, supplying water to the locality yet being showcased for the tourists who would inevitably come to see them bolstering the local economy rather than being an archaeological preserve.

The Mayor of Bhopal is a dynamic personality, interested very much in keeping alive the magnificence of a city just entering a phase of rapid urbanisation.

With committed citizen groups working with the local government it is possible to become water secure, climate resilient, preserve heritage and be water sufficient .

Going local is truly the path to water wisdom. Bhopal can show the way.

S. Vishwanath

zenrainman@gmail.com
title: Go local, be water secure

HDFC Realty, India’s leading real estate advisory solutions company, has been working on the aggregation of real estate agents across key cities for the past few months. To take this initiative further, it has now launched ‘PropPartner’ - an exclusive mobile application for brokers. This app is now live on both Android and iOS platforms.

Post-registration, the PropPartner App gives brokers access to:

· Projects exclusively being marketed by HDFC Realty

· Featured projects - with special schemes by developers

· Projects with HDFC Special Payment Plan schemes

All listed projects would also be approved by HDFC for home loans.

Project details

The app allows the users (real estate agents) to profile their city / area of operation as also the other cities that they are interested to source the projects from, for their customers.

The ‘in-app’ sharing functionality lets the agents share the project details with their customers directly, using any of the sharing apps available on their phone.

The app also has an instant ‘lead pushing’ mechanism which reduces the time lag in responding to inquiries.

Commenting on the new launch, Renu Sud Karnad, Managing Director, HDFC Ltd., said, “The objective is to give brokers larger options to property in their micro-markets as well as other cities and locations. In the current market environment, the PropPartner app would provide the real estate agents an opportunity to market projects in other locations and to help them in their additional top line growth.”

Broker Aggregation Programme

Vikram Goel, CEO, HDFC Realty, said, “We are very happy to launch the PropPartner Mobile App. It is a step forward in our Broker Aggregation Programme, which we launched a couple of months ago. Real estate agents will find it convenient to register themselves though their mobiles and start using the information about projects being marketed by HDFC Realty. We intend to add more features to this app to enhance user experience.”

HDFC Realty has already rolled out an internal campaign “Broker Bhai” which extends to the PAN India HDFC Realty team the facility to enrol the real estate agents who have an existing relationship with the company.

Currently, the app has a total of around 4,500 broker registrations with more than 1,500 downloads so far.

As a part of its Broker Aggregation, HDFC Realty has already organised meets in Mumbai, Pune and other cities of Maharashtra and Gujarat for developers such as Brigade Group, SARE and EKTA Group for cross-city sales and for promotion of the PropPartner App.
title: HDFC Realty launches ‘PropPartner’ app for real estate agents

I own a flat in a colony comprising 4 blocks with a total number of 80 flats. There are 10 entrances, each leading to 8 flats. At present we do not have a registered association for carrying out maintenance work. It is managed independently by the owners of the 10 entrances. If we want to enter into a joint venture with a promoter for redevelopment of our colony, is it necessary to form a registered association?

R. Saraswathi

Chennai

As the redevelopment of the property would involve key decisions, it is advisable to register the association and take decisions in general body meeting. The elected officer bearers could interact with the developer. Once the project is completed, the new owners could be inducted into the association.
title: Redevelopment of colony

text:
The Bombay High Court has asked the Maharashtra government to build a new prison with kitchen and other facilities to solve the problem of space constraint.

A Bench of Justices Abhay Oka and Amjad Sayed, asked the State government to submit a plan for setting up a new prison by January 2017.

The Bench said that the prison should contain all necessary infrastructure and facilities required by house inmates.

“The government should consider setting up a new prison, which not only provides space to the inmates, but also has all the modern facilities for the prisoners to perform their daily chores,” the Bench added.

The court was hearing a petition filed by Shaikh Ibrahim Abdul who is lodged in Yerwada jail in Pune. The petitioner’s lawyer, Uday Warunjikar, claimed that the jail has a “poor” living condition.

At a previous hearing, the government had informed that the food quality at Yerwada jail was good but the jail had a space crunch. It had also said that the jail has a capacity to house 2,323 prisoners but about 6,000 inmates are lodged there presently. — PTI
title: Build new jail to solve overcrowding: HC to State

text:
The proposed 710 kilometre Mumbai-Nagpur Super Expressway will be going cashless with the Maharashtra government planning to use modern technology for levying toll. The move is part of the State’s efforts to boost digital payments.

“Instead of toll nakas, there will be RFID [radio-frequency identification] sensors to enable commuters to pay toll,” PWD Principal Secretary Ashish Kumar Singh said.

“There will not be toll nakas on the expressway — but only at entry and exit points. The amount would be deducted with use of a prepaid RFID tag on vehicles. As soon as a vehicle takes the expressway, and till the time it is on the expressway, the information will be gathered on a computer system at the toll plaza and the amount will be deducted from the RFID tag,” he said.

The official said that the tag is operational on most State highways, but very few people know about it. To popularise its use, government plans to have only one tag on all highways in the State, he added.

The proposed expressway is expected to be completed in three years. — PTI

A prepaid radio-frequency identification tag will be used on vehicles to deduct toll
title: Mumbai-Nagpur expressway ride may to go cashless

text:
Veteran Congress leader and former Union Minister Balasaheb Vikhe-Patil passed away at his home following a long illness. He was 84 years old.

Vikhe-Patil is survived by a wife, two daughters and three sons — one of them is the Leader of Opposition in Maharashtra, Radhakrishna Vikhe-Patil.

Vikhe-Patil breathed his last at his home in Loni-Pravara on Friday evening.

He was one of the pioneers of Maharashtra’s cooperative movement. He also launched Asia’s first cooperative sugar factory at Loni, in his home district Ahmednagar. He represented the Ahmednagar Lok Sabha constituency for eight terms.

Though he was a staunch Congressman, Vikhe-Patil shifted his allegiance to Shiv Sena for brief period during the government of former Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee. During this time, he initially served as the Minister of State for Finance, and later as the Union Minister for Heavy Industries.

The Governor of Maharashtra C. H. Vidyasagar Rao expressed grief over Vikhe-Patil’s demise.

In a letter to Mr. Radhakrishna Vikhe Patil, the Governor said, “Shri Balasaheb Vikhe-Patil was a towering leader in the cooperation movement in Maharashtra. His knowledge of agriculture, irrigation and rural development was remarkable. In his demise, Maharashtra has lost a visionary leader and a great human being.”

Chief Minister Devendra Fadnavis, in his condolence message, said that Vikhe-Patil was a visionary when it came to setting up a model of rural development. “His knowledge in cooperation, irrigation and agriculture was extra ordinary. He used it to set up a number of people oriented projects. He was someone who knew the vein of rural transformation,” Mr. Fadnavis said.
title: Veteran Congressman Balasaheb Vikhe-Patil dies at 84

text:
The Vishva Hindu Parishad’s international working president, Pravin Togadia on Friday claimed that Hindu community in India continues to be “unsafe and underdeveloped” despite being a majority.

“There is a need for majority protection commission in India rather than a minority protection commission as the majority here feels unsafe and scared,” Mr. Togadia said at a rally of VHP officer bearers and workers here.

“Our temples are being destroyed and the governments are citing court orders. I want to ask whether the law is only for the Hindus? Why don’t you dare to remove loudspeakers from Masjids who flout guidelines issued by the Supreme Court? You make an issue on the dead body of one Muslim but you don’t care if the dead bodies of Hindus pile up,” Mr. Togadia said.

He also demanded that houses of the Hindus in Kashmir valley — “which were snatched from them” — be given back.

Citing statistics, the VHP leader claimed that 17 crore Hindus sleep hungry everyday in India.

“One forth of our population is illiterate. Basic health and the medical profession are out of the reach of middle class now. There are 15 crore unemployed Hindu youth in this country. Out of 17 crore farmers in this country, only six crores have a roof to live under. The farmers are committing suicide and business community is being harassed,” he alleged and claimed that his organisation would work towards in achieving the “lost glory” of Hindus.

He demanded that school fees of 10 crore Hindu children be waived off, “just as the government does for 95 lakh Muslim children.” He also said that his organisation was committed to protect cows.
title: Hindus are unsafe in India, claims VHP leader Pravin Togadia

text:
Defence Minister Manohar Parrikar on Friday claimed that BJP has 20 per cent pro-incumbency among people ahead of 2017 State Assembly elections.

Talking to reporters here, Mr. Parrikar claimed that according to a survey carried out by the party in Goa, 58 per cent people want BJP to return to power.

“Last time we had crossed 36 per cent vote share, this time we will cross 45 per cent vote share. We are prepared to contest all 40 seats. It does not mean BJP will field candidates in all constituencies, but we are confident of a comfortable majority,” Mr. Parrikar said.

In reply to a question about the prospects of continuing a pre-poll alliance with regional outfit Maharashtrawadi Gomantak Party (MGP), Mr. Parrikar said that BJP’s doors were not closed.

The alliance is reportedly on the verge of breaking after Chief Minister Laxmikant Parsekar sacked two MGP Ministers — Deepak Dhavalikar and Sudin Dhavalikar — from the State cabinet. The Dhavalikar siblings had demanded that BJP should replace Mr. Parsekar as the Chief Minister if it wants to continue the alliance.

The MGP leaders have confirmed that the party has begun alliance talks with Goa Suraskha Manch, a regional outfit floated by rebel RSS leader Subhash Velingkar.
title: BJP will cross 45 per cent vote share in Goa: Parrikar

text:
Chief Minister Laxmikant Parsekar on Friday said that he will meet Archbishop Filipe Neri Ferrao to discuss the charges of corruption and weak governance the latter levelled against Goa government at the civic reception on Wednesday.

“What we see is an extensive environmental and social damage to Goa, which has generated rampant corruption and [has] even weakened governance,” Mr. Ferrao had said. Mr. Parsekar disagreed with the assessment.

He also rejected the charge made by rebel RSS leader Subhash Velingkar on Thursday that BJP was indulging in “appeasement of minorities”. He said the BJP government was working for all communities.

Defence Minister and former Goa CM Manohar Parrikar, who also attended the civic reception, refused to comment on the Archbishop’s remarks.

“I will answer any of your questions regarding BJP’s election issues,” Mr. Parrikar said at the BJP headquarters in the city.

Shiv Sena warns complaint

Meanwhile the Shiv Sena warned that it will file a complaint with the Election Commission on Saturday against the Archbishop’s comments about guiding Catholics for ethical voting in the upcoming Assembly elections.

“If the Church calls political parties for talks and the Archbishop orders his community about whom to vote, Election Commission should take action,” Shiv Sena Rajya Sabha MP Sanjay Raut told reporters, adding “If Jama Masjid Imam issues fatwa for Muslims ahead of elections, then the BJP objects. Is this fatwa of the Archbishop acceptable to them?”

In his address at the civic reception the Archbishop had also said that in view of the elections, “the Church leadership in Goa will take up once again the duty bound task. We do issue guidelines to our faithful on how to exercise their franchise. These guidelines are read out in our churches, but they never mention the name of any candidate or any political party.”
title: Parsekar to meet Archbishop over corruption remarks
